FASCICLE: A small bundle or collection; a compact cluster; as, a fascicleof fibers; a fascicle of flowers or roots.
FORESKIN: The fold of skin which covers the glans of the penis; theprepuce.
FOOTHOT: Hastily; immediately; instantly; on the spot; hotfloot. Gower.Custance have they taken anon, foothot. Chaucer.
FUSS: To be overbusy or unduly anxious about trifles; to make abustle or ado. Sir W. Scott.
FOLIATE: Furnished with leaves; leafy; as, a foliate stalk. Foliatecurve. (Geom.) Same as Folium.
FLUTIST: A performer on the flute; a flautist. Busby.
FULMINURIC: Pertaining to fulminic and cyanuric acids, and designating anacid so called. Fulminuric acid (Chem.), a white, crystalline,explosive subatance, H3C3N3O3, forming well known salts, and obtainedfrom the fulnunates. It is isomeric with cyanuric acid, and hence isalso called isocyanuric acid.
FIGUREHEAD: The figure, statue, or bust, on the prow of a ship.
FERRETTO: Copper sulphide, used to color glass. Hebert.
FROM: Out of the neighborhood of; lessening or losing proximity to;leaving behind; by reason of; out of; by aid of; -- used wheneverdeparture, setting out, commencement of action, being, state,occurrence, etc., or procedure, emanation, absence, separation, etc.,are to be expressed. It is construed with, and indicates, the pointof space or time at which the action, state, etc., are regarded assetting out or beginning; also, less frequently, the source, thecause, the occasion, out of which anything proceeds; -- thearitithesis and correlative of to; as, it, is one hundred miles fromBoston to Springfield; he took his sword from his side; lightproceeds from the sun; separate the coarse wool from the fine; menhave all sprung from Adam, and often go from good to bad, and frombad to worse; the merit of an action depends on the principle fromwhich it proceeds; men judge of facts from personal knowledge, orfrom testimony.Experience from the time past to the time present. Bacon.The song began from Jove. Drpden.From high Mæonia's rocky shores I came. Addison.If the wind blow any way from shore. Shak.
FINNISH: Of or pertaining to Finland, to the Finns, or to theirlanguage.-- n.
FLEXILE: Flexible; pliant; pliable; easily bent; plastic; tractable.Wordsworth.
FRINGE TREE: A small oleaceous tree (Chionanthus virginica), of the southernUnited States, having clusters of white flowers with slender petals.It is often cultivated.
FLINT GLASS: A soft, heavy, brilliant glass, consisting essentially of asilicate of lead and potassium. It is used for tableware, and foroptical instruments, as prisms, its density giving a high degree ofdispersive power; -- so called, because formerly the silica wasobtained from pulverized flints. Called also crystal glass. Cf.Glass.
FROST SIGNAL: A signal consisting of a white flag with a black center, usedby the United States Weather Bureau to indicate that a local frost isexpected. It is used only in Florida and along the coasts of thePacific and the Gulf Mexico.
FLANGED: Having a flange or flanges; as, a flanged wheel.
FRAGMENTIST: A writer of fragments; as, the fragmentist of Wolfenbüttel.[R.]
FLUE: An inclosed passage way for establishing and directing acurrent of air, gases, etc.; an air passage; esp.:(a) A compartment or division of a chimney for conveying flame andsmoke to the outer air.(b) A passage way for conducting a current of fresh, foul, or heatedair from one place to another.(c) (Steam Boiler) A pipe or passage for conveying flame and hotgases through surrounding water in a boiler; -- distinguished from atube which holds water and is surrounded by fire. Small flues arecalled fire tubes or simply tubes. Flue boiler. See under Boiler.-- Flue bridge, the separating low wall between the flues and thelaboratory of a reverberatory furnace.-- Flue plate (Steam Boiler), a plate to which the ends of the fluesare fastened; -- called also flue sheet, tube sheet, and tube plate.-- Flue surface (Steam Boiler), the aggregate surface of fluesexposed to flame or the hot gases.
FLOWERAGE: State of flowers; flowers, collectively or in general.Tennyson.
FOOT VALVE: A suction valve or check valve at the lower end of a pipe;esp., such a valve in a steam-engine condenser opening to the airpump.
FLATBOAT: A boat with a flat bottom and square ends; -- used for thetransportation of bulky freight, especially in shallow waters.
FROSTBITE: The freezing, or effect of a freezing, of some part of thebody, as the ears or nose. Kane.
FABLER: A writer of fables; a fabulist; a dealer in untruths orfalsehoods. Br. Hall.
FAUBOURG: A suburb of French city; also, a district now within a city,but formerly without its walls.
FORMALIST: One overattentive to forms, or too much confined to them; esp.,one who rests in external religious forms, or observes strictly theoutward forms of worship, without possessing the life and spirit ofreligion.As far a formalist from wisdom sits, In judging eyes, as libertinesfrom wits. Young.
FULL-SAILED: Having all its sails set,; hence, without restriction orreservation. Massinger.
FERIER: , compar. of Fere, fierce. [Obs.]Rhenus ferier than the cataract. Marston.
FORBIDDENLY: In a forbidden or unlawful manner. Shak.
FOCAL: Belonging to,or concerning, a focus; as, a focal point. Focaldistance, or length,of a lens or mirror (Opt.), the distance of thefocus from the surface of the lens or mirror, or more exactly, in thecase of a lens, from its optical center. --Focal distance of atelescope, the distance of the image of an object from the objectglass.
FLUSHNESS: The state of being flush; abundance.
FORMICATE: Resembling, or pertaining to, an ant or ants.
FRUSTRATION: The act of frustrating; disappointment; defeat; as, thefrustration of one's designs
FRINGILLA: A genus of birds, with a short, conical, pointed bill. Itformerly included all the sparrows and finches, but is now restrictedto certain European finches, like the chaffinch and brambling.
FAECES: Excrement; ordure; also, settlings; sediment after infusion ordistillation. [Written also feces.]
FRIGATOON: A Venetian vessel, with a square stern, having only a mainmast,jigger mast, and bowsprit; also a sloop of war ship-rigged.
FORWORN: Much worn. [Obs.]A silly man, in simple weeds forworn. Spenser.
FROTHINESS: State or quality of being frothy.
FURFUROUS: Made of bran; furfuraceous. [R.] "Furfurous bread." SydneySmith.
FLAVIN: A yellow, vegetable dyestuff, resembling quercitron.
FOOTNOTE: A note of reference or comment at the foot of a page.
FORBLACK: Very black. [Obs.]As any raven's feathers it shone forblack. Chaucer.
FILIATION: The assignment of a bastard child to some one as its ather;affiliation. Smart.
FELLOW: To suit with; to pair with; to match. [Obs.] Shak.
FORGIVABLE: Capable of being forgiven; pardonable; venial. Sherwood.
FIGURINE: A very small figure, whether human or of an animal; especially,one in terra cotta or the like; -- distinguished from statuette,which is applied to small figures in bronze, marble, etc.
FERROUS: Pertaining to, or derived from, iron; -- especially used ofcompounds of iron in which the iron has its lower valence; as,ferrous sulphate.
FLAG: An aquatic plant, with long, ensiform leaves, belonging toeither of the genera Iris and Acorus. Cooper's flag, the cat-tail(Typha latifolia), the long leaves of which are placed between thestaves of barrels to make the latter water-tight.-- Corn flag. See under 2d Corn.-- Flag broom, a coarse of broom, originally made of flags orrushes.-- Flag root, the root of the sweet flag.-- Sweet flag. See Calamus, n., 2.
FROLIC: Full of levity; dancing, playing, or frisking about; full ofpranks; frolicsome; gay; merry.The frolic wind that breathes the spring. Milton.The gay, the frolic, and the loud. Waller.
FRANKFORT BLACK: . A black pigment used in copperplate printing, prepared byburning vine twigs, the lees of wine, etc. McElrath.
FISSILINGUIA: A group of Lacertilia having the tongue forked, including thecommon lizards. [Written also Fissilingues.]
FARNESS: The state of being far off; distance; remoteness. [R.] Grew.
FRAY: Affray; broil; contest; combat.Who began this bloody fray Shak.
FELLOW-CREATURE: One of the same race or kind; one made by the same Creator.Reason, by which we are raised above our fellow-creatures, thebrutes. I. Watts.
FASHIONABLE: A person who conforms to the fashions; -- used chiefly in theplural.
FEDERATE: United by compact, as sovereignties, states, or nations; joinedin confederacy; leagued; confederate; as, federate nations.
FELONIOUS: Having the quality of felony; malignant; malicious; villainous;traitorous; perfidious; in a legal sense, done with intent to commita crime; as, felonious homicide.O thievish Night, Why should'st thou, but for some felonious end, Inthy dark lantern thus close up the stars Milton.-- Fe*lo"ni`ous*ly, adv.-- Fe*lo"ni`ous*ness, n.
FOREDATE: To date before the true time; to antendate.
FAVOSITES: A genus of fossil corals abundant in the Silurian and Devonianrocks, having polygonal cells with perforated walls.
FRETT: The worn side of the bank of a river. See 4th Fret, n., 4.
FLOW: imp. sing. of Fly, v. i. Chaucer.
FETCH: To bring one's self; to make headway; to veer; as, to fetchabout; to fetch to windward. Totten. To fetch away (Naut.), to breakloose; to roll slide to leeward.-- To fetch and carry, to serve obsequiously, like a trainedspaniel.
FRIARY: Like a friar; pertaining to friars or to a convent. [Obs.]Camden.
FORETASTER: One who tastes beforehand, or before another.
FASCICULE: A small bunch or bundle; a fascicle; as, a fascicule of fibers,hairs, or spines.
FORCEFUL: Full of or processing force; exerting force; mighty.-- Force"ful*ly, adv.Against the steed he threw His forceful spear. Dryden.
FLORAN: Tin ore scarcely perceptible in the stone; tin ore stamped veryfine. Pryce.
FISTULARIA: A genus of fishes, having the head prolonged into a tube, withthe mouth at the extremity.
FLAMMIVOMOUS: Vomiting flames, as a volcano. W. Thompson. (1745).
FOREORDAIN: To ordain or appoint beforehand; to preordain; to predestinate;to predetermine. Hooker.
FAIR-MINDED: Unprejudiced; just; judicial; honest.-- Fair"*mind`ed*ness, n.
FRITINANCY: A chirping or creaking, as of a cricket. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
FOURDRINIER: A machine used in making paper; -- so named from an earlyinventor of improvements in this class of machinery.
FRAZZLE: To fray; to wear or pull into tatters or tag ends; to tatter; --used literally and figuratively. [Prov. Eng. & U. S.]
FILTHY: Defiled with filth, whether material or moral; nasty; dirty;polluted; foul; impure; obscene. "In the filthy-mantled pool." Shak.He which is filthy let him be filthy still. Rev. xxii. 11.
FALUNS: A series of strata, of the Middle Tertiary period, of France,abounding in shells, and used by Lyell as the type of his Miocenesubdivision.
FROND: The organ formed by the combination or union into one body ofstem and leaf, and often bearing the fructification; as, the frond ofa fern or of a lichen or seaweed; also, the peculiar leaf of a palmtree.
FOOTLIGHT: One of a row of lights in the front of the stage in a theater,etc., and on a level therewith. Before the footlights, upon thestage; -- hence, in the capacity of an actor.
FLIMSINESS: The state or quality of being flimsy.
FALLEN: Dropped; prostrate; degraded; ruined; decreased; dead.Some ruined temple or fallen monument. Rogers.
FOREBODEMENT: The act of foreboding; the thing foreboded.
FLOREAL: The eight month of the French republican calendar. It beganApril 20, and ended May 19. See Vendémiare.
FOOTSTOOL: A low stool to support the feet of one when sitting.
FEBRILE: Pertaining to fever; indicating fever, or derived from it; as,febrile symptoms; febrile action. Dunglison.
FERRUGINATED: Having the color or properties of the rust of iron.
FLINGDUST: One who kicks up the dust; a streetwalker; a low manner. [Obs.]Beau. & Fl.
FIDDLEWOOD: The wood of several West Indian trees, mostly of the genusCitharexylum.
FIXATIVE: That which serves to set or fix colors or drawings, as amordant.
FUNDAMENTAL: Pertaining to the foundation or basis; serving for thefoundation. Hence: Essential, as an element, principle, or law;important; original; elementary; as, a fundamental truth; afundamental axiom.The fundamental reasons of this war. Shak.Some fundamental antithesis in nature. Whewell.Fundamental bass (Mus.), the root note of a chord; a bass formed ofthe roots or fundamental tones of the chords.-- Fundamental chord (Mus.), a chord, the lowest tone of which isits root.-- Fundamental colors, red, green, and violet-blue. See Primarycolors, under Color.
FORESTAFF: An instrument formerly used at sea for taking the altitudes ofheavenly bodies, now superseded by the sextant; -- called also cross-staff. Brande & C.
FRISKINESS: State or quality of being frisky.
FEUILLETON: A part of a French newspaper (usually the bottom of the page),devoted to light literature, criticism, etc.; also, the article ortale itself, thus printed.
FUNERAL: Per. taining to a funeral; used at the interment of the dead;as, funeral rites, honors, or ceremonies. Shak. Funeral pile, astructure of combustible material, upon which a dead body is placedto be reduced to ashes, as part of a funeral rite; a pyre.-- Fu"ner*al*ly, adv. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
FRONTLESS: Without face or front; shameless; not diffident; impudent.[Obs.] "Frontless vice." Dryden. "Frontless flattery." Pope.
FIBRILLOUS: Pertaining to, or composed of, fibers.
FLUIDNESS: The state of being flluid; fluidity.
FEUDALITY: The state or quality of being feudal; feudal form orconstitution. Burke.
FINNIKIN: A variety of pigeon, with a crest somewhat resembling the maneof a horse. [Written also finikin.]
FORE-NIGHT: The evening between twilight and bedtime. [Scot.]
FLUCTUATE: To cause to move as a wave; to put in motion. [R.]And fluctuate all the still perfume. Tennyson.
FIG: A small fruit tree (Ficus Carica) with large leaves, known fromthe remotest antiquity. It was probably native from Syria westward tothe Canary Islands.
FALLING: from Fall, v. i. Falling away, Falling off, etc. See To fallaway, To fall off, etc., under Fall, v. i.-- Falling band, the plain, broad, linen collar turning down overthe doublet, worn in the early part of the 17th century.-- Falling sickness (Med.), epilepsy. Shak.-- Falling star. (Astron.) See Shooting star.-- Falling stone, a stone falling through the atmosphere; ameteorite; an aërolite.-- Falling tide, the ebb tide.-- Falling weather, a rainy season. [Colloq.] Bartlett.
FUR: Articles of clothing made of fur; as, a set of furs for a lady(a collar, tippet, or cape, muff, etc.).Wrapped up in my furs. Lady M. W. Montagu.
FILLET: A piece of lean meat without bone; sometimes, a long striprolled together and tied.
FOOLHARDY: Daring without judgment; foolishly adventurous and bold.Howell.
FETUS: The young or embryo of an animal in the womb, or in the egg;often restricted to the later stages in the development of viviparousand oviparous animals, embryo being applied to the earlier stages.[Written also foetus.]
FARTHEST: Most distant or remote; as, the farthest degree.  See Furthest.
FENESTRATION: The arrangement and proportioning of windows; -- used by modernwriters for the decorating of an architectural composition by meansof the window (and door) openings, their ornaments, and proportions.
FLUORIDE: A binary compound of fluorine with another element or radical.Calcium fluoride (Min.), fluorite, CaF2. See Fluorite.
FLOCCILLATION: A delirious picking of bedclothes by a sick person, as if topick off flocks of wool; carphology; -- an alarming symptom in acutediseases. Dunglison.
FRY: To cook in a pan or on a griddle (esp. with the use of fat,butter, or olive oil) by heating over a fire; to cook in boiling lardor fat; as, to fry fish; to fry doughnuts.
FRANION: A paramour; a loose woman; also, a gay, idle fellow. [Obs.]Spenser.
FULVOUS: Tawny; dull yellow, with a mixture of gray and brown. Lindley.
FOREAPPOINT: To set, order, or appoint, beforehand. Sherwood.
FREE-SOIL: Pertaining to, or advocating, the non-extension of slavery; --esp. applied to a party which was active during the period 1846-1856.[U.S.] -- Free"soil`er, n. [U.S.] -- Free"-soil`ism, n. [U.S.]
FOXERY: Behavior like that of a fox; [Obs.] Chaucer.
FREEZING: Tending to freeze; for freezing; hence, cold or distant inmanner.-- Frrez"ing*ly, adv. Freezing machine. See Ice machine, under Ice.-- Freezing mixture, a mixture (of salt and snow or of chemicalsalts) for producing intense cold.-- Freezing point, that degree of a thermometer at which a fluidbegins to freeze; -- applied particularly to water, whose freezingpoint is at 32º Fahr., and at 0º Centigrade.
FUNGOSITY: The quality of that which is fungous; fungous excrescence.Dunglison.
FERVENCY: The state of being fervent or warm; ardor; warmth of feeling ordevotion; eagerness.When you pray, let it be with attention, with fervency, and withperseverance. Wake.
FLOCCOSE: Having tufts of soft hairs, which are often deciduous.
FORRAY: To foray; to ravage; to pillage.For they that morn had forrayed all the land. Fairfax.
FARMYARD: The yard or inclosure attached to a barn, or the space inclosedby the farm buildings.
FLEET: To slip on the whelps or the barrel of a capstan or windlass; -- said of a cable or hawser.
FEMININE: Any one of those words which are the appellations of females,or which have the terminations usually found in such words; as,actress, songstress, abbess, executrix.There are but few true feminines in English. Latham.
FIST: the index mark [], used to direct special attention to thepassage which follows. Hand over fist (Naut.), rapidly; hand overhand.
FINIS: An end; conclusion. It is often placed at the end of a book.
FIELDPIECE: A cannon mounted on wheels, for the use of a marching army; apiece of field artillery; -- called also field gun.
FAIR: Without sudden change of direction or curvature; smooth;fowing; -- said of the figure of a vessel, and of surfaces, waterlines, and other lines.
FRATERNIZATION: The act of fraternizing or uniting as brothers.I hope that no French fraternization . . . could so change the heartsof Englishmen. Burke.
FOURTH: The interval of two tones and a semitone, embracing fourdiatonic degrees of the scale; the subdominant of any key. TheFourth, specifically, un the United States, the fourth day of July,the anniversary of the declaration of American independence; as, tocelebrate the Fourth.
FERAE: A group of mammals which formerly included the Carnivora,Insectivora, Marsupialia, and lemurs, but is now often restricted tothe Carnivora.
FEARER: One who fars. Sir P. Sidney.
FULL-FORMED: Full in form or shape; rounded out with flesh.The full-formed maids of Afric. Thomson.
FEEBLY: In a feeble manner.The restored church . . . contended feebly, and with half a heart.Macaulay.
FLECTIONAL: Capable of, or pertaining to, flection or inflection.A flectional word is a phrase in the bud. Earle.
FRIEZER: One who, or that which, friezes or frizzes.
FRIEZE: A kind of coarse woolen cloth or stuff with a shaggy or tufted(friezed) nap on one side. "Robes of frieze." Goldsmith.
FLINTINESS: The state or quality of being flinty; hardness; cruelty. Beau.& Fl.
FILICAL: Belonging to the Filices, r ferns.
FOUMART: The European polecat; -- called also European ferret, andfitchew. See Polecat. [Written also foulmart, foulimart, andfulimart.]
FAULT-FINDER: One who makes a practice off discovering others' faults andcensuring them; a scold.
FENERATION: The act of fenerating; interest. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
FLEAM: A sharp instrument used for opening veins, lancing gums, etc.;a kind of lancet. Fleam tooth, a tooth of a saw shaped like anisosceles triangle; a peg tooth. Knight.
FONTAL: Pertaining to a font, fountain, source, or origin; original;primitive. [R.]From the fontal light of ideas only can a man draw intellectualpower. Coleridge.
FIDDLESTRING: One of the catgut strings of a fiddle.
FEMINITY: Womanliness; femininity. [Obs.] "Trained up in true feminity."Spenser.
FARRAGO: A mass ccomposed of various materials confusedly mixed; amedley; a mixture.A confounded farrago of doubts, fears, hopes, wishes, and all theflimsy furniture of a country miss's brain. Sheridan.
FORPINE: To waste away completely by suffering or torment. [Archaic]"Pale as a forpined ghost." Chaucer.
FORESTAL: Of or pertaining to forests; as, forestal rights.
FALLIBILITY: The state of being fallible; liability to deceive or to bedeceived; as, the fallibity of an argument or of an adviser.
FIDDLESTICK: The bow, strung with horsehair, used in playing the fiddle; afiddle bow.
FICTITIOUS: Feigned; imaginary; not real; fabulous; counterfeit; false; notgenuine; as, fictitious fame.The human persons are as fictitious as the airy ones. Pope.-- Fic*ti"tious*ly, adv.-- Fic*ti"tious*ness, n.
FACTO: In fact; by the act or fact. De facto. (Law) See De facto.
FERMENT: To cause ferment of fermentation in; to set in motion; toexcite internal emotion in; to heat.Ye vigorous swains! while youth ferments your blood. Pope.
FULMINIC: Pertaining to fulmination; detonating; specifically (Chem.),pertaining to, derived from, or denoting, an acid, so called; as,fulminic acid. Fulminic acid (Chem.), a complex acid, H2C2N2O2,isomeric with cyanic and cyanuric acids, and not known in the freestate, but forming a large class of highly explosive salts, thefulminates. Of these, mercuric fulminate, the most common, is used,mixed with niter, to fill percussion caps, charge cartridges, etc.-- Fulminic acid is made by the action of nitric acid on alcohol.
FRESCO: To paint in fresco, as walls.
FOOTPRINT: The impression of the foot; a trace or footmark; as,"Footprints of the Creator."
FRETFUL: Disposed to fret; ill-humored; peevish; angry; in a state ofvexation; as, a fretful temper.-- Fret"ful-ly, adv.-- Fret"ful-ness, n.
FALK: The razorbill. [Written also falc, and faik.] [Prov. Eng.]
FISSIGEMMATION: A process of reproduction intermediate between fission andgemmation.
FUM: To play upon a fiddle. [Obs.]Follow me, and fum as you go. B. Jonson.
FRONTISPIECE: The part which first meets the eye; as:(a) (Arch.) The principal front of a building. [Obs. or R.](b) An ornamental figure or illustration fronting the first page, ortitlepage, of a book; formerly, the titlepage itself.
FAY: A fairy; an elf. "Yellow-skirted fays." Milton.
FELT GRAIN: , the grain of timber which is transverse to the annular ringsor plates; the direction of the medullary rays in oak and some othertimber. Knight.
FLAGELLATE: To whip; to scourge; to flog.
FRENCHIFY: To make French; to infect or imbue with the manners or tastesof the French; to Gallicize. Burke.
FRONDENT: Covered with leaves; leafy; as, a frondent tree. [R.]
FLIPPER: A broad flat limb used for swimming, as those of seals, seaturtles, whales, etc.
FUMY: Producing fumes; fumous. "Drowned in fumy wine." H. Brooke.
FER-DE-LANCE: A large, venomous serpent (Trigonocephalus lanceolatus) ofBrazil and the West Indies. It is allied to the rattlesnake, but hasno rattle.
FRIGHTFULLY: In a frightful manner; to a frightful dagree.
FLATULENTLY: In a flatulent manner; with flatulence.
FESTLICH: Festive; fond of festive occasions. [Obs.] "A festlich man."Chaucer.
FOMES: Any substance supposed to be capable of absorbing, retaining,and transporting contagious or infectious germs; as, woolen clothesare said to be active fomites.
FORAY: A sudden or irregular incursion in border warfare; hence, anyirregular incursion for war or spoils; a raid. Spenser.The huge Earl Doorm, . . . Bound on a foray, rolling eyes of prey.Tennyson.
FIN KEEL: A projection downward from the keel of a yacht, resembling inshape the fin of a fish, though often with a cigar-shaped bulb oflead at the bottom, and generally made of metal. Its use is toballast the boat and also to enable her to sail close to the wind andto make the least possible leeway by offering great resistance tolateral motion through the water.
FILIATE: To adopt as son or daughter; to establish filiation between.[R.] Southey.
FOURSQUARE: Having four sides and four equal angles. Sir W. Raleigh.
FRITILLARIA: A genus of liliaceous plants, of which the crown-imperial(Fritillaria imperialis) is one species, and the Guinea-hen flower(F. Meleagris) another. See Crown-imperial.
FULCIBLE: Capable of being propped up. [Obs.] Cockeram.
FORMULARISTIC: Pertaining to, or exhibiting, formularization. Emerson.
FUTURELESS: Without prospect of betterment in the future. W. D. Howells.
FORESTAY: A large, strong rope, reaching from the foremast head to thebowsprit, to support the mast. See Illust. under Ship.
FORAMINOUS: Having foramina; full of holes; porous. Bacon.
FRAPLER: A blusterer; a rowdy. [Obs.]Unpolished, a frapler, and base. B. Jonson.
FILIPINO: A native of the Philippine Islands, specif. one of Spanishdescent or of mixed blood.
FRETTED: Interlaced one with another; -- said of charges and ordinaries.
FOXEARTH: A hole in the earth to which a fox resorts to hide himself.
FREEWHEEL: A clutch fitted in the rear hub of a cycle, which engages therear sprocket with the rear wheel when the pedals are rotatedforwards, but permits the rear wheel to run on free from the rearsprocket when the pedals are stopped or rotated backwards.Freewheelcycles are usually fitted with hub brakes or rim brakes,operated by back pedaling.
FETTER: 1. To put fetters upon; to shakle or confine the feet of with achain; to bind.My heels are fettered, but my fist is free. Milton.
FUTURE: That is to be or come hereafter; that will exist at any timeafter the present; as, the next moment is future, to the present.Future tense (Gram.), the tense or modification of a verb whichexpresses a future act or event.
FILE CLOSER: A commissioned or noncommissioned officer posted in the rear ofa line, or on the flank of a column, of soldiers, to rectify mistakesand insure steadiness and promptness in the ranks.
FATTISH: Somewhat fat; inclined to fatness.Coleridge, a puffy, anxious, obstructed-looking, fattish old man.Carlyle.
FRAULEIN: In Germany, a young lady; an unmarried woman; -- as a title,equivalent to Miss.
FASTIDIOUS: Difficult to please; delicate to fault; suited with difficulty;squeamish; as, a fastidious mind or ear; a fastidious appetite.Proud youth ! fastidious of the lower world. Young.
FLEDGE: Feathered; furnished with feathers or wings; able to fly.Hfledge with wings. Milton.
FAWN: A young deer; a buck or doe of the first year. See Buck.
FORHALL: To harass; to torment; to distress. [Obs.] Spenser.
FOURTEEN: Four and ten more; twice seven.
FLYAWAY GRASS: The hair grass (Agrostis scabra). So called from its lightpanicle, which is blown to great distances by the wind.
FINOS: Second best wool from Merino sheep. Gardner.
FELICITOUS: Characterized by felicity; happy; prosperous; delightful;skilful; successful; happily applied or expressed; appropriate.Felicitous words and images. M. Arnold.-- Fe*lic"i*tous*ly, adv.-- Fe*lic"i*tous*ness, n.
FARCEMENT: Stuffing; forcemeat. [Obs.]They spoil a good dish with . . . unsavory farcements. Feltham.
FUNDABLE: Capable of being funded, or converted into a fund; convertibleinto bonds.
FORFEITER: One who incurs a penalty of forfeiture.
FORESTALLER: One who forestalls; esp., one who forestalls the market. Locke.
FREE-SPOKEN: Accustomed to speak without reserve. Bacon.-- Free"-spo`ken-ness, n.
FANTASIA: A continuous composition, not divided into what are calledmovements, or governed by the ordinary rules of musical design, butin which the author's fancy roves unrestricted by set form.
FRETTER: One who, or that which, frets.
FRUMP: To insult; to flout; to mock; to snub. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
FLOROON: A border worked with flowers. Wright.
FISSIROSTRAL: Having the bill cleft beyond the horny part, as in the case ofswallows and goatsuckers.
FRIENDLESS: Destitute of friends; forsaken.-- Friend"less*ness, n.
FEATHERY: Pertaining to, or resembling, feathers; covered with, or aswith, feathers; as, feathery spray or snow. Milton.Ye feathery people of mid air. Barry Cornwall.
FOOTBATH: A bath for the feet; also, a vessel used in bathing the feet.
FLUTE A BEC: A beak flute, an older form of the flute, played with amouthpiece resembling a beak, and held like a flageolet.
FREQUENTLY: At frequent or short intervals; many times; often; repeatedly;commonly.
FILIGREE: Ornamental work, formerly with grains or breads, but nowcomposed of fine wire and used chiefly in decorating gold and silverto which the wire is soldered, being arranged in designs frequentlyof a delicate and intricate arabesque pattern.
FUNGICIDE: Anything that kills fungi.-- Fun`gi*ci"dal, n.
FLOURY: Of or resembling flour; mealy; covered with flour. Dickens.
FUSE: A tube or casing filled with combustible matter, by means ofwhich a charge of powder is ignited, as in blasting; -- called alsofuzee. See Fuze. Fuse hole, the hole in a shell prepared for thereception of the fuse. Farrow.
FRONTINGLY: In a fronting or facing position; opposingly.
FOUL-MOUTHED: Using language scurrilous, opprobrious, obscene, or profane;abusive.So foul-mouthed a witness never appeared in any cause. Addison.
FROSTWORK: The figurework, often fantastic and delicate, which moisturesometimes forms in freezing, as upon a window pane or a flagstone.
FELLNESS: The quality or state of being fell or cruel; fierce barbarity.Spenser.
FANCYWORK: Ornamental work with a needle or hook, as embroidery,crocheting, netting, etc.
FAULTER: One who commits a fault. [Obs.]Behold the faulter here in sight. Fairfax.
FUCHSINE: Aniline red; an artificial coal-tar dyestuff, of a metallicgreen color superficially, resembling cantharides, but when dissolvedforming a brilliant dark red. It consists of a hydrochloride oracetate of rosaniline. See Rosaniline.
FALSENESS: The state of being false; contrariety to the fact; inaccuracy;want of integrity or uprightness; double dealing; unfaithfulness;treachery; perfidy; as, the falseness of a report, a drawing, or asinger's notes; the falseness of a man, or of his word.
FEMERELL: A lantern, or louver covering, placed on a roof, forventilation or escape of smoke.
FORELOOK: To look beforehand or forward. [Obs.] Spenser.
FLUCAN: Soft clayey matter in the vein, or surrounding it. [Writtenalso flookan, flukan, and fluccan.]
FRONTIERSMAN: A man living on the frontier.
FLIGHTER: A horizontal vane revolving over the surface of wort in acooler, to produce a circular current in the liquor. Knight.
FLUAVIL: A hydrocarbon extracted from gutta-percha, as a yellow,resinous substance; -- called also fluanil.
FRIZ: To soften and make of even thickness by rubbing, as with pumicestone or a blunt instrument. Frizzing machine. (a) (Fabrics) Amachine for frizzing the surface of cloth. (b) (Wood Working) A benchwith a revolving cutter head slightly protruding above its surface,for dressing boards.
FROWY: Musty. rancid; as, frowy butter. "Frowy feed." Spenser
FOX-HUNTING: Pertaining to or engaged in the hunting of foxes; fond ofhunting foxes.
FOSSILIST: One who is versed in the science of fossils; a paleontologist.Joseph Black.
FAVOREDLY: In a favored or a favorable manner; favorably. [Obs.] Deut.xvii. 1. Arscham.
FLUENT: A variable quantity, considered as increasing or diminishing; -- called, in the modern calculus, the function or integral.
FANATICAL: Characteristic of, or relating to, fanaticism; fanatic. -Fa*nat"ic*al*ly, adv.-- Fa*nat"ic*al*ness, n.
FIR: A genus (Abies) of coniferous trees, often of large size andelegant shape, some of them valued for their timber and others fortheir resin. The species are distinguished as the balsam fir, thesilver fir, the red fir, etc. The Scoth fir is a Pinus.
FUNILIFORM: Resembling a cord in toughness and flexibility, as the roots ofsome endogenous trees.
FLOATY: Swimming on the surface; buoyant; light. Sir W. Raleigh.
FINALIST: Any of the players who meet in the final round of a tournamentin which the losers in any round do not play again.
FRUSTRATE: Vain; ineffectual; useless; unprofitable; null; voil; nugatory;of no effect. "Our frustrate search." Shak.
FEMALE RHYMES: double rhymes, or rhymes (called in French feminine rhymesbecause they end in e weak, or feminine) in which two syllables, anaccented and an unaccented one, correspond at the end of each line.
FLAGELLUM: A young, flexible shoot of a plant; esp., the long trailingbranch of a vine, or a slender branch in certain mosses.
FIDDLE-FADDLE: A trifle; trifling talk; nonsense. [Colloq.] Spectator.
FATUITY: Weakness or imbecility of mind; stupidity.Those many forms of popular fatuity. I Taylor.
FARCE: Stuffing, or mixture of viands, like that used on dressing afowl; forcemeat.
FALSIFIER: One who falsifies, or gives to a thing a deceptive appearance;a liar.
FLIER: A fly. See Fly, n., 9, and 13 (b).
FATALIST: One who maintains that all things happen by inevitablenecessity.
FORSYTHIA: A shrub of the Olive family, with yellow blossoms.
FABULIST: One who invents or writes fables.
FUNCTIONARY: One charged with the performance of a function or office; as, apublic functionary; secular functionaries.
FRAPPING: A lashing binding a thing tightly or binding things together.
FEN-SUCKED: Sucked out of marches. "Fen-sucked fogs." Shak.
FOREMOST: First in time or place; most advanced; chief in rank ordignity; as, the foremost troops of an army.THat struck the foremost man of all this world. Shak.
FRUIT: The pulpy, edible seed vessels of certain plants, especiallythose grown on branches above ground, as apples, oranges, grapes,melons, berries, etc. See 3.
FERDING: A measure of land mentioned in Domesday Book. It is supposed tohave consisted of a few acres only. [Obs.]
FIDES: Faith personified as a goddess; the goddess of faith.
FRANKLIN: An English freeholder, or substantial householder. [Obs.]Chaucer.The franklin, a small landholder of those days. Sir J. Stephen.
FELLON: Variant of Felon. [Obs.]Those two were foes the fellonest on ground. Spenser.
FARCICAL: Pertaining to farce; appropriated to farce; ludicrous;unnatural; unreal.They deny the characters to be farcical, because they are Gay.-- Far"ci*cal*ly, adv. -Far"ci*cal*ness, n.
FRANKLY: In a frank manner; freely.Very frankly he confessed his treasons. Shak.
FORNICATE: To commit fornication; to have unlawful sexual intercourse.
FOREREMEMBERED: Called to mind previously. Bp. Montagu.
FEAT-BODIED: Having a feat or trim body. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
FROGGED: Provided or ornamented with frogs; as, a frogged coat. SeeFrog, n., 4. Ld. Lytton.
FIBRILLAR: Of or pertaining to fibrils or fibers; as, fibrillartwitchings.
FIVES: A kind of play with a ball against a wall, resembling tennis; -- so named because three fives, or fifteen, are counted to the game.Smart. Fives court, a place for playing fives.
FRAGMENTARINESS: The quality or property of being in fragnebts, or brokenpieces, incompleteness; want of continuity. G. Eliot.
FUTURITION: The state of being future; futurity. [R.]Nothing . . . can have this imagined futurition, but as it isdecreed. Coleridge.
FORM: A suffix used to denote in the form or shape of, resembling,etc.; as, valiform; oviform.
FARDING-BAG: The upper stomach of a cow, or other ruminant animal; therumen.
FAIRYLIKE: Resembling a fairy, or what is made or done be fairies; as,fairylike music.
FRESH: To refresh; to freshen. [Obs.] Rom. of R.
FORAMINIFERA: An extensive order of rhizopods which generally have achambered calcareous shell formed by several united zooids. Many ofthem have perforated walls, whence the name. Some species are coveredwith sand. See Rhizophoda.
FERMENTABLE: Capable of fermentation; as, cider and other vegetable liquorsare fermentable.
FORMULARIZE: To reduce to a forula; to formulate.
FLY: That part of a compass on which the points are marked; thecompass card. Totten.
FLECHE: A simple fieldwork, consisting of two faces forming a salientangle pointing outward and open at the gorge.
FOGY: A dull old fellow; a person behind the times, over-conservative, or slow; -- usually preceded by old. [Written alsofogie and fogey.] [Colloq.]Notorious old bore; regular old fogy. Thackeray.
FUSCIN: A brown, nitrogenous pigment contained in the retinalepithelium; a variety of melanin.
FLOWINGNESS: Flowing tendency or quality; fluency. [R.] W. Nichols.
FOREGROUND: On a painting, and sometimes in a bas-relief, mosaic picture,or the like, that part of the scene represented, which is nearest tothe spectator, and therefore occupies the lowest part of the work ofart itself. Cf. Distance, n., 6.
FORMATIVE: Serving to form; derivative; not radical; as, a terminationmerely formative.
FIORITURE: Little flowers of ornament introduced into a melody by a singeror player.
FUGACIOUS: Fleeting; lasting but a short time; -- applied particularly toorgans or parts which are short-lived as compared with the life ofthe individual.
FUNEBRIAL: Pertaining to a funeral or funerals; funeral; funereal. [Obs.][Written also funebral.] Sir T. Browne.
FUSELAGE: An elongated body or frame of an aëroplane or flying machine;sometimes, erroneously, any kind of frame or body. Many aëroplaneshave no fuselage, properly so called.
FRINGILLINE: Pertaining to the family Fringillidæ; characteristic offinches; sparrowlike.
FIBRIFORM: Having the form of a fiber or fibers; resembling a fiber.
FERFORTH: Far forth. [Obs.] As ferforth as, as far as.-- So ferforth, to such a degree.
FELLER: One who, or that which, fells, knocks or cuts down; a machinefor felling trees.
FLATFISH: Any fish of the family Pleuronectidæ; esp., the winter flounder(Pleuronectes Americanus). The flatfishes have the body flattened,swim on the side, and have eyes on one side, as the flounder, turbot,and halibut. See Flounder.
FAVEOLATE: Honeycomb; having cavities or cells, somewhat resembling thoseof a honeycomb; alveolate; favose.
FORESTRY: The art of forming or of cultivating forests; the management ofgrowing timber.
FORTALICE: A small outwork of a fortification; a fortilage; -- called alsofortelace.
FOREIGNNESS: The quality of being foreign; remoteness; want of relation orappropriateness.Let not the foreignness of the subject hinder you from endeavoring toset me right. Locke.A foreignness of complexion. G. Eliot.
FABELLA: One of the small sesamoid bones situated behind the condyles ofthe femur, in some mammals.
FLOCCULENT: Applied to the down of newly hatched or unfledged birds.
FLASHILY: In a flashy manner; with empty show.
FIZZ: To make a hissing sound, as a burning fuse.
FLAMMATION: The act of setting in a flame or blaze. [Obs.] Sir. T. Browne.
FERROCYANATE: A salt of ferrocyanic acid; a ferrocyanide.
FINLET: A little fin; one of the parts of a divided fin.
FACTUM: A man's own act and deed; particularly:(a) (Civil Law) Anything stated and made certain.(b) (Testamentary Law) The due execution of a will, includingeverything necessary to its validity.
FERTILITY: The state or quality of being fertile or fruitful;fruitfulness; productiveness; fecundity; richness; abundance ofresources; fertile invention; quickness; readiness; as, the fertilityof soil, or of imagination. "fertility of resource." E. Everett.And all her husbandry doth lie on heaps Corrupting in its ownfertility. Shak.Thy very weeds are beautiful; thy waste More rich than other climes'fertility. Byron.
FRANKALMOIGNE: A tenure by which a religious corporation holds lands given tothem and their successors forever, usually on condition of prayingfor the soul of the donor and his heirs; -- called also tenure byfree alms. Burrill.
FAINTISH: Slightly faint; somewhat faint.-- Faint"ish*ness, n.
FENESTRATE: Having transparent spots, as the wings of certain butterflies.
FREYA: The daughter of Njörd, aud goddess of love and beauty; theScandinavian Venus; -- in Teutonic myths confounded with Frigga, butin Scandinavian, distinct. [Written also Frea, Fraying, and Ereyja.]
FATTENER: One who, or that which, fattens; that which gives fatness orfertility.
FEMININENESS: The quality of being feminine; womanliness; womanishness.
FLABELLIFORM: Having the form of a fan; fan-shaped; flabellate.
FONDE: To endeavor; to strive; to try. [Obs.] Chaucer.
FALLIBLE: Liable to fail, mistake, or err; liable to deceive or to bedeceived; as, all men are fallible; our opinions and hopes arefallible.
FINE: To impose a pecuniary penalty upon for an offense or breach oflaw; to set a fine on by judgment of a court; to punish by fine; tomulct; as, the trespassers were fined ten dollars.
FORTUNE: To fall out; to happen.It fortuned the same night that a Christian, serving a Turk in thecamp, secretely gave the watchmen warning. Knolles.
FROLICSOME: Full of gayety and mirth; given to pranks; sportive.Old England, who takes a frolicsome brain fever once every two orthree years, for the benefit of her doctors. Sir W. Scott.-- Frol"ic*some*ly, adv.-- Frol"ic*some*ness, n.
FINANCIAL: Pertaining to finance. "Our financial and commercial system."Macaulay.
FRAGRANT: [fragrans. -antis, p.pr. of fragrare to emit a smell offragrance: cf. OF. fragrant. Affecting the olfactory nervesagreeably; sweet of smell; odorous; having or emitting an agreeableperfume.Fragrant the fertile earth After soft showers. Milton.
FORETOKEN: Prognostic; previous omen. Sir P. Sidney.
FOLKETHING: The lower house of the Danish Rigsdag, or Parliament. SeeLegislature, below.
FAUX PAS: A false step; a mistake or wrong measure.
FIREBACK: One of several species of pheasants of the genus Euplocamus,having the lower back a bright, fiery red. They inhabit Southern Asiaand the East Indies.
FANON: A term applied to various articles, as: (a) A peculiar stripedscarf worn by the pope at mass, and by eastern bishops. (b) Amaniple. [Written also fannel, phanon, etc.]
FIBROCARTILAGE: A kind of cartilage with a fibrous matrix and approachingfibrous connective tissue in structure.-- Fi`bro*car`ti*lag"i*nous, a.
FRAKEN: A freckle. [Obs.]A few fraknes in his face. Chaucer.
FRANCOLITE: A variety of apatite from Wheal Franco in Devonshire.
FORDWINE: To dwindle away; to disappear. [Obs.] Rom of R.
FUND: The stock of a national debt; public securities; evidences(stocks or bonds) of money lent to government, for which interest ispaid at prescribed intervals; -- called also public funds.
FOUNDATION: The lowest and supporting part or member of a wall, includingthe base course (see Base course (a), under Base, n.) and footingcourses; in a frame house, the whole substructure of masonry.
FLINDERS: Small pieces or splinters; fragments.The tough ash spear, so stout and true, Into a thousand flindersflew. Sir W. Scott.
FAIN: With joy; gladly; -- with wold.He would fain have filled his belly with the husks that the swine dideat. Luke xv. 16.Fain Would I woo her, yet I dare not. Shak.
FOROLD: Very old. [Obs.]A bear's skin, coal-black, forold. Chaucer.
FILL: One of the thills or shafts of a carriage. Mortimer. Fillhorse, a thill horse. Shak.
FRAISE: A large and thick pancake, with slices of bacon in it. [Obs.]Johnson.
FORERECITED: Named or recited before. "The forerecited practices." Shak.
FINEER: To run in dept by getting goods made up in a way unsuitable forthe use of others, and then threatening not to take them except oncredit. [R.] Goldsmith.
FUSSY: Making a fuss; disposed to make an unnecessary ado abouttrifles; overnice; fidgety.Not at all fussy about his personal appearance. R. G. White.
FIBROVASCULAR: Containing woody fiber and ducts, as the stems of all floweringplants and ferns; -- opposed to cellular.
FIVEFOLD: In fives; consisting of five in one; five repeated; quintuple.
FOOTS: The settlings of oil, molasses, etc., at the bottom of a barrelor hogshead. Simmonds.
FILATORY: A machine for forming threads. [Obs.] W. Tooke.
FACETE: Facetious; witty; humorous. [Archaic] "A facete discourse."Jer. Taylor."How to interpose" with a small, smart remark, sentiment facete, orunctuous anecdote. Prof. Wilson.-- Fa*cete"ly, adv.-- Fa*cete"ness, n.
FRONS: The forehead; the part of the cranium between the orbits andthe vertex.
FURNITURE: A mixed or compound stop in an organ; -- sometimes calledmixture.
FOREMENTIONED: Mentioned before; already cited; aforementioned. Addison.
FENNY: Pertaining to, or inhabiting, a fen; abounding in fens; swampy;boggy. "Fenny snake." Shak.
FORFEND: To prohibit; to forbid; to avert. [Archaic]Which peril heaven forefend! Shak.
FOREGO: To go before; to precede; -- used especially in the present andpast participles.Pleasing remembrance of a thought foregone. Wordsworth.For which the very mother's face forewent The mother's specialpatience. Mrs. Browning.Foregone conclusion, one which has preceded argument or examination;one predetermined.
FOREKNOWABLE: That may be foreknown. Dr. H. More.
FLAP: Anything broad and limber that hangs loose, or that is attachedby one side or end and is easily moved; as, the flap of a garment.A cartilaginous flap upon the opening of the larynx. Sir T. Browne.
FUMBLINGLY: In the manner of one who fumbles.
FINISHING: The act or process of completing or perfecting; the final workupon or ornamentation of a thing.
FORTIFIER: One who, or that which, fortifies, strengthens, supports, orupholds.
FRUCTIFY: To bear fruit. "Causeth the earth to fructify." Beveridge.
FLIPPANCY: The state or quality of being flippant.This flippancy of language. Bp. Hurd.
FOOTPATH: A narrow path or way for pedestrains only; a footway.
FINNED: Having a fin, or fins, or anything resembling a fin. Mortimer.
FLEXOR: A muscle which bends or flexes any part; as, the flexors of thearm or the hand; -- opposed to extensor.
FRITH: A narrow arm of the sea; an estuary; the opening of a riverinto the sea; as, the Frith of Forth.
FLAMBEAU: A flaming torch, esp. one made by combining together a numberof thick wicks invested with a quick-burning substance (anciently,perhaps, wax; in modern times, pitch or the like); hence, any torch.
FRATERNATE: To fraternize; to hold fellowship. Jefferson.
FORWANDER: To wander away; to go astray; to wander far and to weariness.[Obs.]
FORLET: To give up; to leave; to abandon. [Obs.] "To forlet sin."Chaucer.
FESTIVOUS: Pertaining to a feast; festive. [R.] Sir W. Scott.
FORWARDNESS: The quality of being forward; cheerful readiness; promtness;as, the forwardness of Christians in propagating the gospel.
FLUIDITY: The quality of being fluid or capable of flowing; a liquid,aëriform. or gaseous state; -- opposed to solidity.It was this want of organization, this looseness and fluidity of thenew movement, that made it penetrate through every class of society.J. R. Green.
FORCE: To stuff; to lard; to farce. [R.]Wit larded with malice, and malice forced with wit. Shak.
FLORIFORM: Having the form of a flower; flower-shaped.
FREQUENTER: One who frequents; one who often visits, or resorts tocustomarily.
FAROESE: An inhabitant, or, collectively, inhabitants, of the Faroeislands.
FURTHERER: One who furthers. or helps to advance; a promoter. Shak.
FERRARESE: Pertaining to Ferrara, in Italy.-- n., sing. & pl.
FUMITORY: The common uame of several species of the genus Fumaria, annualherbs of the Old World, with finely dissected leaves and smallflowers in dense racemes or spikes. F. officinalis is a commonspecies, and was formerly used as an antiscorbutic. Climbing fumitory(Bot.), the Alleghany vine (Adlumia cirrhosa); a biennial climbingplant with elegant feathery leaves and large clusters of pretty whiteor pinkish flowers looking like grains of rice.
FUZE: A tube, filled with combustible matter, for exploding a shell,etc. See Fuse, n. Chemical fuze, a fuze in which substances separateduntil required for action are then brought into contact, and unitingchemically, produce explosion.-- Concussion fuze, a fuze ignited by the striking of theprojectile.-- Electric fuze, a fuze which is ignited by heat or a sparkproduced by an electric current.-- Friction fuze, a fuze which is ignited by the heat evolved byfriction.-- Percussion fuze, a fuze in which the ignition is produced by ablow on some fulminating compound.-- Time fuze, a fuze adapted, either by its length or by thecharacter of its composition, to burn a certain time before producingan explosion.
FILBERT: The fruit of the Corylus Avellana or hazel. It is an oval nut,containing a kernel that has a mild, farinaceous, oily taste,agreeable to the palate.
FOOTPAD: A highwayman or robber on foot.
FUNGIAN: Of or pertaining to the Fungidæ, a family of stony corals.-- n.
FEBRIFUGE: A medicine serving to mitigate or remove fever.-- a.
FLIRT-GILL: A woman of light behavior; a gill-flirt. [Obs.] Shak.You heard him take me up like a flirt-gill. Beau. & Fl.
FETATION: The formation of a fetus in the womb; pregnancy.
FLEMING: A native or inhabitant of Flanders.
FIENDISH: Like a fiend; diabolically wicked or cruel; infernal;malignant; devilish; hellish.-- Fiend"ish*ly, adv.-- Fiend"ish*ness, n.
FILANDERS: A disease in hawks, characterized by the presence of smallthreadlike worms, also of filaments of coagulated blood, from therupture of a vein; -- called also backworm. Sir T. Browne.
FERRARY: The art of working in iron. [Obs.] Chapman.
FLESHMONGER: One who deals in flesh; hence, a pimp; a procurer; a pander.[R.] Shak.
FINGRIGO: A prickly, climbing shrub of the genus Pisonia. The fruit is akind of berry.
FISHFUL: Abounding with fish. [R.] "My fishful pond." R. Carew.
FROWEY: Working smoothly, or without splitting; -- said of timber.
FELLOWLESS: Without fellow or equal; peerless.Whose well-built walls are rare and fellowless. Chapman.
FORSPENT: Wasted in strength; tired; exhausted. [Archaic]A gentleman almost forspent with speed. Shak.
FALANAKA: A viverrine mammal of Madagascar (Eupleres Goudotii), allied tothe civet; -- called also Falanouc.
FORMATION: The arrangement of a body of troops, as in a square, column,etc. Farrow.
FRAMING: A framework, or a sy Framing chisel (Carp.), a heavy chiselwith a socket shank for making mortises.
FAIRWAY: The navigable part of a river, bay, etc., through which vesselsenter or depart; the part of a harbor or channel ehich is kept openand unobstructed for the passage of vessels. Totten. the rough.
FOOT CANDLE: The amount of illumination produced by a standard candle at adistance of one foot.
FIXURE: Fixed position; stable condition; firmness. [Obs.] Shak.
FRAGOR: A strong or sweet scent. [Obs. & Illegitimate.] Sir T. Herbert.
FUNCTIONAL: Pertaining to the function of an organ or part, or to thefunctions in general. Functional disease (Med.), a disease of whichthe symptoms cannot be referred to any appreciable lesion or changeof structure; the derangement of an organ arising from a cause, oftenunknown, external to itself opposed to organic disease, in which theorgan itself is affected.
FOCALIZATION: The act of focalizing or bringing to a focus, or the state ofbeing focalized.
FEMME: A woman. See Feme, n. Femme de chambre. Etym: [F.] A lady'smaid; a chambermaid.
FRATRICIDAL: Of or pertaining to fratricide; of the nature of fratricide.
FIREDOG: A support for wood in a fireplace; an andiron.
FELO-DE-SE: One who deliberately puts an end to his own existence, or loseshis life while engaged in the commission of an unlawful or maliciousact; a suicide. Burrill.
FUTURABLE: Capable of being future; possible to occur. [R.]Not only to things future, but futurable. Fuller.
FAULTFUL: Full of faults or sins. Shak.
FOLIAGED: Furnished with foliage; leaved; as, the variously foliagedmulberry.
FREE-MILLING: Yielding free gold or silver; -- said of certain ores which canbe reduced by crushing and amalgamation, without roasting or otherchemical treatment. Raymond.
FULL-ORBED: Having the orb or disk complete or fully illuminated; like thefull moon.
FOREBY: Near; hard by; along; past. See Forby. Spenser.
FEE-FAW-FUM: A nonsensical exclamation attributed to giants and ogres;hence, any expression calculated to impose upon the timid andignorant. "Impudent fee-faw-fums." J. H. Newman.
FLAGELLATA: An order of Infusoria, having one or two long, whiplike cilia,at the anterior end. It includes monads. See Infusoria, and Monad.
FACOUND: Speech; eloquence. [Obs.]Her facound eke full womanly and plain. Chaucer.
FIORIN: A species of creeping bent grass (Agrostis alba); -- calledalso fiorin grass.
FOLIACEOUS: Belonging to, or having the texture or nature of, a leaf;having leaves intermixed with flowers; as, a foliaceous spike.
FARD: Paint used on the face. [Obs.] "Painted with French fard." J.Whitaker.
FILICIDE: The act of murdering a son or a daughter; also, parent whocommits such a murder.
FUMIFY: To subject to the action of smoke. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
FRESHMAN: novice; one in the rudiments of knowledge; especially, astudent during his fist year in a college or university.He drank his glass and cracked his joke, And freshmen wondered as hespoke. Goldsmith.Freshman class, the lowest of the four classes in an Americancollege. [ U. S.]
FLEXUOUS: Having alternate curvatures in opposite directions; bent in azigzag manner.
FEU DE JOIE: A fire kindled in a public place in token of joy; a bonfire; afiring of guns in token of joy.
FRACTURAL: Pertaining to, or consequent on, a fracture. [R.]
FAST: That which fastens or holds; especially, (Naut.) a mooringrope, hawser, or chain; -- called, according to its position, a bow,head, quarter, breast, or stern fast; also, a post on a pier aroundwhich hawsers are passed in mooring.
FLAUTO: A flute. Flaute piccolo ( Etym: [It., little flute], an octaveflute.-- Flauto traverso ( Etym: [It., transverse flute], the Germanflute, held laterally, instead of being played, like the old flûte abec, with a mouth piece at the end.
FORENAME: A name that precedes the family name or surname; a first name.Selden.
FORTHRIGHTNESS: Straightforwardness; explicitness; directness. [Archaic]Dante's concise forthrightness of phrase. Hawthorne.
FREE-LOVE: The doctrine or practice of consorting with the opposite sex,at pleasure, without marriage.
FAMOSITY: The state or quality of being famous. [Obs.] Johnson.
FABRICATOR: One who fabricates; one who constructs or makes.The fabricator of the works of Ossian. Mason.
FOSSULATE: Having, or surrounded by, long, narrow depressions or furrows.
FERRET: An animal of the Weasel family (Mustela or Putorius furo),about fourteen inches in length, of a pale yellow or white color,with red eyes. It is a native of Africa, but has been domesticated inEurope. Ferrets are used to drive rabbits and rats out of theirholes.
FORFICULA: A genus of insects including the earwigs. See Earwig, 1.
FLORIN: A silver coin of Florence, first struck in the twelfth century,and noted for its beauty. The name is given to different coins indifferent countries. The florin of England, first minted in 1849, isworth two shillings, or about 48 cents; the florin of theNetherlands, about 40 cents; of Austria, about 36 cents.
FIDUCIARY: One who depends for salvation on faith, without works; anAntinomian. Hammond.
FRAXIN: A colorless crystalline substance, regarded as a glucoside, andfound in the bark of the ash (Fraxinus) and along with esculin in thebark of the horse-chestnut. It shows a delicate fluorescence inalkaline solutions; -- called also paviin.
FAVILLOUS: Of or pertaining to ashes. [Obs.]Light and favollous particles. Sir T. Browne.
FLEAKING: A light covering of reeds, over which the main covering islaid, in thatching houses. [Prov. Eng.] Wright.
FLAME: To kindle; to inflame; to excite.And flamed with zeal of vengeance inwardly. Spenser.
FLOG: To beat or strike with a rod or whip; to whip; to lash; tochastise with repeated blows.
FLATTERY: The act or practice of flattering; the act of pleasing byartiful commendation or compliments; adulation; false, insincere, orexcessive praise.Just praise is only a debt, but flattery is a present. Rambler.Flattery corrupts both the receiver and the giver. Burke.
FIDEJUSSION: The act or state of being bound as surety for another;suretyship.
FUTURISM: A movement or phase of post-impressionism (which see, below).
FLAWN: A sort of flat custard or pie. [Obs.] Tusser.
FAUCAL: Pertaining to the fauces, or opening of the throat; faucial;esp., (Phon.) produced in the fauces, as certain deep guttural soundsfound in the Semitic and some other languages.Ayin is the most difficult of the faucals. I. Taylor (The Alphabet).
FOOTBREADTH: The breadth of a foot; -- used as a measure. Longfellow.Not so much as a footbreadth. Deut. ii. 5.
FOVILLA: One of the fine granules contained in the protoplasm of apollen grain.
FABRIC: To frame; to built; to construct. [Obs.] "Fabric theirmansions." J. Philips.
FLUORESCIN: A colorless, amorphous substance which is produced by thereduction of fluoresceïn, and from which the latter may be formed byoxidation.
FEATURELESS: Having no distinct or distinctive features.
FINNIC: Of or pertaining to the Finns.
FRUITERER: One who deals in fruit; a seller of fruits.
FALDFEE: A fee or rent paid by a tenant for the privilege of faldage onhis own ground. Blount.
FETTERED: Seeming as if fettered, as the feet pf certain animals whichbend backward, and appear unfit for walking.
FERREOUS: Partaking of, made of, or pertaining to, iron; like iron.[Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
FIREARM: A gun, pistol, or any weapon from a shot is discharged by theforce of an explosive substance, as gunpowder.
FOISON: Rich harvest; plenty; abundance. [Archaic] Lowell.That from the seedness the bare fallow brings To teeming foison.Shak.
FULLY: In a full manner or degree; completely; entirely; without lackor defect; adequately; satisfactorily; as, to be fully persuaded ofthe truth of a proposition. Fully committed (Law), committed toprison for trial, in distinction from being detained for examination.
FURUNCLE: A superficial, inflammatory tumor, suppurating with a centralcore; a boil.
FAREN: p. p. of Fare, v. i. Chaucer.
FALDISTORY: The throne or seat of a bishop within the chancel. [Obs.]
FULL-MANNED: Completely furnished wiith men, as a ship.
FICHTELITE: A white crystallized mineral resin from the Fichtelgebirge,Bavaria.
FEMINIZATION: The act of feminizing, or the state of being feminized.
FRISKY: Inclined to frisk; frolicsome; gay.He is too frisky for an old man. Jeffrey.
FOOTWORN: Worn by, or weared in, the feet; as, a footworn path; afootworn traveler.
FULL HOUSE: A hand containing three of a kind and a pair, as three kingsand two tens. It ranks above a flush and below four of a kind.
FEAZE: To untwist; to unravel, as the end of a rope. Johnson.
FRUGIVOROUS: Feeding on fruit, as birds and other animals. Pennant.
FIRSTLY: In the first place; before anything else; -- sometimesimproperly used for first.
FORTUNATENESS: The condition or quality of being fortunate; good luck;success; happiness.
FORK-TAILED: Having the outer tail feathers longer than the median ones;swallow-tailed; -- said of many birds. Fork-tailed flycatcher(Zoöl.), a tropical American flycatcher (Milvulus tyrannus).-- Fork-tailed gull (Zoöl.), a gull of the genus Xema, of twospecies, esp. X. Sabinii of the Arctic Ocean.-- Fork-tailed kite (Zoöl.), a graceful American kite (Elanoidesforficatus); -- called also swallow-tailed kite.
FACIAL: Of or pertaining to the face; as, the facial artery, vein, ornerve.-- Fa"cial*ly, adv. Facial angle (Anat.), the angle, in a skull,included between a straight line (ab, in the illustrations), from themost prominent part of the forehead to the front efge of the upperjaw bone, and another (cd) from this point to the center of theexternal auditory opening. See Gnathic index, under Gnathic.
FAILLE: A soft silk, heavier than a foulard and not glossy.
FULL-BOTTOMED: Of great capacity below the water line.
FAN-TAILED: Having an expanded, or fan-shaped, tail; as, the fan-tailedpigeon.
FLAMMEOUS: Pertaining to, consisting of, or resembling, flame. [Obs.] SirT. Browne.
FLOCKMEL: In a flock; in a body. [Obs.]That flockmel on a day they to him went. Chaucer.
FLABBINESS: Quality or state of being flabby.
FLESHPOT: A pot or vessel in which flesh is cooked; hence (pl.),
FUMARIC: Pertaining to, or derived from, fumitory (Fumaria officinalis).Fumaric acid (Chem.), a widely occurring organic acid, exttractedfrom fumitory as a white crystallline substance, C2H2(CO2H)2, andproduced artificially in many ways, as by the distillation of malicacid; boletic acid. It is found also in the lichen, Iceland moss, andhence was also called lichenic acid.
FIREFLAIRE: A European sting ray of the genus Trygon (T. pastinaca); --called also fireflare and fiery flaw.
FIN DE SIECLE: Lit., end of the century; -- mostly used adjectively in Englishto signify: belonging to, or characteristic of, the close of the 19thcentury; modern; "up-to-date;" as, fin-de-siècle ideas.
FLOODING: The filling or covering with water or other fluid; overflow;inundation; the filling anything to excess.
FRUMENTACEOUS: Made of, or resembling, wheat or other grain.
FENCI-BLE: Capable of being defended, or of making or affording defense.[Obs.]No fort so fencible, nor walls so strong. Spenser.
FUNDUS: The bottom or base of any hollow organ; as, the fundus of thebladder; the fundus of the eye.
FACTOR: One who transacts business for another; an agent; a substitute;especially, a mercantile agent who buys and sells goods and transactsbusiness for others in commission; a commission merchant orconsignee. He may be a home factor or a foreign factor. He may buyand sell in his own name, and he is intrusted with the possession andcontrol of the goods; and in these respects he differs from a broker.Story. Wharton.My factor sends me word, a merchant's fled That owes me for a hundredtun of wine. Marlowe.
FOOT POUND: A unit of energy, or work, being equal to the work done inraising one pound avoirdupois against the force of gravity the heightof one foot.
FAIR-LEADER: A block, or ring, serving as a guide for the running rigging orfor any rope.
FLANERIE: Lit., strolling; sauntering; hence, aimless; idleness; as,intellectual flânerie.
FILING: A fragment or particle rubbed off by the act of filing; as,iron filings.
FLATWORM: Any worm belonging to the Plathelminthes; also, sometimesapplied to the planarians.
FIRST-RATE: Of the highest excellence; preëminent in quality, size, orestimation.Our only first-rate body of contemporary poetry is the German. M.Arnold.Hermocrates . . . a man of first-rate ability. Jowett (Thucyd).
FANGLESS: Destitute of fangs or tusks. "A fangless lion." Shak.
FIANTS: The dung of the fox, wolf, boar, or badger.
FURNISHMENT: The act of furnishing, or of supplying furniture; also,furniture. [Obs.] Daniel.
FLIMSY: Weak; feeble; limp; slight; vain; without strength or solidity;of loose and unsubstantial structure; without reason or plausibility;as, a flimsy argument, excuse, objection.Proud of a vast extent of flimsy lines. Pope.All the flimsy furniture of a country miss's brain. Sheridan.
FOURLING: A compound or twin crystal consisting of four individuals.
FOREFOOT: A piece of timber which terminates the keel at the fore end,connecting it with the lower end of the stem.
FLANKER: One who, or that which, flanks, as a skirmisher or a body oftroops sent out upon the flanks of an army toguard a line of march,or a fort projecting so as to command the side of an assailing body.They threw out flankers, and endeavored to dislodge their assailants.W. Irwing.
FLATIRON: An iron with a flat, smooth surface for ironing clothes.
FULL: Complete measure; utmost extent; the highest state or degree.The swan's-down feather, That stands upon the swell at full of tide.Shak.Full of the moon, the time of full moon.
FALERNIAN: Of or pertaining to Mount Falernus, in Italy; as,Falernianwine.
FENNEL: A perennial plant of the genus Fæniculum (F.vulgare), havingvery finely divided leaves. It is cultivated in gardens for theagreeable aromatic flavor of its seeds.Smell of sweetest fennel. Milton.A sprig of fennel was in fact the theological smelling bottle of thetender sex. S. G. Goodrich.Azorean, or Sweet, fennel, (Fæniculum dulce). It is a smaller andstouter plant than the common fennel, and is used as a pot herb.-- Dog's fennel (Anthemis Cotula), a foul-smelling European weed; --called also mayweed.-- Fennel flower (Bot.), an herb (Nigella) of the Buttercup family,having leaves finely divided, like those of the fennel. N.Damascenais common in gardens. N.sativa furnishes the fennel seed, used as acondiment, etc., in India. These seeds are the "fitches" mentioned inIsaiah (xxviii. 25).-- Fennel water (Med.), the distilled water of fennel seed. It isstimulant and carminative.-- Giant fennel (Ferula communis), has stems full of pith, which, itis said, were used to carry fire, first, by Prometheus.-- Hog's fennel, a European plant (Peucedanum officinale) lookingsomething like fennel.
FRONT: Of or relating to the front or forward part; having a positionin front; foremost; as, a front view.
FISTULA: A permanent abnormal opening into the soft parts with aconstant discharge; a deep, narrow, chronic abscess; an abnormalopening between an internal cavity and another cavity or the surface;as, a salivary fistula; an anal fistula; a recto-vaginal fistula.Incomplete fistula (Med.), a fistula open at one end only.
FANGLED: New made; hence, gaudy; showy; vainly decorated. [Obs., exceptwith the prefix new.] See Newfangled. "Our fangled world." Shak.
FEBRIFUGAL: Having the quality of mitigating or curing fever. Boyle.
FIORD: A narrow inlet of the sea, penetrating between high banks orrocks, as on the coasts of Norway and Alaska. [Written also fjord.]
FOR: In the most general sense, indicating that in consideration of,in view of, or with reference to, which anything is done or takesplace.
FLYBLOW: To deposit eggs upon, as a flesh fly does on meat; to cause tobe maggoty; hence, to taint or contaminate, as if with flyblows. Bp.Srillingfleet.
FOREYARD: The lowermost yard on the foremast.
FORTHRIGHT: Straight forward; in a straight direction. [Archaic] Sir P.Sidney.
FOH: An exclamation of abhorrence or contempt; poh; fle. Shak.
FLUFF: Nap or down; flue; soft, downy feathers.
FLUSTERATION: The act of flustering, or the state of being flustered;fluster. [Colloq.]
FRESHMANSHIP: The state of being a freshman.
FOURCHETTE: An instrument used to raise and support the tongue during thecutting of the frænum.
FORAMEN: A small opening, perforation, or orifice; a fenestra. Foramenof Monro (Anat.), the opening from each lateral into the thirdventricle of the brain.-- Foramen of Winslow (Anat.), the opening connecting the sac of theomentum with the general cavity of the peritoneum.
FUNCTIONALIZE: To assign to some function or office. [R.]
FOX: A carnivorous animal of the genus Vulpes, family Canidæ, ofmany species. The European fox (V. vulgaris or V. vulpes), theAmerican red fox (V. fulvus), the American gray fox (V. Virginianus),and the arctic, white, or blue, fox (V. lagopus) are well-knownspecies.
FLAVINE: A yellow, crystalline, organic base, C13H12N2O, obtainedartificially.
FATE: The three goddesses, Clotho, Lachesis, and Atropos, sometimescalled the Destinies, or Parcæwho were supposed to determine thecourse of human life. They are represented, one as holding thedistaff, a second as spinning, and the third as cutting off thethread.
FISSIPAROUS: Reproducing by spontaneous fission. See Fission.-- Fis*sip"a*rous*ly, adv.
FREQUENTATIVE: Serving to express the frequent repetition of an action; as, afrequentative verb.-- n.
FRIZEL: A movable furrowed piece of steel struck by the flint, to throwsparks into the pan, in an early form of flintlock. Knight.
FARCY: A contagious disease of horses, associated with painfululcerating enlargements, esp. upon the head and limbs. It is of thesame nature as glanders, and is often fatal. Called also farcin, andfarcimen.
FRATER: A monk; also, a frater house. [R.] Shipley. Frater house, anapartament in a convent used as an eating room; a refectory; --called also a fratery.
FILIFORM: Having the shape of a thread or filament; as, the filiformpapillæ of the tongue; a filiform style or peduncle. See Illust. ofAntennÆ.
FLUENCY: The quality of being fluent; smoothness; readiness ofutterance; volubility.The art of expressing with fluency and perspicuity. Macaulay.
FRACTIOUS: Apt to break out into a passion; apt to scold; cross; snappish;ugly; unruly; as, a fractious man; a fractious horse.
FORSWEAR: To swear falsely; to commit perjury. Shak.
FLUORESCEIN: A yellowish red, crystalline substance, C20H12O5, produced byheating together phthalic anhydride and resorcin; -- so called, fromthe very brilliant yellowish green fluorescence of its alkalinesolutions. It has acid properties, and its salts of the alkalies areknown to the trade under the name of uranin.
FIDGET: To move uneasily one way and the other; to move irregularly, orby fits and starts. Moore.
FORESHIP: The fore part of a ship. [Obs.]
FIFE: A small shrill pipe, resembling the piccolo flute, used chieflyto accompany the drum in military music. Fife major (Mil.), anoncommissioned officer who superintends the fifers of a regiment.-- Fife rail. (Naut.) (a) A rail about the mast, at the deck, tohold belaying pins, etc. (b) A railing around the break of a poopdeck.
FABRILE: Pertaining to a workman, or to work in stone, metal, wood etc.;as, fabrile skill.
FURBISHER: One who furbishes; esp., a sword cutler, who finishes swordblades and similar weapons.
FIBROCHONDROSTEAL: Partly fibrous, partly cartilaginous, and partly osseous. St.George Mivart.
FETTLING: A mixture of ore, cinders, etc., used to line the hearth of apuddling furnace. [Eng.] [It is commonly called fix in the UnitedStates.]
FASCIOLA: A band of gray matter bordering the fimbria in the brain; thedentate convolution. Wilder.
FUMIFUGIST: One who, or that which, drives away smoke or fumes.
FINSEN LIGHT: Highly actinic light, derived from sunlight or from some formof electric lamp, used in the treatment of lupus and other cutaneousaffections.
FOGGINESS: The state of being foggy. Johnson.
FEATHERINESS: The state or condition of being feathery.
FURRIER: A dealer in furs; one who makes or sells fur goods.
FIMBRIATE: Having the edge or extremity bordered by filiform processesthicker than hairs; fringed; as, the fimbriate petals of the pink;the fimbriate end of the Fallopian tube.
FITTEDNESS: The state or quality of being fitted; adaptation. [Obs.] Dr. H.More.
FORFETE: To incur a penalty; to transgress. [Obs.]And all this suffered our Lord Jesus Christ that never forfeted.Chaucer.
FUDDLE: To make foolish by drink; to cause to become intoxicated.[Colloq.]I am too fuddled to take care to observe your orders. Steele.
FORCING: The art of raising plants, flowers, and fruits at an earlierseason than the natural one, as in a hitbed or by the use ofartificial heat. Forcing bed or pit, a plant bed having an underlayer of fermenting manure, the fermentation yielding bottom heat forforcing plants; a hotbed.-- Forcing engine, a fire engine.-- Forcing fit (Mech.), a tight fit, as of one part into a hole inanother part, which makes it necessary to use considerable force inputting the two parts together.-- Forcing house, a greenhouse for the forcing of plants, fruittrees, etc.-- Forcing machine, a powerful press for putting together orseparating two parts that are fitted tightly one into another, as forforcing a crank on a shaft, or for drawing off a car wheel from theaxle.-- Forcing pump. See Force pump (b).
FALCONINE: Like a falcon or hawk; belonging to the Falconid�
FRANKNESS: The quality of being frank; candor; openess; ingenuousness;fairness; liberality.
FLUORITE: Calcium fluoride, a mineral of many different colors, white,yellow, purple, green, red, etc., often very beautiful, crystallizingcommonly in cubes with perfect octahedral cleavage; also massive. Itis used as a flux. Some varieties are used for ornamental vessels.Also called fluor spar, or simply fluor.
FEAT: To form; to fashion. [Obs.]To the more mature, A glass that feated them. Shak.
FALLFISH: A fresh-water fish of the United States (Semotilus bullaris); -- called also silver chub, and Shiner. The name is also applied toother allied species.
FIREFISH: A singular marine fish of the genus Pterois, family Scorpænidæ,of several species, inhabiting the Indo-Pacific region. They areusually red, and have very large spinose pectoral and dorsal fins.
FULGOR: Dazzling brightness; splendor. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
FLESHLING: A person devoted to fleshly things. [Obs.] Spenser.
FISK: To run about; to frisk; to whisk. [Obs.]He fisks abroad, and stirreth up erroneous opinions. Latimer.
FOXLIKE: Resembling a fox in his characteristic qualities; cunning;artful; foxy.
FLINT: A massive, somewhat impure variety of quartz, in color usuallyof a gray to brown or nearly black, breaking with a conchoidalfracture and sharp edge. It is very hard, and strikes fire withsteel.
FIRST: Before any other person or thing in time, space, rank, etc.; --much used in composition with adjectives and participles.Adam was first formed, then Eve. 1 Tim. ii. 13.At first, At the first, at the beginning or origin.-- First or last, at one time or another; at the beginning or end.And all are fools and lovers first or last. Dryden.
FEUDALISM: The feudal system; a system by which the holding of estates inland is made dependent upon an obligation to render military serviceto the kind or feudal superior; feudal principles and usages.
FORGO: To pass by; to leave. See 1st Forego.For sith [since] I shall forgoon my liberty At your request. Chaucer.And four [days] since Florimell the court forwent. Spenser.
FORE-TOPMAST: The mast erected at the head of the foremast, and at the headof which stands the fore-topgallant mast. See Ship.
FIB: A falsehood; a lie; -- used euphemistically.They are very serious; they don't tell fibs. H. James.
FURIOSO: With great force or vigor; vehemently.
FERRY: To carry or transport over a river, strait, or other narrowwater, in a boat.
FIDDLER: A burrowing crab of the genus Gelasimus, of many species. Themale has one claw very much enlarged, and often holds it in aposition similar to that in which a musician holds a fiddle, hencethe name; -- called also calling crab, soldier crab, and fightingcrab.
FRANC-TIREUR: A French partisan soldier, or one belonging to a corps ofdetached light troops engaged in forays, skirmishes, scouting, etc.
FLORIFICATION: The act, process, or time of flowering; florescence.
FRIM: Flourishing; thriving; fresh; in good case; vigorous. [Obs.]"Frim pastures." Drayton.
FOAM: The white substance, consisting of an aggregation of bubbles,which is formed on the surface of liquids,or in the mouth of ananimal, by violent agitation or fermentation; froth; spume; scum; as,the foam of the sea. Foam cock, in steam boilers, a cock at the waterlevel, to blow off impurities.
FISSIPEDIA: A division of the Carnivora, including the dogs, cats, andbears, in which the feet are not webbed; -- opposed to Pinnipedia.
FLITTING: Contention; strife; scolding; specif., a kind of metricalcontest between two persons, popular in Scotland in the 16th century.[Obs. or Scot.]
FAUVETTE: A small singing bird, as the nightingale and warblers.
FERRICYANIC: Pertaining to, or derived from, a ferricyanide. Ferricyanicacid (Chem.), a brown crystalline substance, H6(CN)12Fe2, obtainedfrom potassium ferricyanide, and regarded as the type of theferricyanides; -- called also hydro-ferricyanic acid, hydrogenferricyanide, etc.
FEASTFUL: Festive; festal; joyful; sumptuous; luxurious. "Feastful days."Milton.-- Feast"ful*ly, adv.
FLACON: A small glass bottle; as, a flacon for perfume. "Two glassflacons for the ink." Longfellow.
FORTY-NINER: One of those who went to California in the rush for gold in1849; an argonaut. [Colloq., U. S.]
FLATHEAD: Characterized by flatness of head, especially that produced byartificial means, as a certain tribe of American Indians.
FEEBLE: To make feble; to enfeeble. [Obs.]Shall that victorious hand be feebled here Shak.
FOLIO: The page number. The even folios are on the left-hand pages andthe odd folios on the right-hand.
FRO: From; away; back or backward; -- now used only in oppositiontothe word to, in the phrase to and fro, that is, to and from. See Toand fro under To. Millon.
FAINEANT DEITY: A deity recognized as real but conceived as not acting in humanaffairs, hence not worshiped.
FANTAST: One whose manners or ideas are fantastic. [R.] Coleridge.
FLASHING: The creation of an artifical flood by the sudden letting in ofa body of water; -- called also flushing.
FLORAL: Containing, or belonging to, a flower; as, a floral bud; afloral leaf; floral characters. Martyn. Floral envelope (Bot.), thecalyx and corolla, one or the other of which (mostly the corolla) maybe wanting.
FLAVOROUS: Imparting flavor; pleasant to the taste or smell; sapid.Dryden.
FORELOCK: A cotter or split pin, as in a slot in a bolt, to preventretraction; a linchpin; a pin fastening the cap-square of a gun.Forelock bolt, a bolt retained by a key, gib, or cotter passingthrough a slot.-- Forelock hook (Rope Making), a winch or whirl by which a bunch ofthree yarns is twisted into a standard. Knight.-- To take time, or occasion, by the forelock, to make prompt use ofanything; not to let slip an opportunity.Time is painted with a lock before and bald behind, signifyingthereby that we must take time by the forelock; for when it is oncepast, there is no recalling it. Swift.On occasion's forelock watchful wait. Milton.
FORESIGHT: Any sight or reading of the leveling staff, except thebacksight; any sight or bearing taken by a compass or theodolite in aforward direction.
FLAT FOOT: A foot in which the arch of the instep is flattened so that theentire sole of the foot rests upon the ground; also, the deformity,usually congential, exhibited by such a foot; splayfoot.
FORECAST: To contrive or plan beforehand.If it happen as I did forecast. Milton.
FLORICOMOUS: Having the head adorned with flowers. [R.]
FLANNEL: A soft, nappy, woolen cloth, of loose texture. Shak. Adam'sflannel. (Bot.) See under Adam.-- Canton flannel, Cotton flannel. See Cotton flannel, under Cotton.
FRECKLY: Full of or marked with freckles; sprinkled with spots;freckled.
FORESAY: To foretell. [Obs.]Her danger nigh that sudden change foresaid. Fairfax.
FARMSTEAD: A farm with the building upon it; a homestead on a farm.Tennyson.With its pleasant groves and farmsteads. Carlyle.
FACULTATIVE: Having the power to live under different conditions; as, afacultative parasite, a plant which is normally saprophytic, butwhich may exist wholly or in part as a parasite; -- opposed toobligate.
FUMBLE: To handle or manage awkwardly; to crowd or tumble together.Shak.
FENCE MONTH: the month in which female deer are fawning, when hunting isprohibited. Bullokar.-- Fence roof, a covering for defense. "They fitted their shieldsclose to one another in manner of a fence roof." Holland. Fence time,the breeding time of fish or game, when they should not be killed.-- Rail fence, a fence made of rails, sometimes supported by posts.-- Ring fence, a fence which encircles a large area, or a wholeestate, within one inclosure.-- Worm fence, a zigzag fence composed of rails crossing one anotherat their ends; -- called also snake fence, or Virginia rail fence.-- To be on the fence, to be undecided or uncommitted in respect totwo opposing parties or policies. [Colloq.]
FINITELY: In a finite manner or degree.
FLEETINGS: A mixture of buttermilk and boiling whey; curds. [prov. Eng.]Wright.
FROSTBOW: A white arc or circle in the sky attending frosty weather andformed by reflection of sunlight from ice crystals floating in theair; the parhelic circle whose center is at the zenith.
FALCON: An ancient form of cannon. Chanting falcon. (Zoöl.) See underChanting.
FLUOSILICATE: A double fluoride of silicon and some other (usually basic)element or radical, regarded as a salt of fluosilicic acid; -- calledalso silicofluoride.
FITLY: In a fit manner; suitably; properly; conveniently; as, a maximfitly applied.
FOLIOLE: One of the distinct parts of a compound leaf; a leaflet.
FIDDLE: A stringed instrument of music played with a bow; a violin; akit.
