FLOSS: The slender styles of the pistillate flowers of maize; alsocalled silk.
FOSSORIOUS: Adapted for digging; -- said of the legs of certain insects.
FORTH: Forth from; out of. [Archaic]Some forth their cabins peep. Donne.
FUNGIN: A name formerly given to cellulose found in certain fungi andmushrooms.
FESTAL: Of or pertaining to a holiday or a feast; joyous; festive.You bless with choicer wine the festal day. Francis.
FADING: Losing freshness, color, brightness, or vigor.-- n.
FRICATIVE: Produced by the friction or rustling of the breath, intonatedor unintonated, through a narrow opening between two of the mouthorgans; uttered through a close approach, but not with a completeclosure, of the organs of articulation, and hence capable of beingcontinued or prolonged; -- said of certain consonantal sounds, as f,v, s, z, etc.-- n.
FIBROSPONGIAE: An order of sponges having a fibrous skeleton, including thecommercial sponges.
FRUCTUOUS: Fruitful; productive; profitable. [Obs.]Nothing fructuous or profitable. Chaucer.-- Fruc"tu*ous*ly, adv.-- Fruc"tu*ous*ness, n. [Obs.]
FIN: To carve or cut up, as a chub.
FEMALIST: A gallant. [Obs.]Courting her smoothly like a femalist. Marston.
FOREDOOM: To doom beforehand; to predestinate.Thou art foredomed to view the Stygian state. Dryden.
FERNTICLE: A freckle on the skin, resembling the seed of fern. [Prov.Eng.]
FORTUNIZE: To regulate the fortune of; to make happy. [Obs.] Spenser.
FALSE-HEARTED: Hollow or unsound at the core; treacherous; deceitful;perfidious. Bacon.-- False"*heart`ed*ness, n. Bp. Stillingfleet.
FACED: Having (such) a face, or (so many) faces; as, smooth-faced,two-faced.
FUSAROLE: A molding generally placed under the echinus or quarter roundof capitals in the Doric, Ionic, and Corinthian orders ofarchitecture.
FOUR: One more than three; twice two.
FRENCH: Of or pertaining to France or its inhabitants. French bean(Bot.), the common kidney bean (Phaseolus vulgaris).-- French berry (Bot.), the berry of a species of buckthorn (Rhamnuscatharticus), which affords a saffron, green or purple pigment.-- French casement (Arch.) See French window, under Window.-- French chalk (Min.), a variety of granular talc; -- used fordrawing lines on cloth, etc. See under Chalk.-- French cowslip (Bot.) The Primula Auricula. See Bear's-ear.-- French fake (Naut.), a mode of coiling a rope by running itbackward and forward in parallel bends, so that it may run freely.-- French honeysuckle (Bot.) a plant of the genus Hedysarum (H.coronarium); -- called also garland honeysuckle.-- French horn, a metallic wind instrument, consisting of a longtube twisted into circular folds and gradually expanding from themouthpiece to the end at which the sound issues; -- called in Francecor de chasse.-- French leave, an informal, hasty, or secret departure; esp., theleaving a place without paying one's debts.-- French pie Etym: [French (here used in sense of "foreign") + piea magpie (in allusion to its black and white color)] (Zoöl.), theEuropean great spotted woodpecker (Dryobstes major); -- called alsowood pie.-- French polish. (a) A preparation for the surface of woodwork,consisting of gums dissolved in alcohol, either shellac alone, orshellac with other gums added. (b) The glossy surface produced by theapplication of the above.-- French purple, a dyestuff obtained from lichens and used forcoloring woolen and silken fabrics, without the aid of mordants. Ure.-- French red rouge.-- French rice, amelcorn.-- French roof (Arch.), a modified form of mansard roof having anearly flat deck for the upper slope.-- French tub, a dyer's mixture of protochloride of tin and logwood;-- called also plum tub. Ure.-- French window. See under Window.
FENES-TELLA: Any small windowlike opening or recess, esp. one to show therelics within an altar, or the like.
FOSSILIZATION: The process of converting, or of being converted, into afossil.
FORESTER: A lepidopterous insect belonging to Alypia and allied genera;as, the eight-spotted forester (A. octomaculata), which in the larvalstate is injurious to the grapevine.
FOREPRIZE: To prize or rate beforehand. [Obs.] Hooker.
FACILITATION: The act of facilitating or making easy.
FUEGIAN: Of or pertaining to Terra del Fuego.-- n.
FOURFOOTED: Having four feet; quadruped; as, fourfooted beasts.
FIRE: To cauterize. To fire up, to light up the fires of, as of anengine.
FRONTAGE: The front part of an edifice or lot; extent of front.
FIELDEN: Consisting of fields. [Obs.]The fielden country also and plains. Holland.
FLEURON: A flower-shaped ornament, esp. one terminating an object orforming one of a series, as a knob of a cover to a dish, or a flower-shaped part in a necklace.
FOULARD: A thin, washable material of silk, or silk and cotton,originally imported from India, but now also made elsewhere.
FEUDALIZE: To reduce toa feudal tenure; to conform to feudalism.
FORMICAROID: Like or pertaining to the family Formicaridæ or ant thrushes.
FROWN: To repress or repel by expressing displeasure or disapproval;to rebuke with a look; as, frown the impudent fellow into silence.
FLANCHED: Having flanches; -- said of an escutcheon with those bearings.
FLAX: A plant of the genus Linum, esp. the L. usitatissimum, whichhas a single, slender stalk, about a foot and a half high, with blueflowers. The fiber of the bark is used for making thread and cloth,called linen, cambric, lawn, lace, etc. Linseed oil is expressed fromthe seed.
FRATERNIZE: To associate or hold fellowship as brothers, or as men of likeoccupation or character; to have brotherly feelings.
FRIEZED: Gathered, or having the map gathered, into little tufts, knots,or protuberances. Cf. Frieze, v. t., and Friz, v. t.,
FOREDECK: The fore part of a deck, or of a ship.
FUNKY: Pertaining to, or characterized by, great fear, or funking.[Colloq. Eng.]
FESTIVAL: Pertaining to a fest; festive; festal; appropriate to afestival; joyous; mirthful.I cannot woo in festival terms. Shak.
FLAVORED: Having a distinct flavor; as, high-flavored wine.
FULL-BLOOMED: Like a perfect blossom. "Full-bloomed lips." Crashaw.
FLAGSTONE: A flat stone used in paving, or any rock which will split intosuch stones. See Flag, a stone.
FAIR CATCH: A catch made by a player on side who makes a prescribed signalthat he will not attempt to advance the ball when caught. He must notthen be interfered with.
FROISE: A kind of pancake. See 1st Fraise. [Written also fraise.]
FILLETING: The protecting of a joint, as between roof and parapet wall,with mortar, or cement, where flashing is employed in better work.
FOG: (Agric.) To pasture cattle on the fog, or aftergrass, of; toeat off the fog from.
FORSLUGGE: To lsoe by idleness or slotch. [Obs.] Chaucer.
FUSTINESS: A fusty state or quality; moldiness; mustiness; an ill smellfrom moldiness.
FOOTHILL: A low hill at the foot of highe
FORESLOW: To make slow; to hinder; to obstruct. [Obs.] See Forslow, v. t.No stream, no wood, no mountain could foreslow Their hasty pace.Fairfax.
FULLERY: The place or the works where the fulling of cloth is carriedon.
FLORIDITY: The quality of being florid; floridness. Floyer.
FRUSTRABLE: Capable of beeing frustrated or defeated.
FIDIA: A genus of small beetles, of which one species (the grapevineFidia, F. longipes) is very injurious to vines in America.
FASSAITE: A variety of pyroxene, from the valley of Fassa, in the Tyrol.
FIACRE: A kind of French hackney coach.
FANFARON: A bully; a hector; a swaggerer; an empty boaster. [R.] Dryden.
FATALISTIC: Implying, or partaking of the nature of, fatalism.
FIRE-SET: A set of fire irons, including, commonly, tongs, shovel, andpoker.
FREEWILL: Of or pertaining to free will; voluntary; spontaneous; as, afreewill offering. Frewill Baptists. See under Baptist.
FASCET: A wire basket on the end of a rod to carry glass bottles, etc.,to the annealing furnace; also, an iron rod to be thrust into themouths of bottles, and used for the same purpose; -- calles alsopontee and punty.
FRANK-FEE: A species of tenure in fee simple, being the opposite ofancient demesne, or copyhold. Burrill.
FLYAWAY: Disposed to fly away; flighty; unrestrained; light and free; --used of both persons and things. -- n.
FINNY: Having, or abounding in, fins, as fishes; pertaining to fishes.
FLORIKEN: An Indian bustard (Otis aurita). The Bengal floriken isSypheotides Bengalensis. [Written also florikan, floriken, florican.]
FUNDAMENTALLY: Primarily; originally; essentially; radically; at thefoundation; in origin or constituents. "Fundamentally defective."Burke.
FERINE: Wild; untamed; savage; as, lions, tigers, wolves, and bears areferine beasts. Sir M. Hale.-- n.
FORESKIRT: The front skirt of a garment, in distinction from the train.Honor's train Is longer than his foreskirt. Shak.
FRONTO-: A combining form signifying relating to the forehead or thefrontal bone; as, fronto-parietal, relating to the frontal and theparietal bones; fronto-nasal, etc.
FISHING: Pertaining to fishing; used in fishery; engaged in fishing; as,fishing boat; fishing tackle; fishing village. Fishing fly, anartificial fly for fishing.-- Fishing line, a line used in catching fish.-- Fishing net, a net of various kinds for catching fish; includingthe bag net, casting net, drag net, landing net, seine, shrimpingnet, trawl, etc.-- Fishing rod, a long slender rod, to which is attached the linefor angling.-- Fishing smack, a sloop or other small vessel used in sea fishing.-- Fishing tackle, apparatus used in fishing, as hook, line, rod,etc.-- Fishing tube (Micros.), a glass tube for selecting a microscopicobject in a fluid.
FEMINYE: The people called Amazons. [Obs.] "[The reign of] feminye."Chaucer.
FLOURED: Finely granulated; -- said of quicksilver which has beengranulated by agitation during the amalgamation process. Raymond.
FAHAM: The leaves of an orchid (Angraecum fragrans), of the islands ofBourbon and Mauritius, used (in France) as a substitute for Chinesetea.
FLOWERER: A plant which flowers or blossoms.Many hybrids are profuse and persistent flowerers. Darwin.
FINGER: To use the fingers in playing on an instrument. Busby.
FADE: Weak; insipid; tasteless; commonplace. [R.] "Passages that aresomewhat fade." Jeffrey.His masculine taste gave him a sense of something fade and ludicrous.De Quincey.
FIRSTLING: Firstborn.All the firstling males. Deut. xv. 19.
FORECLOSURE: The act or process of foreclosing; a proceeding which bars orextinguishes a mortgager's right of redeeming a mortgaged estate.
FORETELL: To predict; to tell before occurence; to prophesy; to foreshow.Deeds then undone my faithful tongue foretold. Pope.Prodigies, foretelling the future eminence and luster of hischaracter. C. Middleton.
FAMILIARIZATION: The act or process of making familiar; the result of becomingfamiliar; as, familiarization with scenes of blood.
FOOLHARDIHOOD: The state of being foolhardy; foolhardiness.
FREE-HAND: Done by the hand, without support, or the guidance ofinstruments; as, free-hand drawing. See under Drawing.
FEODALITY: Feudal tenure; the feudal system. See Feudality. Burke.
FRIDAY: The sixth day of the week, following Thursday and precedingSaturday.
FOSSA: A pit, groove, cavity, or depression, of greater or less depth;as, the temporal fossa on the side of the skull; the nasal fossæcontaining the nostrils in most birds.
FOOL: A compound of gooseberries scalded and crushed, with cream; --commonly called gooseberry fool.
FAMILY: A groupe of organisms, either animal or vegetable, related bycertain points of resemblance in structure or development, morecomprehensive than a genus, because it is usually based on fewer orless pronounced points of likeness. In zoölogy a family is lesscomprehesive than an order; in botany it is often considered the samething as an order. Family circle. See under Circle.-- Family man. (a) A man who has a family; esp., one who has a wifeand children living with him andd dependent upon him. (b) A man ofdomestic habits. "The Jews are generally, when married, mostexemplary family men." Mayhew.-- Family of curves or surfaces (Geom.), a group of curves orsurfaces derived from a single equation.-- In a family way, like one belonging to the family. "Why don't weask him and his ladies to come over in a family way, and dine withsome other plain country gentlefolks" Thackeray.-- In the family way, pregnant. [Colloq.]
FRUCTESCENCE: The maturing or ripening of fruit. [R.] Martyn.
FELLINIC: Of, relating to, or derived from, bile or gall; as, fellinicacid.
FOSSANE: A species of civet (Viverra fossa) resembling the genet.
FOVEOLATE: Having small pits or depression, as the receptacle in somecomposite flowers.
FUNIS: A cord; specifically, the umbilical cord or navel string.
FOURFOLD: Four times; quadruple; as, a fourfold division.He snall restore the lamb fourfold. 2 Sam. xii. 6.
FANFARONADE: A swaggering; vain boasting; ostentation; a bluster. Swift.
FATHERHOOD: The state of being a father; the character or authority of afather; paternity.
FLYBOAT: A large Dutch coasting vessel.Captain George Weymouth made a voyage of discovery to the northwestwith two flyboats. Purchas.
FUNNELFORM: Having the form of a funnel, or tunnel; that is, expandinggradually from the bottom upward, as the corolla of some flowers;infundibuliform.
FLAYER: One who strips off the skin.
FLOUR: The finely ground meal of wheat, or of any other grain;especially, the finer part of meal separated by bolting; hence, thefine and soft powder of any substance; as, flour of emery; flour ofmustard. Flour bolt, in milling, a gauze-covered, revolving,cylindrical frame or reel, for sifting the flour from the refusecontained in the meal yielded by the stones.-- Flour box a tin box for scattering flour; a dredging box.-- Flour dredge or dredger, a flour box.-- Flour dresser, a mashine for sorting and distributing flouraccording to grades of fineness.-- Flour mill, a mill for grinding and sifting flour.
FOREGANGER: A short rope grafted on a harpoon, to which a longer linTotten.
FEESE: the short run before a leap. [Obs.] Nares.
FACEWORK: The material of the outside or front side, as of a wall orbuilding; facing.
FLAXY: Like flax; flaxen. Sir M. Sandys.
FALLOWIST: One who favors the practice of fallowing land. [R.] Sinclair.
FULCRATE: Propped; supported by accessory organs. [R.] Gray.
FLEETNESS: Swiftness; rapidity; velocity; celerity; speed; as, thefleetness of a horse or of time.
FREETHINKING: Undue boldness of speculation; unbelief. Berkeley.-- a.
FIERINESS: The quality of being fiery; heat; acrimony; irritability; as, afieriness of temper. Addison.
FLAPDRAGON: To swallow whole, as a flapdragon; to devour. [Obs.]See how the sea flapdragoned it. Shak.
FUGUE: A polyphonic composition, developed from a given theme orthemes, according to strict contrapuntal rules. The theme is firstgiven out by one voice or part, and then, while that pursues its way,it is repeated by another at the interval of a fifth or fourth, andso on, until all the parts have answered one by one, continuing theirseveral melodies and interweaving them in one complex progressivewhole, in which the theme is often lost and reappears.All parts of the scheme are eternally chasing each other, like theparts of a fugue. Jer. Taylor.
FERAE NATURAE: Of a wild nature; -- applied to animals, as foxes, wild ducks,etc., in which no one can claim property.
FAMILISTERY: A community in which many persons unite as in one family, andare regulated by certain communistic laws and customs.
FROGMOUTH: One of several species of Asiatic and East Indian birds of thegenus Batrachostomus (family Podargidæ); -- so called from their verybroad, flat bills.
FOOTSTONE: The stone at the foot of a grave; -- opposed to headstone.
FOP: One whose ambition it is to gain admiration by showy dress; acoxcomb; an inferior dandy.
FILTER: Any porous substance, as cloth, paper, sand, or charcoal,through which water or other liquid may passed to cleanse it from thesolid or impure matter held in suspension; a chamber or devicecontaining such substance; a strainer; also, a similar device forpurifying air. Filter bed, a pond, the bottom of which is a filtercomposed of sand gravel.-- Filter gallery, an underground gallery or tunnel, alongside of astream, to collect the water that filters through the interveningsand and gravel; -- called also infiltration gallery.
FLOWERLESS: Having no flowers. Flowerless plants, plants which have no trueflowers, and produce no seeds; cryptigamous plants.
FORGING: A piece of forged work in metal; -- a general name for a pieceof hammered iron or steel.There are very few yards in the world at which such forgings could beturned out. London Times.
FEMINIZE: To make womanish or effeminate. Dr. H. More.
FLIMFLAM: A freak; a trick; a lie. Beau. & Fl.
FACINOROUS: Atrociously wicked. [Obs.] Jer. Taylor.-- Fa*cin"o*rous*ness, n. [Obs.]
FASTUOUS: Proud; haughty; disdainful. [Obs.] Barrow. Fas"tu*ous*ness, n.[Obs.] Jer. Taylor.
FOCALIZE: To bring to a focus; to focus; to concentrate.Light is focalized in the eye, sound in the ear. De Quincey.
FORTED: Furnished with, or guarded by, forts; strengthened or defended,as by forts. [R.] Shak.
FETTLE: 1. To repair; to prepare; to put in order. [Prov. Eng.]Carlyle.
FOREDETERMINE: To determine or decree beforehand. Bp. Hopkins.
FINDABLE: Capable of beong found; discoverable. Fuller.
FLEECE: The fine web of cotton or wool removed by the doffing knifefrom the cylinder of a carding machine. Fleece wool, wool shorn fromthe sheep.-- Golden fleece. See under Golden.
FLOP: Act of flopping. [Colloq.] W. H. Russell.
FALSETTO: A false or artificial voice; that voice in a man which liesabove his natural voice; the male counter tenor or alto voice. SeeHead voice, under Voice.
FORMAT: The shape and size of a book; hence, its external form.
FARTHERMOST: Most distant or remote; as, the farthest degree. See Furthest.
FEDERARY: A partner; a confederate; an accomplice. [Obs.] hak.
FORTNIGHT: The space of fourteen days; two weeks.
FOREALLEGE: To allege or cite before. Fotherby.
FLORA: The goddess of flowers and spring.
FORGETTABLE: Liable to be, or that may be, forgotten. Carlyle.
FONDON: A large copper vessel used for hot amalgamation.
FULGURITE: A vitrified sand tube produced by the striking of lightning onsand; a lightning tube; also, the portion of rock surface fused by alightning discharge.
FIBRINOGEN: An albuminous substance existing in the blood, and in otheranimal fluids, which either alone or with fibrinoplastin orparaglobulin forms fibrin, and thus causes coagulation.
FORENOTICE: Notice or information of an event before it happens;forewarning. [R.] Rymer.
FAIRILY: In the manner of a fairy.Numerous as shadows haunting fairily The brain. Keats.
FEUILLTONIST: A writer of feuilletons. F. Harrison.
FICO: A fig; an insignificant trifle, no more than the snap of one'sthumb; a sign of contempt made by the fingers, expressing. A fig foryou.Steal! foh, a fico for the phrase. Shak.
FILLING: Prepared wort added to ale to cleanse it. Back filling. (Arch.)See under Back, a.
FLATLING: With the flat side, as of a sword; flatlong; in a prostrateposition. [Obs.] Spenser.
FULMAR: One of several species of sea birds, of the familyprocellariidæ, allied to the albatrosses and petrels. Among the well-known species are the arctic fulmar (Fulmarus glacialis) (called alsofulmar petrel, malduck, and mollemock), and the giant fulmar(Ossifraga gigantea).
FARDEL: A bundle or little pack; hence, a burden. [Obs.] Shak.A fardel of never-ending misery and suspense. Marryat.
FILIETY: The relation of a son to a father; sonship; -- the correlativeof paternity. J. S. Mill.
FESTIVE: Pertaining to, or becoming, a feast; festal; joyous; gay;mirthful; sportive.-- Fes"tive*ly, adv.The glad circle round them yield their souls To festive mirth and witthat knows no gall. Thomson.
FLUID: Having particles which easily move and change their relativeposition without a separation of the mass, and which easily yield topressure; capable of flowing; liquid or gaseous.
FRYING: The process denoted by the verb fry. Frying pan, an iron panwith a long handle, used for frying meat. vegetables, etc.
FLOWAGE: An overflowing with water; also, the water which thusoverflows.
FUNNY: Droll; comical; amusing; laughable. Funny bone. See crazy bone,under Crazy.
FIFTY: Five times ten; as, fifty men.
FORMLESS: Shapeless; without a determinate form; wanting regularity ofshape.-- Form"less*ly, adv.-- Form"less*ness, n.
FLY-CASE: The covering of an insect, esp. the elytra of beetles.
FECULA: Any pulverulent matter obtained from plants by simply breakingdown the texture, washing with water, and subsidence. Especially:(a) The nutritious part of wheat; starch or farina; -- called alsoamylaceous fecula. (b) The green matter of plants; chlorophyll.
FLAGELLATOR: One who practices flagellation; one who whips or scourges.
FURNISH: That which is furnished as a specimen; a sample; a supply.[Obs.] Greene.
FIREFLY: Any luminous winged insect, esp. luminous beetles of the familyLampyridæ.
FROE: A dirty woman; a slattern; a frow. [Obs.] "Raging franticfroes." Draylon.
FETAL: Pertaining to, or connected with, a fetus; as, fetalcirculation; fetal membranes.
FACTITIVE: Pertaining to that relation which is proper when the act, as ofa transitive verb, is not merely received by an object, but producessome change in the object, as when we say, He made the water wine.Sometimes the idea of activity in a verb or adjective involves in ita reference to an effect, in the way of causality, in the activevoice on the immediate objects, and in the passive voice on thesubject of such activity. This second object is called the factitiveobject. J. W. Gibbs.
FOAL: The young of any animal of the Horse family (Equidæ); a colt; afilly. Foal teeth (Zoöl.), the first set of teeth of a horse.-- In foal, With foal, being with young; pregnant; -- said of a mareor she ass.
FLAT-HEADED: Having a head with a flattened top; as, a flat-headed nail.
FRONDLET: A very small frond, or distinct portion of a compound frond.
FECUNDIFY: To make fruitful; to fecundate. Johnson.
FRORN: Frozen. [Obs.]Well nigh frorn I feel. Spenser.
FAD: A hobby ; freak; whim.-- Fad"dist, n.It is your favorite fad to draw plans. G. Eliot.
FRUSH: To batter; to break in pieces. [Obs.]I like thine armor well; I'll frush it and unlock the rivets all.Shak.
FIRETAIL: The European redstart; -- called also fireflirt. [prov. Eng.]
FRISURE: The dressing of the hair by crisping or curling. Smollett.
FORK: To raise, or pitch with a fork, as hay; to dig or turn overwith a fork, as the soil.Forking the sheaves on the high-laden cart. Prof. Wilson.To fork over or out, to hand or pay over, as money. [Slang] G. Eliot.
FESTUCOUS: Formed or consisting of straw. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
FALCULATE: Curved and sharppointed, like a falcula, or claw of a falcon.
FAN PALM: Any palm tree having fan-shaped or radiate leaves; as theChamærops humilis of Southern Europe; the species of Sabal andThrinax in the West Indies, Florida, etc.; and especially the greattalipot tree (Corypha umbraculifera) of Ceylon and Malaya. The leavesof the latter are often eighteen feet long and fourteen wide, and areused for umbrellas, tents, and roofs. When cut up, they are used forbooks and manuscripts.
FRISKER: One who frisks; one who leaps of dances in gayety; a wanton; aninconstant or unsettled person. Camden.
FOREJUDGER: A judgment by which one is deprived or put of a right or thingin question.
FOZINESS: The state of being fozy; spiritlessness; dullness. [Scot.][The Whigs'] foziness can no longer be concealed. Blackwood's.
FALSISM: That which is evidently false; an assertion or statement thefalsity of which is plainly apparent; -- opposed to truism.
FAMELESS: Without fame or renown.-- Fame"less*ly, adv.
FURDLE: To draw up into a bundle; to roll up. [Ods.]
FALCIFORM: Having the shape of a scithe or sickle; resembling a reapinghook; as, the falciform ligatment of the liver.
FLUX: Any substance or mixture used to promote the fusion of metalsor minerals, as alkalies, borax, lime, fluorite.
FELIS: A genus of carnivorous mammals, including the domestic cat, thelion, tiger, panther, and similar animals.
FOOTING: The thickened or sloping portion of a wall, or of an embankmentat its foot. Footing course (Arch.), one of the courses of masonry atthe foot of a wall, broader than the courses above.-- To pay one's footing, to pay a fee on first doing anything, asworking at a trade or in a shop. Wright.-- Footing beam, the tie beam of a roof.
FROEBELIAN: Pertaining to, or derived from, Friedrich Froebel, or thekindergarten system of education, which he organized. -- n.
FINJAN: In the Levant, a small coffee cup without a handle, such as isheld in a cup or stand called a zarf.
FINCH: A small singing bird of many genera and species, belonging tothe family Fringillidæ.
FEDERALISM: the principles of Federalists or of federal union.
FORTUNATELY: In a fortunate manner; luckily; successfully; happily.
FORBIDDANCE: The act of forbidding; prohibition; command or edict against athing. [Obs.]ow hast thou yield to transgress The strict forbiddance. Milton.
FORCED: Done or produced with force or great labor, or by extraordinaryexertion; hurried; strained; produced by unnatural effort orpressure; as, a forced style; a forced laugh. Forced draught. Seeunder Draught.-- Forced march (Mil.), a march of one or more days made with allpossible speed.-- For"ced*ly, adv.-- For"ced*ness, n.
FLUORIC: Pertaining to, obtained from, or containing, fluorine.
FORESTALL: To obstruct or stop up, as a way; to stop the passage of onhighway; to intercept on the road, as goods on the way to market. Toforestall the market, to buy or contract for merchandise or provisionon its way to market, with the intention of selling it again at ahigher price; to dissuade persons from bringing their goods orprovisions there; or to persuade them to enhance the price whenthere. This was an offense at law in England until 1844. Burrill.
FREIGHT: Employed in the transportation of freight; having to do withfreight; as, a freight car. Freight agent, a person employed by atransportation company to receive, forward, or deliver goods.-- Freight car. See under Car.-- Freight train, a railroad train made up of freight cars; --called in England goods train.
FILER: One who works with a file.
FEARSOME: . Easily frightened; timid; timorous. "A silly fearsome thing."B. Taylor
FOEMAN: An enemy in war.And the stern joy which warriors feel In foemen worthy of theirsteel. Sir W. Scott
FOSSORES: A group of hymenopterous insects including the sand wasps. Theyexcavate cells in earth, where they deposit their eggs, with thebodies of other insects for the food of the young when hatched.[Written also Fossoria.]
FRATRICIDE: One who murders or kills his own brother.
FROWNY: Frowning; scowling. [Obs.]Her frowny mother's ragged shoulder. Sir F. Palgrave.
FIRER: One who fires or sets fire to anything; an incendiary. [R.] R.Carew.
FICTIONAL: Pertaining to, or characterized by, fiction; fictitious;romantic."Fictional rather than historical." Latham.
FROSTED: Covered with hoarfrost or anything resembling hoarfrost;ornamented with frosting; also, frost-bitten; as, a frosted cake;frosted glass.Frosted work is introduced as a foil or contrast to burnished work.Knight.
FIL: imp. of Fall, v. i. Fell. Chaucer.
FOUR-WAY: Allowing passage in either of four directions; as, a four-waycock, or valve. Francis. Four-way cock, a cock connected with fourpipes or ports, and having two or more passages in the plug, by whichthe adjacent pipes or ports may be made to communicate; formerly usedas a valve in the steam engine, and now for various other purposes.In the illustration, a leads to the upper end of a steam enginecylinder, and b to the lower end; c is the steam pipe, and d theexhaust pipe.
FORWAKED: Tired out with excessive waking or watching. [Obs.] Chaucer.
FRUTICULOSE: Like, or pertaining to, a small shrub. Gray.
FEIGNED: Not real or genuine; pretended; counterfeit; insincere; false."A feigned friend." Shak.Give ear unto my prayer, that goeth not out of feigned lips. Ps.xvii. 1.-- Feign"ed*ly, adv.-- Feign"ed*ness, n.Her treacherous sister Judah hath not turned unto me with her wholeheart, but feignedly. Jer. iii. 10.Feigned issue (Law), an issue produced in a pretended action betweentwo parties for the purpose of trying before a jury a question offact which it becomes necessary to settle in the progress of a cause.Burill. Bouvier.
FRAUGHTING: Constituting the freight or cargo. [Obs.] "The fraughting soulswithin her." Shak.
FIREPROOFING: The act or process of rendering anything incombustible; also,the materials used in the process.
FORWOT: pres. indic. 1st & 3d pers. sing. of Forwete. [Obs.] Chaucer.
FIFER: One who plays on a fife.
FECKS: A corruption of the word faith. Shak.
FILIPENDULOUS: Suspended by, or strung upon, a thread; -- said of tuberousswellings in the middle or at the extremities of slender, threadlikerootlets.
FULGURATA: A spectro-electric tube in which the decomposition of a liquidby the passage of an electric spark is observed. Knight.
FOLIOLATE: Of or pertaining to leaflets; -- used in composition; as, bi-foliolate. Gray.
FINIKIN: Precise in trifles; idly busy. [Colloq.] Smart.
FANTOCCINI: Puppets caused to perform evolutions or dramatic scenes bymeans of machinery; also, the representations in which they are used.
FAG: A knot or coarse part in cloth. [Obs.]
FLOWERPOT: A vessel, commonly or earthenware, for earth in which plantsare grown.
FRAME: To construct by fitting and uniting the several parts of theskeleton of any structure; specifically, in woodwork, to put togetherby cutting parts of one member to fit parts of another. See Dovetail,Halve, v. t., Miter, Tenon, Tooth, Tusk, Scarf, and Splice.
FUCUS: A genus of tough, leathery seaweeds, usually of a dull brownishgreen color; rockweed.
FULGENT: Exquisitely bright; shining; dazzling; effulgent.Other Thracians . . . fulgent morions wore. Glower.
FORTREAD: To tread down; to trample upon. [Obs.]In hell shall they be all fortroden of devils. Chaucer.
FOOTLICKER: A sycophant; a fawner; a toady. Cf. Bootlick. Shak.
FURCULA: A forked process; the wishbone or furculum.
FRANCIC: Pertaining to the Franks, or their language; Frankish.
FORBEARANCE: The act of forbearing or waiting; the exercise of patience.He soon shall findForbearance no acquittance ere day end. Milton.
FENUGREEK: A plant (trigonella Foenum Græcum) cultivated for its strong-smelling seeds, which are "now only used for giving false importanceto horse medicine and damaged hay." J. Smith (Pop. Names of Plants,1881).
FREIESLEBENITE: A sulphide of antimony, lead, and silver, occuring inmonoclinic crystals.
FLEXION: Syntactical change of form of words, as by declension orconjugation; inflection.Express the syntactical relations by flexion. Sir W. Hamilton.
FLAX-PLANT: A plant in new Zealand (Phormium tenax), allied to the liliesand aloes. The leaves are two inches wide and several feet long, andfurnish a fiber which is used for making ropes, mats, and coarsecloth.
FERMERERE: The officer in a religious house who had the care of theinfirmary. [Obs.]
FEATHER-VEINED: Having the veins (of a leaf) diverging from the two sides of amidrib.
FABACEOUS: Having the nature of a bean; like a bean.
FLIGHT-SHOT: The distance to which an arrow or flight may be shot; bowshot,-- about the fifth of a mile. [Prov. Eng. & Scot.]Within a flight-shot it inthe valley. Evelyn.Half a flight-shot from the king's oak. Sir W. Scott.
FELTER: To clot or mat together like felt.His feltered locks that on his bosom fell. Fairfax.
FLACKER: To flutter, as a bird. [Prov. Eng.] Grose.
FOREBRACE: A rope applied to the fore yardarm, to change the position ofthe foresail.
FLANNEN: Made or consisting of flannel. [Obs.] "Flannen robes." Dryden.
FALLOW DEER: A European species of deer (Cervus dama), much smaller than thered deer. In summer both sexes are spotted with white. It is commonin England, where it is often domesticated in the parks.
FRECKLED: Marked with freckles; spotted. "The freckled trout." Dryden.The freckled cowslip, burnet, and green clover. Shak.
FLAMBOYANT: Characterized by waving or flamelike curves, as in the traceryof windows, etc.; -- said of the later (15th century) French Gothicstyle.
FREAK: To variegate; to checker; to streak. [R.]Freaked with many a mingled hue. Thomson.
FEDERATIVE: Uniting in a league; forming a confederacy; federal. "Afederative society." Burke.
FY: A word which expresses blame, dislike, disapprobation,abhorrence, or contempt. See Fie.
FOURIERISM: The coöperative socialistic system of Charles Fourier, aFrenchman, who recommended the reorganization of society into smallcommunities, living in common.
FLOPPY: Having a tendency to flop or flap; as, a floppy hat brim. G.Eliot.
FOREFEEL: To feel beforehand; to have a presentiment of. [Obs.]As when, with unwieldy waves, the great sea forefeels winds. Chapman.
FLAGSHIP: The vessel which carries the commanding officer of a fleet orsquadron and flies his distinctive flag or pennant.
FUNERATE: To bury with funeral rites. [Obs.] Cockeram.
FIGURABLE: Capable of being brought to a fixed form or shape.Lead is figurable, but water is not. Johnson.
FORETIME: The past; the time before the present. "A very dim foretime."J. C. Shairp.
FENNEC: A small, African, foxlike animal (Vulpes zerda) of a pale fawncolor, remarkable for the large size of its ears.
FLUSH: A hand of cards of the same suit.
FOXGLOVE: Any plant of the genus Digitalis. The common English foxglove(Digitalis purpurea) is a handsome perennial or biennial plant, whoseleaves are used as a powerful medicine, both as a sedative anddiuretic. See Digitalis.Pan through the pastures oftentimes hath run To pluck the speckledfoxgloves from their stem. W. Browne.
FEBRUARY: The second month in the year, said to have been introduced intothe Roman calendar by Numa. In common years this month containstwenty-eight days; in the bissextile, or leap year, it has twenty-nine days.
FRIMAIRE: The third month of the French republican calendar. It commencedNovember 21, and ended December 20., See Vendémiaire.
FLY-FISH: To angle, using flies for bait. Walton.
FOLD: To become folded, plaited, or doubled; to close over another ofthe same kind; to double together; as, the leaves of the door fold. 1Kings vi. 34.
FREESTONE: A stone composed of sand or grit; -- so called because it iseasily cut or wrought.
FISTULIFORM: Of a fistular form; tubular; pipe-shaped.Stalactite often occurs fistuliform. W. Philips.
FANAL: A lighthouse, or the apparatus placed in it for giving light.
FAVIER EXPLOSIVE: Any of several explosive mixtures, chiefly of ammonium nitrateand a nitrate derivative of naphthalene. They are stable, but requireprotection from moisture. As prepared it is a compressed cylinder ofthe explosive, filled with loose powder of the same composition, allinclosed in waterproof wrappers. It is used for mining.
FLUOBORIC: Pertaining to, derived from, or consisting of, fluorine andboron. Fluoridic acid (Chem.), a double fluoride, consistingessentially of a solution of boron fluoride, in hydrofluoric acid. Ithas strong acid properties, and is the type of the borofluorides.Called also borofluoric acid.
FIGURANT: One who dances at the opera, not singly, but in groups orfigures; an accessory character on the stage, who figures in itsscenes, but has nothing to say; hence, one who figures in any scene,without taking a prominent part.
FUMET: The dung of deer. B. Jonson.
FERTILELY: In a fertile or fruitful manner.
FIENDFUL: Full of fiendish spirit or arts. Marlowe.-- Fiend"ful*ly, adv.
FLESHLY: In a fleshly manner; carnally; lasciviously. [Obs.] Chaucer.
FOSTERER: One who, or that which, fosters.
FAUNIST: One who describes the fauna of country; a naturalist. GilbertWhite.
FLYCATCHER: One of numerous species of birds that feed upon insects, whichthey take on the wing.
FORSLOW: To delay; to hinder; to neglect; to put off. [Obs.] Bacon.
FORCARVE: To cut completely; to cut off. [Obs.] Chaucer.
FIELDWORK: Any temporary fortification thrown up by an army in the field;-- commonly in the plural.All works which do not come under the head of permanent fortificationare called fieldworks. Wilhelm.
FILE: To put upon the files or among the records of a court; to noteon (a paper) the fact date of its reception in court.To file a paper, on the part of a party, is to place it in theofficial custody of the clerk. To file, on the part of the clerk, isto indorse upon the paper the date of its reception, and retain it inhis office, subject to inspection by whomsoever it may concern.Burrill.
FORBEAR: An ancestor; a forefather; -- usually in the plural. [Scot.]"Your forbears of old." Sir W. Scott.
FLAGELLATION: A beating or flogging; a whipping; a scourging. Garth.
FINIFY: To make fine; to dress finically. [Obs.]Hath so pared and finified them [his feet.] B. Jonson.
FUMACIOUS: Smoky; hence, fond of smoking; addicted to smoking tobacco.
FRAXINUS: A genus of deciduous forest trees, found in the north temperatezone, and including the true ash trees.
FULCRUM: That by which a lever is sustained, or about which it turns inlifting or moving a body.
FANATIC: Pertaining to, or indicating, fanaticism; extravagant inopinions; ultra; unreasonable; excessively enthusiastic, especiallyon religious subjects; as, fanatic zeal; fanatic notions.But Faith, fanatic Faith, once wedded fast To some dear falsehood,hugs it to the last. T. Moore.
FINN: A native of Finland; one of the FinnFinns.
FEUDALIZATION: The act of reducing to feudal tenure.
FURLOUGH: Leave of abserice; especially, leave given to an offcer orsoldier to be absent from service for a certain time; also, thedocument granting leave of absence.
FENESTRA: A small opening; esp., one of the apertures, closed bymembranes, between the tympanum and internal ear.
FORTIETH: One of forty equal parts into which one whole is divided; thequotient of a unit divided by forty; one next in order after thethirty-ninth.
FOSTRESS: A woman who feeds and cherishes; a nurse. B. Jonson.
FAUNA: The animals of any given area or epoch; as, the fauna ofAmerica; fossil fauna; recent fauna.
FISSURE: A narrow opening, made by the parting of any substance; acleft; as, the fissure of a rock. Cerebral fissures (Anat.), thefurrows or clefts by which the surface of the cerebrum is divided;esp., the furrows first formed by the infolding of the whole wall ofthe cerebrum.-- Fissure needle (Surg.), a spiral needle for catching together thegaping lips of wounds. Knight.-- Fissure of rolando (Anat.), the furrow separating the frontalfrom the parietal lobe in the cerebrum.-- Fissure of Sylvius (Anat.), a deep cerebral fissure separatingthe frontal from the temporal lobe. See Illust. under Brain.-- Fissure vein (Mining), a crack in the earth's surface filled withmineral matter. Raymond.
FLIRT: One who flirts; esp., a woman who acts with giddiness, or playsat courtship; a coquette; a pert girl.Several young flirts about town had a design to cast us out of thefashionable world. Addison.
FLAY: To skin; to strip off the skin or surface of; as, to flay anox; to flay the green earth.With her nails She 'll flay thy wolfish visage. Shak.
FORFEIT: Lost or alienated for an offense or crime; liable to penalseizure.Thy wealth being forfeit to the state. Shak.To tread the forfeit paradise. Emerson.
FLYING: Moving in the air with, or as with, wings; moving lightly orrapidly; intended for rapid movement.
FORTRESS: A fortified place; a large and permanent fortification,sometimes including a town; a fort; a castle; a stronghold; a placeof defense or security.
FLOUTINGLY: With flouting; insultingly; as, to treat a lover floutingly.
FLEETING: Passing swiftly away; not durable; transient; transitory; as,the fleeting hours or moments.
FLICKER: The golden-winged woodpecker (Colaptes aurutus); -- so calledfrom its spring note. Called also yellow-hammer, high-holder, pigeonwoodpecker, and yucca.The cackle of the flicker among the oaks. Thoureau.
FOUSSA: A viverrine animal of Madagascar (Cryptoprocta ferox). Itresembles a cat in size and form, and has retractile claws.
FOSSORIAL: Fitted for digging, adapted for burrowing or digging; as, afossorial foot; a fossorial animal.
FLUXIBILITY: The quality of being fluxible. Hammond.
FOREBRAIN: The anterior of the three principal divisions of the brain,including the prosencephalon and thalamencephalon. Sometimesrestricted to the prosencephalon only. See Brain.
FENCE: A projection on the bolt, which passes through the tumblergates in locking and unlocking.
FUGLE: To maneuver; to move hither and thither. [Colloq.]Wooden arms with elbow joints jerking and fugling in the air.Carlyle.
FOLIAR: Consisting of, or pertaining to, leaves; as, foliar appendages.Foliar gap (Bot.), an opening in the fibrovascular system of a stemat the point of origin of a leaf.-- Foliar trace (Bot.), a particular fibrovascular bundle passingdown into the stem from a leaf.
FORWARD: An agreement; a covenant; a promise. [Obs.]Tell us a tale anon, as forward is. Chaucer.
FEBRIFEROUS: Causing fever; as, a febriferous locality.
FUSTERIC: The coloring matter of fustet. Ure.
FOLIATION: The enrichment of an opening by means of foils, arranged intrefoils, quatrefoils, etc.; also, one of the ornaments. See Tracery.
FEASIBILITY: The quality of being feasible; practicability; also, that whichis feasible; as, before we adopt a plan, let us consider itsfeasibility.Men often swallow falsities for truths, dubiosities for certainties,possibilities for feasibilities. Sir T. Browne.
FURFUROL: A colorless oily liquid, C4H3O.CHO, of a pleasant odor,obtained by the distillation of bran, sugar, etc., and regarded as analdehyde derivative of furfuran; -- called also furfural.
FALDAGE: A privilege of setting up, and moving about, folds for sheep,in any fields within manors, in order to manure them; -- oftenreserved to himself by the lord of the manor. Spelman.
FROST-BITTEN: Nipped, withered, or injured, by frost or freezing.
FOOTBALL: An inflated ball to be kicked in sport, usually made in Indiarubber, or a bladder incased in Leather. Waller.
FUMAGE: Hearth money.Fumage, or fuage, vulgarly called smoke farthings. Blackstone.
FEME: A woman. Burrill. Feme covert (Law), a married woman. SeeCovert, a., 3.-- Feme sole (Law), a single or unmarried woman; a woman who hasnever been married, or who has been divorced, or whose husband isdead.-- Feme sole trader or merchant (Eng. Law), a married woman, by thecustom of London, engages in business on her own account, inpendentlyof her husband.
FRIGATE-BUILT: Built like a frigate with a raised quarter-deck and forecastle.
FLANK: That part of a bastion which reaches from the curtain to theface, and defends the curtain, the flank and face of the oppositebastion; any part of a work defending another by a fire along theoutside of its parapet. See Illust. of Bastion.
FLEME: To banish; to drive out; to expel. [Obs.] "Appetite flemethdiscretion." Chaucer.
FRITILLARY: A plant with checkered petals, of the genus Fritillaria: theGuinea-hen flower. See Fritillaria.
FENKS: The refuse whale blubber, used as a manure, and in themanufacture of Prussian blue. Ure.
FALCADE: The action of a horse, when he throws himself on his haunchestwo or three times, bending himself, as it were, in very quickcurvets. Harris.
FANATICIZE: To cause to become a fanatic.
FAUN: A god of fields and shipherds, diddering little from the satyr.The fauns are usually represented as half goat and half man.Satyr or Faun, or Sylvan. Milton.
FEUDATORY: A tenant or vassal who held his lands of a superior oncondition of feudal service; the tenant of a feud or fief.The grantee . . . was styled the feudatory or vassal. Blackstone.[He] had for feudatories great princes. J. H. Newman.
FOSSICK: To search for gold by picking at stone or earth or among rootsin isolated spots, picking over abandoned workings, etc.; hence, tosteal gold or auriferous matter from another's claim. [Australia]
FIASCO: A complete or ridiculous failure, esp. of a musicalperformance, or of any pretentious undertaking.
FLYER: One in a flight of steps which are parallel to each other(as inordinary stairs), as distinguished from a winder.
FRINGE: One of a number of light or dark bands, produced by theinterference of light; a diffraction band; -- called alsointerference fringe.
FUNGIVOROUS: Eating fungi; -- said of certain insects and snails.
FORMATE: A salt of formic acid. [Written also formiate.]
FIGURAL: Figurate. See Figurate. Figural numbers. See Figurate numbers,under Figurate.
FISHERY: The right to take fish at a certain place, or in particularwaters. Abbott.
FLUMINOUS: Pertaining to rivers; abounding in streama.
FORTNIGHTLY: Occurring or appearing once in a fortnight; as, a fortnightlymeeting of a club; a fortnightly magazine, or other publication.-- adv.
FIRRY: Made of fir; abounding in firs.In firry woodlands making moan. Tennyson.
FEATLY: Neatly; dexterously; nimbly. [Archaic]Foot featly here and there. Shak.
FRIENDLINESS: The condition or quality of being friendly. Sir P. Sidney.
FISTULATE: To make hollow or become hollow like a fistula, or pipe. [Obs.]"A fistulated ulcer." Fuller.
FELUCCA: A small, swift-sailing vessel, propelled by oars and lateensails, -- once common in the Mediterranean.
FORDLESS: Without a ford.A deep and fordless river. Mallock.
FILIBUSTERISM: The characteristics or practices of a filibuster. Bartlett.
FICTOR: An artist who models or forms statues and reliefs in anyplastic material. [R.] Elmes.
FRAP: To draw together; to bind with a view to secure and strengthen,as a vessel by passing cables around it; to tighten; as a tackle bydrawing the lines together. Tottem.
FITCHE: Sharpened to a point; pointed. Cross fitché, a cross having thelower arm pointed.
FILARIA: A genus of slender, nematode worms of many species, parasiticin various animals. See Guinea worm.
FOREFRONT: Foremost part or place.Set ye Uriah in the forefront of the hottest battle. 2 Sam. xi. 15.Socrates, Plato, Aristotle, standing in the forefront for all time,the masters of those who know. J. C. Shairp.
FLUTING: Decoration by means of flutes or channels; a flute, or flutescollectively; as, the fluting of a column or pilaster; the fluting ofa lady's ruffle. Fluting iron, a laundry iron for fluting ruffles; --called also Italian iron, or gaufering iron. Knight.-- Fluting lathe, a machine for forming spiral flutes, as onbalusters, table legs, etc.
FLESH: To remove flesh, membrance, etc., from, as from hides.
FLINGER: One who flings; one who jeers.
FICKLENESS: The quality of being fickle; instability; inconsonancy. Shak.
FASHIONIST: An obsequious follower of the modes and fashions. [R.] Fuller.
FETOR: A strong, offensive smell; stench; fetidness. Arbuthnot.
FRIT: The material of which glass is made, after having been calcinedor partly fused in a furnace, but before vitrification. It is acomposition of silex and alkali, occasionally with other ingredients.Ure.
FILIBUSTER: A lawless military adventurer, especially one in quest ofplunder; a freebooter; -- originally applied to buccaneers infestingthe Spanish American coasts, but introduced into common English todesignate the followers of Lopez in his expedition to Cuba in 1851,and those of Walker in his expedition to Nicaragua, in 1855.
FISH-TAIL: Like the of a fish; acting, or producing something, like thetail of a fish. Fish-tail burner, a gas burner that gives a spreadingflame shaped somewhat like the tail of a fish.-- Fish-tail propeller (Steamship), a propeller with a single bladethat oscillates like the tail of a fish when swimming.
FLOWERET: A small flower; a floret. Shak.
FREEMASONIC: Pertaining to, or resembling, the institutions or the practicesof freemasons; as, a freemasonic signal.
FLATWARE: Articles for the table, as china or silverware, that are moreor less flat, as distinguished from hollow ware.
FREEMASON: One of an ancient and secret association or fraternity, said tohave been at first composed of masons or builders in stone, but nowconsisting of persons who are united for social enjoyment and mutualassistance.
FASCICLED: Growing in a bundle, tuft, or close cluster; as, the fascicledleaves of the pine or larch; the fascicled roots of the dahlia;fascicled muscle fibers; fascicled tufts of hair.
FRONTAL: Belonging to the front part; being in front; esp. (Anat.),
FREE SILVER: The free coinage of silver; often, specif., the free coinage ofsilver at a fixed ratio with gold, as at the ratio of 16 to 1, whichratio for some time represented nearly or exactly the ratio of themarket values of gold and silver respectively.
FUTTOCK: One of the crooked timbers which are scarfed together to formthe lower part of the compound rib of a vessel; one of the crookedtransverse timbers passing across and over the keel. Futtock plates(Naut.), plates of iron to which the dead-eyes of the topmast riggingare secured.-- Futtock shrouds, short iron shrouds leading from the upper partof the lower mast or of the main shrouds to the edge of the top, orthrough it, and connecting the topmast rigging with the lower mast.Totten.
FERRULE: A bushing for expanding the end of a flue to fasten it tightlyin the tube plate, or for partly filling up its mouth.
FEATHERNESS: The state or condition of being feathery.
FRACTIONALLY: By fractions or separate portions; as, to distill a liquidfractionally, that is, so as to separate different portions.
FOOTHOLD: A holding with the feet; firm L'Estrange.
FURBISH: To rub or scour to brightness; to clean; to burnish; as, tofurbish a sword or spear. Shak.Furbish new the name of John a Gaunt. Shak.
FUNEST: Lamentable; doleful. [R.] "Funest and direful deaths."Coleridge.A forerunner of something very funest. Evelyn.
FLEXURE: The last joint, or bend, of the wing of a bird.
FORTUITOUS: Happening independently of human will or means of foresight;resulting from unavoidable physical causes. Abbott.
FLAM: A freak or whim; also, a falsehood; a lie; an illusory pretext;deception; delusion. [Obs.]A perpetual abuse and flam upon posterity. South.
FLOTATION PROCESS: A process of separating the substances contained in pulverizedore or the like by depositing the mixture on the  surface of aflowing liquid, the substances that are quickly wet readilyovercoming the surface tension of the liquid and sinking, the othersflowing off in a film or slime on the surface, though, perhaps,having a greater specific gravity than those that sink.
FLICK: To whip lightly or with a quick jerk; to flap; as, to flick ahorse; to flick the dirt from boots. Thackeray.
FIE: An exclamation denoting contempt or dislike. See Fy. Fuller.
FEROHER: A symbol of the solar deity, found on monuments exhumed inBabylon, Nineveh, etc.
FINIAL: The knot or bunch of foliage, or foliated ornament, that formsthe upper extremity of a pinnacle in Gothic architecture; sometimes,the pinnacle itself.
FEMALE: A plant which produces only that kind of reproductive organswhich are capable of developing into fruit after impregnation orfertilization; a pistillate plant.
FACTIONER: One of a faction. Abp. Bancroft.
FLUOROSCOPY: Examination of an object, as the human body, by exposing it tothe X rays and observing the shadow cast upon a fluorescent screen;cryptoscopy.
FINEDRAW: To sew up, so nicely that the seam is not perceived; to renter.Marryat.
FORWARDING: The process of putting a book into its cover, and making itready for the finisher.
FLOWERING: Having conspicuous flowers; -- used as an epithet with manynames of plants; as, flowering ash; flowering dogwood; floweringalmond, etc. Flowering fern, a genus of showy ferns (Osmunda), withconspicuous bivalvular sporangia. They usually grow in wet places.-- Flowering plants, plants which have stamens and pistils, andproduce true seeds; phenogamous plants; -- distinguished fromflowerless plants.-- Flowering rush, a European rushlike plant (Butomus umbellatus),with an umbel of rosy blossoms.
FINOCHIO: An umbelliferous plant (Foeniculum dulce) having a somewhattuberous stem; sweet fennel. The blanched stems are used in Franceand Italy as a culinary vegetable.
FREEBOOTER: One who plunders or pillages without the authority of nationalwarfare; a member of a predatory band; a pillager; a buccaneer; a searobber. Bacon.
FRONDE: A political party in France, during the minority of Louis XIV.,who opposed the government, and made war upon the court party.
FLUO-: A combining form indicating fluorine as an ingredient; as influosilicate, fluobenzene.
FIDELITY: Faithfulness; adherence to right; careful and exact observanceof duty, or discharge of obligations. Especially:(a) Adherence to a person or party to which one is bound; loyalty.Whose courageous fidelity was proof to all danger. Macaulay.The best security for the fidelity of men is to make interestcoincide with duty. A. Hamilton.
FORMULARIZATION: The act of formularizing; a formularized or formulatedstatement or exhibition. C. Kingsley.
FLITTERN: A term applied to the bark obtained from young oak trees.McElrath.
FAMOUSLY: In a famous manner; in a distinguished degree; greatly;splendidly.Then this land was famously enriched With politic grave counsel.Shak.
FUDGE WHEEL: A tool for ornamenting the edge of a sole.
FENESTRULE: One of the openings in a fenestrated structure.
FUSION: The union, or binding together, of adjacent parts or tissues.
FILARIASIS: The presence of filariæ in the blood; infection with filariæ.
FALLER: A part which acts by falling, as a stamp in a fulling mill, orthe device in a spinning machine to arrest motion when a threadbreaks.
FLUE PIPE: A pipe, esp. an organ pipe, whose tone is produced by theimpinging of a current of air upon an edge, or lip, causing a wavemotion in the air within; a mouth pipe; -- distinguished from reedpipe. Flue pipes are either open or closed (stopped at the distantend). The flute and flageolet are open pipes; a bottle acts as aclosed pipe when one blows across the neck. The organ has both openand closed flue pipes, those of metal being usually round in section,and those of wood triangular or square.
FISHHOOK: A hook with a pendant, to the end of which the fish-tackle ishooked. Dana.
FORMICA: A Linnæan genus of hymenopterous insects, including the commonants. See Ant.
FALSIFIABLE: Capable of being falsified, counterfeited, or corrupted.Johnson.
FOREWARN: To warn beforehand; to give previous warning, admonition,information, or notice to; to caution in advance.We were forewarned of your coming. Shak.
FLAT-CAP: A kind of low-crowned cap formerly worn by all classes inEngland, and continued in London after disuse elsewhere; -- hence, acitizen of London. Marston.
FOREARM: To arm or prepare for attack or resistance before the time ofneed. South.
FREMESCENT: Becoming murmurous, roaring. "Fremescent clangor." Carlyle. --Fre*mes"cence (#), n.
FISHGIG: A spear with barbed prongs used for harpooning fish. Knight.
FIN-TOED: Having toes connected by a membrane; palmiped; palmated; also,lobate.
FLAVANILINE: A yellow, crystalline, organic dyestuff, C16H14N2, of artificalproduction. It is a strong base, and is a complex derivative ofaniline and quinoline.
FAUCES: The narrow passage from the mouth to the pharynx, situatedbetween the soft palate and the base of the tongue; -- called alsothe isthmus of the fauces. On either side of the passage twomembranous folds, called the pillars of the fauces, inclose thetonsils.
FRUSTRATORY: Making void; rendering null; as, a frustratory appeal. [Obs.]Ayliffe.
FOLDER: One who, or that which, folds; esp., a flat, knifelikeinstrument used for folding paper.
FUNGI IMPERFECTI: A heterogenous group of fungi of which the complete lifehistory is not known. Some undoubtedly represent the conidium stagesof various Ascomycetes. The group is divided into the ordersSphæropsidales, Melanconiales, and Moniliales.
FUMIGATORY: Having the quality of purifying by smoke. [R.]
FOOTBRIDGE: A narrow bridge for foot passengers only.
FRIZZLE: To curl or crisp, as hair; to friz; to crinkle. Gay. To frizzleup, to crinkle or crisp excessively.
FACULTY: The body of person to whom are intrusted the government andinstruction of a college or university, or of one of its departments;the president, professors, and tutors in a college. Dean of faculty.See under Dean.-- Faculty of advocates. (Scot.) See under Advocate.
FLEA-LOUSE: A jumping plant louse of the family Psyllidæ, of many species.That of the pear tree is Psylla pyri.
FOREJUDGE: To judge beforehand, or before hearing the facts and proof; toprejudge.
FLIPE: To turn inside out, or with the leg part back over the foot, asa stocking in pulling off or for putting on. [Scot.]
FERRIAGE: The price or fare to be paid for passage at a ferry.
FLOWER: That part of a plant destined to produce seed, and henceincluding one or both of the sexual organs; an organ or combinationof the organs of reproduction, whether inclosed by a circle of foliarparts or not. A complete flower consists of two essential parts, thestamens and the pistil, and two floral envelopes, the corolla andcallyx. In mosses the flowers consist of a few special leavessurrounding or subtending organs called archegonia. See Blossom, andCorolla.
FOSSEWAY: One of the great military roads constructed by the Romans inEngland and other parts of Europe; -- so called from the fosse orditch on each side for keeping it dry.
FIREWORK: A pyrotechnic exhibition. [Obs. in the sing.]Night before last, the Duke of Richmond gave a firework. Walpole.
FINERY: A charcoal hearth or furnace for the conversion of cast ironinto wrought iron, or into iron suitable for puddling.
FRACTION: One or more aliquot parts of a unit or whole number; anexpression for a definite portion of a unit or magnitude. Common, orVulgar, fraction, a fraction in which the number of equal parts intowhich the integer is supposed to be divided is indicated by figuresor letters, called the denominator, written below a line, over whichis the numerator, indicating the number of these parts included inthe fraction; as -- Complex fraction, a fraction having a fraction ormixed number in the numerator or denominator, or in both. Davies &Peck.-- Compound fraction, a fraction of a fraction; two or morefractions connected by of.-- Continued fraction, Decimal fraction, Partial fraction, etc. Seeunder Continued, Decimal, Partial, etc.-- Improper fraction, a fraction in which the numerator is greaterthan the denominator.-- Proper fraction, a fraction in which the numerator is less thanthe denominator.
FAUTOR: A favorer; a patron; one who gives countenance or support; anabettor. [Obs.]The king and the fautors of his proceedings. Latimer.
FLAMMABILITY: The quality of being flammable; inflammability. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
FANGLENESS: Quality of being fangled. [Obs.]He them in new fangleness did pass. Spenser.
FERRYMAN: One who maintains or attends a ferry.
FOLIUM: A curve of the third order, consisting of two infinitebranches, which have a common asymptote. The curve has a doublepoint, and a leaf-shaped loop; whence the name. Its equation is x3 +y3 = axy.
FROUNCE: To gather into or adorn with plaits, as a dress; to formwrinkles in or upon; to curl or frizzle, as the hair.Not tricked and frounced, as she was wont. Milton.
FLECK: A flake; also, a lock, as of wool. [Obs.] J. Martin.
FERIATION: The act of keeping holiday; cessation from work. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
FEATHERBONE: A substitute for whalebone, made from the quills of geese andturkeys.
FEATHER-FOIL: An aquatic plant (Hottonia palustris), having finely dividedleaves.
FLOBERT: A small cartridge designed for target shooting; -- sometimescalled ball cap. Flobert rifle, a rifle adapted to the use offloberts.
FECUNDATE: To render fruitful or prolific; to impregnate; as, in flowersthe pollen fecundates the ovum through the stigma.
FRONTLET: The margin of the head, behind the bill of birds, often bearingrigid bristles.
FROG: 1. (Zoöl.) An amphibious animal of the genus Rana and relatedgenera, of many species. Frogs swim rapidly, and take long leaps onland. Many of the species utter loud notes in the springtime.
FRED: Peace; -- a word used in composition, especially in propernames; as, Alfred; Frederic.
FOREBEAM: The breast beam of a loom.
FRUBISH: To rub up: to furbish. [Obs.] Beau. c& Et.
FIMBRIA: A fringe, or fringed border.(b) A band of white matter bordering the hippocampus in the brain.-- Fim"bri*al, a.
FANTASY: To have a fancy for; to be pleased with; to like; to fancy.[Obs.] Cavendish.Which he doth most fantasy. Robynson (More's Utopia).
FORDRY: Entirely dry; withered. [Obs.] "A tree fordry." Chaucer.
FORWEARY: To weary extremely; to dispirit. [Obs.] Spenser.
FAMOUS: Celebrated in fame or public report; renowned; mach talked of;distinguished in story; -- used in either a good or a bad sense,chiefly the former; often followed by for; as, famous for erudition,for eloquence, for military skill; a famous pirate.Famous for a scolding tongue. Shak.
FOREFATHER: One who precedes another in the line of genealogy in anydegree, but usually in a remote degree; an ancestor.Respecting your forefathers, you would have been taught to respectyourselves. Burke.Forefathers' Day, the anniversary of the day (December 21) on whichthe Pilgrim Fathers landed at Plymouth, Massachusetts (1620). Onaccount of a mistake in reckoning the change from Old Style to NewStyle, it has generally been celebrated on the 22d.
FEMORAL: Pertaining to the femur or thigh; as, the femoral artery."Femoral habiliments." Sir W. Scott.
FOLLOW: To go or come after; -- used in the various senses of thetransitive verb: To pursue; to attend; to accompany; to be a result;to imitate.
FOREDESIGN: To plan beforehand; to intend previously. Cheyne.
FICUS: A genus of trees or shrubs, one species of which (F. Carica)produces the figs of commerce; the fig tree.
FLUXIBLE: Capable of being melted or fused, as a mineral. Holland.-- Flux"i*ble*ness, n.
FLINTY: Consisting of, composed of, abounding in, or resembling, flint;as, a flinty rock; flinty ground; a flinty heart. Flinty rockFlintystate, a siliceous slate; -- basanite is here included. See Basanite.
FONDANT: A kind of soft sweetmeat made by boiling solutions to the pointof crystallization, usually molded; as, cherry fondant.
FEELINGLY: In a feeling manner; pathetically; sympathetically.
FLUVIATIC: Belonging to rivers or streams; fluviatile. Johnson.
FILARIAL: Of, pertaining to, or caused by, filariæ and allied parasiticworms.
FORGEMAN: A skilled smith, who has a hammerer to assist him.
FRESHEN: To relieve, as a rope, by change of place where friction wearsit; or to renew, as the material used to prevent chafing; as, tofreshen a hawse. Totten. To freshen ballast (Naut.), to shift Orrestore it.-- To freshen the hawse, to pay out a little more cable, so as tobring the chafe on another part.-- To freshen the way, to increase the speed of a vessel. Ham. Nav.Encyc.
FRIVOL: To act frivolously; to trifle. Kipling. -- Friv"ol*er (#),Friv"ol*ler, n. [All Colloq.]
FIEND: An implacable or malicious foe; one who is diabolically wickedor cruel; an infernal being; -- applied specifically to the devil ora demon.Into this wild abyss the wary fiend Stood on the brink of Hell andlooked a while. Milton.O woman! woman! when to ill thy mind Is bent, all hell contains nofouler fiend. Pope.
FANG: The tusk of an animal, by which the prey is seized and held ortorn; a long pointed tooth; esp., one of the usually erectile,venomous teeth of serpents. Also, one of the falcers of a spider.Since I am a dog, beware my fangs. Shak.
FLUNKYDOM: The place or region of flunkies. C. Kingsley.
FLACCID: Yielding to pressure for want of firmness and stiffness; softand weak; limber; lax; drooping; flabby; as, a flaccid muscle;flaccid flesh.Religious profession . . . has become flacced. I. Taylor.-- Flac"cid*ly, adv.-- Flac"cid*ness, n.
FISHERMAN: A ship or vessel employed in the business of taking fish, as inthe cod fishery.
FORGER: One who forges, makes, of forms; a fabricator; a falsifier.
FIREWORM: The larva of a small tortricid moth which eats the leaves ofthe cranberry, so that the vines look as if burned; -- called alsocranberry worm.
FRIABIIITY: The quality of being friable; friableness. Locke.
FORGIVING: Disposed to forgive; inclined to overlook offenses; mild;merciful; compassionate; placable; as, a forgiving temper.-- For*giv"ing*ly, adv.-- For*giv"ing*ness, n. J. C. Shairp.
FORGET-ME-NOT: A small herb, of the genus Myosotis (M. palustris, incespitosa,etc.), bearing a beautiful blue flower, and extensively consideredthe emblem of fidelity.
FIGULINE: A piece of pottery ornamented with representations of naturalobjects.Whose figulines and rustic wares Scarce find him bread from day today. Longfellow.
FENIAN: A member of a secret organization, consisting mainly ofIrishment, having for its aim the overthrow of English rule inireland.
FAYALITE: A black, greenish, or brownish mineral of the chrysolite group.It is a silicate of iron.
FOULDER: To flash, as lightning; to lighten; to gleam; to thunder.[Obs.] "Flames of fouldering heat." Spenser.
FIERASFER: A genus of small, slender fishes, remarkable for their habit ofliving as commensals in other animals. One species inhabits the gillcavity of the pearl oyster near Panama; another lives within an EastIndian holothurian.
FROTH: To throw up or out spume, foam, or bubbles; to foam; as beerfroths; a horse froths.
FAREWELL: Go well; good-by; adieu; -- originally applied to a persondeparting, but by custom now applied both to those who depart andthose who remain. It is often separated by the pronoun; as, fare youwell; and is sometimes used as an expression of separation only; as,farewell the year; farewell, ye sweet groves; that is, I bid youfarewell.So farewell hope, and with hope, farewell fear. Milton.Fare thee well! and if forever, Still forever fare thee well. Byron.
FLUORENE: A colorless, crystalline hydrocarbon, C13H10 having a beautifulviolet fluorescence; whence its name. It occurs in the higher boilingproducts of coal tar, and is obtained artificially.
FIBULA: The outer and usually the smaller of the two bones of the leg,or hind limb, below the knee.
FOREIGNISM: Anything peculiar to a foreign language or people; a foreignidiom or custom.It is a pity to see the technicalities of the so-called liberalprofessions distigured by foreignisms. Fitzed. Hall.
FOLDING: The keepig of sheep in inclosures on arable land, etc. Foldingboat, a portable boat made by stretching canvas, etc., over jointedframework, used in campaigning, and by tourists, etc. Ham. Nav.Encyc. Folding chairFolding door, one of two or more doors filling asingle and hung upon hinges.
FIBROUS: Containing, or consisting of, fibers; as, the fibrous coat ofthe cocoanut; the fibrous roots of grasses.-- Fi"brous*ness, n.
FREELY: In a free manner; without restraint or compulsion; abundantly;gratuitously.Of every tree of the garden thou mayst freely eat. Gen. ii. 16.Freely ye have received, freely give. Matt. x. 8.Freely they stood who stood, and fell who fell. Milton.Freely we serve Because we freely love. Milton.
FLUOROSCOPE: An instrument for observing or exhibiting fluorescence.
FERRARA: A sword bearing the mark of one of the Ferrara family of Italy.These swords were highly esteemed in England and Scotland in the 16thand 17th centuries.
FORSLACK: To neglect by idleness; to delay or to waste by sloth. [Obs.]Spenser.
FONTANGE: A kind of tall headdress formerly worn. Addison.
FLOGGING: from Flog, v. t. Flogging chisel (Mach.), a large cold chisel,used in chipping castings.-- Flogging hammer, a small sledge hammer used for striking aflogging chisel.
FATHERLINESS: The qualities of a father; parantal kindness, care, etc.
FUNDHOLDER: One who has money invested in the public funds. J. S. Mill.
FATTEN: To grow fat or corpulent; to grow plump, thick, or fleshy; tobe pampered.And villains fatten with the brave man's labor. Otway.
FOOTCLOTH: Formerly, a housing or caparison for a horse. Sir W. Scott.
FRICACE: A ragout or fricassee of veal; a fancy dish of veal or of bonedturkey, served as an entrée, -- called also fricandel. A. J. Cooley.
FUSOME: Handy; reat; handsome; notable. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
FAINTS: The impure spirit which comes over first and last in thedistillation of whisky; -- the former being called the strong faints,and the latter, which is much more abundant, the weak faints. Thiscrude spirit is much impregnated with fusel oil. Ure.
FEZ: A felt or cloth cap, usually red and having a tassel, -- avariety of the tarboosh. See Tarboosh. B. Taylor.
FEATHERED: Having a fringe of feathers, as the legs of certian birds; orof hairs, as the legs of a setter dog.
FESTUCINE: Of a straw color; greenish yellow. [Obs.]A little insect of a festucine or pale green. Sir T. Browne.
FINICAL: Affectedly fine; overnice; unduly particular; fastidious."Finical taste." Wordsworth.The gross style consists in giving no detail, the finical in givingnothing else. Hazlitt.
FINABLE: Liable or subject to a fine; as, a finable person or offense.Bacon.
FASHION-MONGER: One who studies the fashions; a fop; a dandy. Marston.
FRISKET: The light frame which holds the sheet of paper to the tympan inprinting.
FIDDLEDEEDEE: An exclamatory word or phrase, equivalent to nonsense![Colloq.]
FLOSCULARIAN: One of a group of stalked rotifers, having ciliated tentaclesaround the lobed disk.
FIGURIAL: Represented by figure or delineation. [R.] Craig.
FITNESS: The state or quality of being fit; as, the fitness of measuresor laws; a person's fitness for office.
FLUNK: To fail, as on a lesson; to back out, as from an undertaking,through fear.
FLATTER: To use flattery or insincere praise.If it may stand him more in stead to lie, Say and unsay, feign,flatter, or adjure. Milton.
FLAME-COLORED: Of the color of flame; of a bright orange yellow color. Shak.
FANCY-FREE: Free from the power of love. "In maiden meditation, fancy-free." Shak.
FACTION: One of the divisions or parties of charioteers (distinguishedby their colors) in the games of the circus.
FOE: See Fiend, and cf. Feud a quarrel.
FULLONICAL: Pertaining to a fuller of cloth. [Obs.] Blount.
FISTICUFF: A cuff or blow with the fist or hand; (pl.)
FARLIE: An unusual or unexpected thing; a wonder. See Fearly. [Obs. orProv. Eng.] Drayton.
FALTERING: Hesitating; trembling. "With faltering speech." Milton.-- n.
FORMALDEHYDE: A colorless, volatile liquid, H2CO, resembling acetic or ethylaldehyde, and chemically intermediate between methyl alcohol andformic acid.
FOUNDRESS: A female founder; a woman who founds or establishes, or whoendows with a fund.
FIESTA: Among Spanish, a religious festival; a saint's day or holiday;also, a holiday or festivity.
FEW: Not many; small, limited, or confined in number; -- indicatinga small portion of units or individuals constituing a whole; often,by ellipsis of a noun, a few people. "Are not my days few" Job x. 20.Few know and fewer care. Proverb.
FIERI FACIAS: A judicial writ that lies for one who has recovered in debt ordamages, commanding the sheriff that he cause to be made of thegoods, chattels, or real estate of the defendant, the sum claimed.Blackstone. Cowell.
FAKE: One of the circles or windings of a cable or hawser, as it liesin a coil; a single turn or coil.
FERMENTATIVE: Causing, or having power to cause, fermentation; produced byfermentation; fermenting; as, a fermentative process.-- Fer*ment"a*tive*ly, adv.-- Fer*ment"a*tive*ness, n.
FACINGLY: In a facing manner or position.
FOPPISH: Foplike; characteristic of a top in dress or manners; making anostentatious display of gay clothing; affected in manners.
FRIGIDARIUM: The cooling room of the Roman thermæ, furnished with a coldbath.
FRUTESCENT: Somewhat shrubby in character; imperfectly shrubby, as theAmerican species of Wistaria.
FRISKAL: A leap or caper. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
FISHLIKE: Like fish; suggestive of fish; having some of the qualities offish.A very ancient and fishlike smell. Shak.
FELICITATE: Made very happy. [Archaic]I am alone felicitate In your dear highness' love. Shak.
FLORIATED: Having floral ornaments; as, floriated capitals of Gothicpillars.
FORCITE: A gelatin dynamite in which the dope is composed largely ofsodium nitrate.
FAVORITE: Short curls dangling over the temples; -- fashionable in thereign of Charles II. [Obs.] Farquhar.
FIRE-NEW: Fresh from the forge; bright; quite new; brand-new. Charlesreade.Your fire-new stamp of honor is scarce current. Shak.
FORDRIVE: To drive about; to drive here and there. [Obs.] Rom. of R.
FICKLE: Not fixed or firm; liable to change; unstable; of a changeablemind; not firm in opinion or purpose; inconstant; capricious; as,Fortune's fickle wheel. Shak.They know how fickle common lovers are. Dryden.
FLIP: A mixture of beer, spirit, etc., stirred and heated by a hotiron. Flip dog, an iron used, when heated, to warm flip.
FIMBRICATE: fringed, on one side only, by long, straight hairs, as theantennæ of certain insects.
FUSTILARIAN: A low fellow; a stinkard; a scoundrel. [Obs.] Shak.
FORALITE: A tubelike marking, occuring in sandstone and other strata.
FOOTHALT: A disease affecting the feet of sheep.
FRAUD: An intentional perversion of truth for the purpose of obtainingsome valuable thing or promise from another.
FOREWORN: Worn out; wasted; used up. [Archaic]Old foreworn stories almost forgotten. Brydges.
FATTY: Containing fat, or having the qualities of fat; greasy; gross;as, a fatty substance. Fatty acid (Chem.), any one of the paraffinseries of monocarbonic acids, as formic acid, acetic, etc.; -- socalled because the higher members, as stearic and palmitic acids,occur in the natural fats, and are themselves fatlike substances.-- Fatty clays. See under Clay.-- Fatty degeneration (Med.), a diseased condition, in which the oilglobules, naturally present in certain organs, are so multiplied asgradually to destroy and replace the efficient parts of these organs.-- Fatty heart, Fatty liver, etc. (Med.), a heart, liver, etc.,which have been the subjects of fatty degeneration or infiltration.-- Fatty infiltration (Med.), a condition in which there is anexcessive accumulation of fat in an organ, without destruction of anyessential parts of the latter.-- Fatty tumor (Med.), a tumor consisting of fatty or adiposetissue; lipoma.
FLOREN: A cerain gold coin; a Florence. [Obs.] Chaucer.
FASCINOUS: Caused or acting by witchcraft. [Obs.] "Fascinous diseases."Harvey.
FLOSSY: Pertaining to, made of, or resembling, floss; hence, light;downy.
FOREMAN: The first or chief man; as:(a) The chief man of a jury, who acts as their speaker.(b) The chief of a set of hands employed in a shop, or on works ofany kind, who superintends the rest; an overseer.
FRAME-UP: A conspiracy or plot, esp. for a malicious or evil purpose, asto incriminate a person on false evidence. [Slang]
FIGURE: A diagram or drawing; made to represent a magnitude or therelation of two or more magnitudes; a surface or space inclosed onall sides; -- called superficial when inclosed by lines, and solidwhen inclosed by surface; any arrangement made up of points, lines,angles, surfaces, etc.
FIGURANTE: A female figurant; esp., a ballet girl.
FURTHERMORE: or conj. Moreover; besides; in addition to what has been said.
FIEF: An estate held of a superior on condition of military service;a fee; a feud. See under Benefice, n., 2.
FUSTET: The wood of the Rhus Cptinus or Venice sumach, a shrub ofSouthern Europe, which yields a fine orange color, which, however, isnot durable without a mordant. Ure.
FOOT-SORE: Having sore or tender feet, as by reason of much walking; as,foot-sore cattle.
FU: A department in China comprising several hsein; also, the chiefcity of a department; -- often forming the last part of a name; as,Paoting-fu.
FODDER: A weight by which lead and some other metals were formerlysold, in England, varying from 19 [Obs.]
FLAGEOLET: A small wooden pipe, having six or more holes, and a mouthpieceinserted at one end. It produces a shrill sound, softer than of thepiccolo flute, and is said to have superseded the old recorder.Flageolet tones (Mus.), the naturel harmonics or overtones ofstringed instruments.
FOSSILIZED: Converted into a fossil; antiquated; firmly fixed in views oropinions.A fossilized sample of confused provincialism. Earle.
FRANKLINITE: A kind of mineral of the spinel group.
FOREBODE: To fortell; to presage; to augur.If I forebode aright. Hawthorne.
FILLED CHEESE: An inferior kind of cheese made from skim milk with a fatty"filling," such as oleomargarine or lard, to replace the fat removedin the cream.
FRANGULIN: A yellow crystalline dyestuff, regarded as a glucoside,extracted from a species (Rhamnus Frangula) of the buckthorn; --called also rhamnoxanthin.
FLUSTRATION: The act of flustrating; confusion; flurry. [Colloq.]Richardson.
FORMULE: A set or prescribed model; a formula. [Obs.] Johnson.
FRANGIBLE: Capable of being broken; brittle; fragile; easily broken.
FACTORESS: A factor who is a woman. [R.]
FRIGHTEN: To disturb with fear; to throw into a state of alarm or fright;to affright; to terrify.More frightened than hurt. Old Proverb.
FLEECY: Covered with, made of, or resembling, a fleece. "Fleecyflocks." Prior.
FOREFINGER: The finger next to the thumb; the index.
FIREPLACE: The part a chimney appropriated to the fire; a hearth; --usually an open recess in a wall, in which a fire may be built.
FLABELLATION: The act of keeping fractured limbs cool by the use of a fan orsome other contrivance. Dunglison.
FRUMENTY: Food made of hulled wheat boiled in milk, with sugar, plums,etc. [Written also furmenty and furmity.] Halliwell.
FEVERFEW: A perennial plant (Pyrethrum, or Chrysanthemum, Parthenium)allied to camomile, having finely divided leaves and white blossoms;-- so named from its supposed febrifugal qualities.
FISHHAWK: The osprey (Pandion haliaëtus), found both in Europe andAmerica; -- so called because it plunges into the water and seizesfishes in its talons. Called also fishing eagle, and bald buzzard.
FOREKNOWLEDGE: Knowledge of a thing before it happens, or of whatever is tohappen; prescience.If I foreknew, Foreknowledge had no influence on their fault. Milton.
FISSURAL: Pertaining to a fissure or fissures; as, the fissural patternof a brain.
FIRMNESS: The state or quality of being firm.
FRIAR: A brother or member of any religious order, but especially ofone of the four mendicant orders, viz: (a) Minors, Gray Friars, orFranciscans. (b) Augustines. (c) Dominicans or Black Friars. (d)White Friars or Carmelites. See these names in the Vocabulary.
FENESTRAL: Pertaining to a window or to windows.
FUMIGATOR: One who, or that which, fumigates; an apparattus forfumigating.
FLABBERGASTATION: The state of being flabbergasted. [Jocular] London Punch.
FORGETTER: One who forgets; a heedless person. Johnson.
FILAMENT: A thread or threadlike object or appendage; a fiber; esp.(Bot.), the threadlike part of the stamen supporting the anther.
FLUVIAL: Belonging to rivers; growing or living in streams or ponds; as,a fluvial plant.
FELICITATION: The act of felicitating; a wishing of joy or happiness;congratulation.
FIBRILLA: A minute thread of fiber, as one of the fibrous elements of amuscular fiber; a fibril.
FENCER: One who fences; one who teaches or practices the art of fencingwith sword or foil.As blunt as the fencer's foils. Shak.
FULCIMENT: A prop; a fulcrum. [Obs.] Bp. Wilkins.
FRIENDLY: In the manner of friends; amicably; like friends. [Obs.] Shak.In whom all graces that can perfect beauty Are friendly met. Beau. &Fl.
FAULTLESS: Without fault; not defective or imperfect; free from blemish;free from incorrectness, vice, or offense; perfect; as, a faultlesspoem.Whoever thinks a faultless piece to see, Thinks what ne'er was, noris, nor e'er shall be. Pope.
FATHERLAND: One's native land; the native land of one's fathers orancestors.
FOUTRA: A fig; -- a word of contempt. [Obs.]A foutra for the world and wordlings base! Shak.
