FULLING: The process of cleansing, shrinking, and thickening cloth bymoisture, heat, and pressure. Fulling mill, a mill for fulling clothas by means of pesties or stampers, which alternately fall into andrise from troughs where the cloth is placed with hot water andfuller's earth, or other cleansing materials.
FOLIAGE: To adorn with foliage or the imitation of foliage; to form intothe representation of leaves. [R.] Drummond.
FROWARD: Not willing to yield or compIy with what is required or isreasonable; perverse; disobedient; peevish; as, a froward child.A froward man soweth strife. Prov. xvi. 28.A froward retention of custom is as turbulent a thing as innovation.Bacon.
FECIAL: Pertaining to heralds, declarations of war, and treaties ofpeace; as, fecial law. Kent.
FRAGMENTAL: Consisting of the pulverized or fragmentary material of rock,as conglomerate, shale, etc.
FLUCTUANT: showing undulation or fluctuation; as, a fluctuant tumor.
FATHER-IN-LAW: The father of one's husband or wife; -- correlative to son-in-law and daughter-in-law.
FLINCH: To let the foot slip from a ball, when attempting to give atight croquet.
FURZE: A thorny evergreen shrub (Ulex Europæus), with beautiful yellowflowers, very common upon the plains and hills of Great Britain; --called also gorse, and whin. The dwarf furze is Ulex nanus.
FETLOCK: The cushionlike projection, bearing a tuft of long hair, on theback side of the leg above the hoof of the horse and similar animals.Also, the joint of the limb at this point (between the great pasternbone and the metacarpus), or the tuft of hair.Their wounded steeds Fret fetlock deep in gore. Shak.
FADDLE: To trifle; to toy.-- v. t.
FINLANDER: A native or inhabitant of Finland.
FEN: Low land overflowed, or covered wholly or partially with water,but producing sedge, coarse grasses, or other aquatic plants; boggyland; moor; marsh.'Mid reedy fens wide spread. Wordsworth.
FREENESS: The state or quality of being free; freedom; liberty; openness;liberality; gratuitousness.
FLAKY: Consisting of flakes or of small, loose masses; lying, orcleaving off, in flakes or layers; flakelike.What showers of mortal hail, what flaky fires! Watts.A flaky weight of winter's purest snows. Wordsworth.
FIVE: Four and one added; one more than four.
FERROCYANIC: Pertaining to, derived from, or designating, a ferrocyanide.ferrocyanic acid (Chem.), a white crystalline substance, H4(CN)6Fe,of strong acid properties, obtained from potassium ferrocyanide, andregarded as the type of the ferrocyanides; -- called also hydro-ferrocyanic acid, hydrogen ferrocyanide. etc.
FORESPENT: Already spent; gone by; past. [Obs.] Shak.
FALLACY: An argument, or apparent argument, which professes to bedecisive of the matter at issue, while in reality it is not; asophism.
FAVORER: One who favors; one who regards with kindness or friendship; awell-wisher; one who assists or promotes success or prosperity.[Written also favourer.]And come to us as favorers, not as foes. Shak.
FRIGIDLY: In a frigid manner; coldly; dully; without affection.
FORECONCEIVE: To preconceive; to imagine beforehand. [Obs.] Bacon.
FUCOID: A plant, whether recent or fossil, which resembles a seaweed.See Fucoid, a.
FRITTING: The formation of frit or slag by heat with but incipientfusion.
FORBID: To utter a prohibition; to prevent; to hinder. "I did not orforbid." Milton.
FLORESCENCE: A bursting into flower; a blossoming. Martyn.
FLOCCULAR: Of or pertaining to the flocculus.
FAT: Of a character which enables the compositor to make largewages; -- said of matter containing blank, cuts, or many leads, etc.;as, a fat take; a fat page. Fat lute, a mixture of pipe clay and oilfor filling joints.
FUCHS: A student of the first year.
FLOWING: That flows or for flowing (in various sense of the verb);gliding along smoothly; copious. Flowing battery (Elec.), a batterywhich is kept constant by the flowing of the exciting liquid throughthe cell or cells. Knight.-- Flowing furnace, a furnace from which molten metal, can be drawn,as through a tap hole; a foundry cupola.-- Flowing sheet (Naut.), a sheet when eased off, or loosened to thewind, as when the wind is abaft the beam. Totten.
FUNICLE: The little stalk that attaches a seed to the placenta.
FAWN-COLORED: Of the color of a fawn; light yellowish brown.
FLABELLINERVED: Having many nerves diverging radiately from the base; -- saidof a leaf.
FADAISE: A vapid or meaningless remark; a commonplace; nonsense.
FORNICATRESS: A woman guilty of fornication. Shak.
FIAR: One in whom the property of an estate is vested, subject to theestate of a life renter.I am fiar of the lands; she a life renter. Sir W. Scott.
FLYING FISH: A fish which is able to leap from the water, and fly aconsiderable distance by means of its large and long pectoral fins.These fishes belong to several species of the genus Exocoetus, andare found in the warmer parts of all the oceans.
FORMERET: One of the half ribs against the walls in a ceiling vaultedwith ribs.
FLYBLOWN: Tainted or contaminated with flyblows; damaged; foul.Wherever flyblown reputations were assembled. Thackeray.
FARO: A gambling game at cardds, in whiich all the other players playagainst the dealer or banker, staking their money upon the order inwhich the cards will lie and be dealt from the pack. Faro bank, thecapital which the proprietor of a farotable ventures in the game;also, the place where a game of faro is played. Hoyle.
FORTUNELESS: Luckless; also, destitute of a fortune or portion. Spenser.
FETICIDE: The act of killing the fetus in the womb; the offense ofprocuring an abortion.
FUNGIA: A genus of simple, stony corals; -- so called because they areusually flat and circular, with radiating plates, like the gills of amushroom. Some of them are eighteen inches in diameter.
FRANKLINIC: Of or pertaining to Benjamin Franklin. Franklinic electricity,electricity produced by friction; called also statical electricity.
FILAMENTARY: Having the character of, or formed by, a filament.
FIXTURE: Anything of an accessory character annexed to houses and lands,so as to constitute a part of them. This term is, however, quitefrequently used in the peculiar sense of personal chattels annexed tolands and tenements, but removable by the person annexing them, orhis personal representatives. In this latter sense, the same thingsmay be fixtures under some circumstances, and not fixtures underothers. Wharton (Law Dict. ). Bouvier.
FEERE: A consort, husband or wife; a companion; a fere. [Obs.]
FLUOBORATE: A salt of fluoboric acid; a fluoboride.
FRISIAN: Of or pertaining to Friesland, a province of the Netherlands;Friesic.
FERRO-CONCRETE: Concrete strengthened by a core or foundation skeleton of ironor steel bars, strips, etc. Floors, columns, piles, water pipes,etc., have been successfully made of it. Called also armored concretesteel, and reënforced concrete.
FLESHMENT: The act of fleshing, or the excitement attending a successfulbeginning. [R.] Shak.
FOXTAIL: The name of several kinds of grass having a soft dense head offlowers, mostly the species of Alopecurus and Setaria.
FLANCH: A bearing consisting of a segment of a circle encroaching onthe field from the side.
FAVUS: A disease of the scalp, produced by a vegetable parasite.
FLEWS: The pendulous or overhanging lateral parts of the upper lip ofdogs, especially prominent in hounds; -- called also chaps. SeeIllust. of Bloodhound.
FROSTLESS: Free from frost; as, a frostless winter.
FATISCENCE: A gaping or opening; state of being chinky, or havingapertures. Kirwan.
FORCELESS: Having little or no force; feeble.These forceless flowers like sturdy trees support me. Shak.
FLYMAN: The driver of a fly, or light public carriage.
FLAGGING: A pavement or sidewalk of flagstones; flagstones, collectively.
FORMULATION: The act, process, or result of formulating or reducing to aformula.
FATIDICAL: Having power to foretell future events; prophetic; fatiloquent;as, the fatidical oak. [R.] Howell.-- Fa*tid"i*cal*ly, adv.
FLUTE: A channel of curved section; -- usually applied to one of avertical series of such channels used to decorate columns andpilasters in classical architecture. See Illust. under Base, n.
FRAIL: A basket made of rushes, used chiefly for containing figs andraisins.
FILICOID: Fernlike, either in form or in the nature of the method ofreproduction.
FREE COINAGE: In the fullest sense, the conversion of bullion (of anyspecified metal) into legal-tender coins for any person who choosesto bring it to the mint; in a modified sense, such coinage when doneat a fixed charge proportionate to the cost of the operation.
FOOTMARK: A footprint; a track or vestige. Coleridge.
FASTENING: Anything that binds and makes fast, as a lock, catch, bolt,bar, buckle, etc.
FANGLE: Something new-fashioned; a foolish innovation; a gewgaw; atrifling ornament.
FORCEMENT: The act of forcing; compulsion. [Obs.]It was imposed upon us by constraint; And will you count suchforcement treachery J. Webster.
FORTHCOMING: Ready or about to appear; making appearance.
FORKY: Opening into two or more parts or shoots; forked; furcated."Forky tongues." Pope.
FACETIAE: Witty or humorous writings or saying; witticisms; merryconceits.
FLIGHTINESS: The state or quality of being flighty.The flightness of her temper. Hawthorne.
FEEBLE-MINDED: Weak in intellectual power; wanting firmness or constancy;irresolute; vacilating; imbecile. "comfort the feeble-minded." 1Thess. v. 14.-- Fee"ble-mind"ed*ness, n.
FOREMOSTLY: In the foremost place or order; among the foremost. J. Webster.
FONTANEL: An issue or artificial ulcer for the discharge of humors fromthe body.[Obs.] Wiseman.
FARINOSE: Civered with a sort of white, mealy powder, as the leaves ofsome poplars, and the body of certain insects; mealy.
FRECK: To checker; to diversify. [R. & Poet.]The painted windows, frecking gloom with glow. Lowell.
FRATERY: A frater house. See under Frater.
FATALISM: The doctrine that all things are subject to fate, or that theytake place by inevitable necessity.
FOREIGNER: A person belonging to or owning allegiance to a foreigncountry; one not native in the country or jurisdiction underconsideration, or not naturalized there; an alien; a stranger.Joy is such a foreigner, So mere a stranger to my thoughts. Denham.Nor could the majesty of the English crown appear in a greaterluster, either to foreigners or subjects. Swift.
FILAR: Of or pertaining to a thread or line; characterized by threadsstretched across the field of view; as, a filar microscope; a filarmicrometer.
FLAGGY: Abounding with the plant called flag; as, a flaggy marsh.
FEATHER-HEAD: A frivolous or featherbrained person. [Colloq.] H. James.
FUMAROLE: A hole or spot in a volcanic or other region, from which fumesissue.
FRONTED: Formed with a front; drawn up in line. "Fronted brigades."Milton.
FLY-BITTEN: Marked by, or as if by, the bite of flies. Shak.
FRANKISH: Like, or pertaining to, the Franks.
FINT: 3d pers. sing. pr. of Find, for findeth. [Obs.] Chaucer.
FORESHOT: In distillation of low wines, the first portion of spirit thatcomes over, being a fluid abounding in fusel oil. Knight.
FRAUDLESS: Free from fraud.-- Fraud"less*ly, adv.-- Fraud"less*ness, n.
FARRAND: Manner; custom; fashion; humor. [Prov. Eng.] [Written alsofarand.] Grose.
FREIHERR: In Germany and Austria, a baron.
FINISHED: Polished to the highest degree of excellence; complete;perfect; as, a finished poem; a finished education. Finished work(Mach.), work that is made smooth or polished, though not necessarilycompleted.
FLEURY: Finished at the ends with fleurs-de-lis; -- said esp. a crossso decorated.
FOLIOSITY: The ponderousness or bulk of a folio; voluminousness. [R.] DeQuincey.
FREE-SWIMMING: Swimming in the open sea; -- said of certain marine animals.
FLETE: To float; to swim. [Obs.] "Whether I sink or flete." Chaucer.
FEIGNING: That feigns; insincere; not genuine; false.-- Feign"ing*ly, adv.
FLARE-UP: A sudden burst of anger or passion; an angry dispute. [Colloq.]
FLAKE: A small stage hung over a vessel's side, for workmen to standon in calking, etc.
FUROIN: A colorless, crystalline substance, C10H8O4, from furfurol.
FLOE: A low, flat mass of floating ice. Floe rat (Zoöl.), a seal(Phoca foetida).
FOGBOW: A nebulous arch, or bow, of white or yellowish light sometimesseen in fog, etc.
FRUCTED: Bearing fruit; -- said of a tree or plant so represented uponan escutcheon. Cussans.
FUNGIBLES: Things which may be furnished or restored in kind, asdistinguished from specific things; -- called also fungible things.Burrill.
FUMING: Producing fumes, or vapors. Cadet's fuming liquid (Chem.),alkarsin.-- Fuming liquor of Libsvius (Old Chem.), stannic chloride; thechloride of tin, SnCl4, forming a colorless, mobile liquid whichfumes in the air. Mixed with water it solidifies to the so-calledbutter of tin.-- Fuming sulphuric acid. (Chem.) Same as Disulphuric acid, uderDisulphuric.
FLATTERING: That flatters (in the various senses of the verb); as, aflattering speech.Lay not that flattering unction to your soul. Shak.A flattering painter, who made it his care, To draw men as they oughtbe, not as they are. Goldsmith.
FORESIGNIFY: To signify beforehand; to foreshow; to typify. Milton.
FURTHERSOME: Tending to further, advance, or promote; helpful; advantageous.[R.]You will not find it furthersome. Carlyle.
FIRK: To beat; to strike; to chastise. [Obs.]I'll fer him, and firk him, and ferret him. Shak.
FORMULIZE: To reduce to a formula; to formulate. Emerson.
FISSIROSTRES: A group of birds having the bill deeply cleft.
FITZ: A son; -- used in compound names, to indicate paternity, esp.of the illegitimate sons of kings and princes of the blood; as,Fitzroy, the son of the king; Fitzclarence, the son of the duke ofClarence.
FUSTIC: The wood of the Maclura tinctoria, a tree growing in the WestIndies, used in dyeing yellow; -- called also old fustic. [Writtenalso fustoc.]
FYKE: A long bag net distended by hoops, into which fish can passeasily, without being able to return; -- called also fyke net.Cozzens.
FONDU: Blended; passing into each other by subtle gradations; -- saidof colors or of the surface or material on which the colors are laid.
FRAUNHOFER LINES: The lines of the spectrun; especially and properly, the darklines of the solar spectrum, so called because first accuratelyobserved and interpreted by Fraunhofer, a German physicist.
FEATHERSTITCH: A kind of embroidery stitch producing a branching zigzag line.
FAIRNESS: The state of being fair, or free form spots or stains, as ofthe skin; honesty, as of dealing; candor, as of an argument, etc.
FLOWN: p. p. of Fly; -- often used with the auxiliary verb to be; as,the birds are flown.
FREEHOLD: An estate in real property, of inheritance (in fee simple orfee tail) or for life; or the tenure by which such estate is held.Kent. Burrill. To abate into a freehold. See under Abate.
FEAGUE: To beat or whip; to drive. [Obs.] Otway.
FORGATHER: To convene; to gossip; to meet accidentally. [Scot.] Jamieson.Within that circle he forgathered with many a fool. Wilson.
FORELEADER: One who leads others by his example; aguide.
FOREGLEAM: An antecedent or premonitory gleam; a dawning light.The foregleams of wisdom. Whittier.
FALSIFY: To avoid or defeat; to prove false, as a judgment. Blackstone.
FOR-: A prefix to verbs, having usually the force of a negative orprivative. It often implies also loss, detriment, or destruction, andsometimes it is intensive, meaning utterly, quite thoroughly, as inforbathe.
FIFTEEN: Five and ten; one more than fourteen.
FORFERED: Excessively alarmed; in great fear. [Obs.] "Forfered of hisdeath." Chaucer.
FALCONGENTIL: The female or young of the goshawk (Astur palumbarius).
FAMILIAR: A confidential officer employed in the service of the tribunal,especially in apprehending and imprisoning the accused.
FEATURELY: Having features; showing marked peculiarities; handsome. [R.]Featurely warriors of Christian chivalry. Coleridge.
FANGED: Having fangs or tusks; as, a fanged adder. Also usedfiguratively.
FUDGE: A made-up story; stuff; nonsense; humbug; -- often anexclamation of contempt.
FIBROID: Resembling or forming fibrous tissue; made up of fibers; as,fibroid tumors.-- n.
FLIX: Down; fur. [Obs. or Eng.] J. Dyer.
FOREHOLD: The forward part of the hold of a ship.
FIRMER-CHISEL: A chisel, thin in proportion to its width. It has a tang toenter the handle instead of a socket for receiving it. Knight.
FORSAY: To forbid; to renounce; to forsake; to deny. [Obs.] Spenser.
FEINT: Feigned; counterfeit. [Obs.]Dressed up into any feint appearance of it. Locke.
FIRESIDE: A place near the fire or hearth; home; domestic life orretirement.
FOREMILK: The milk secreted just before, or directly after, the birth ofa child or of the young of an animal; colostrum.
FROW: A cleaving tool with handle at right angles to the blade, forsplitting cask staves and shingles from the block; a frower.
FUSIL: A light kind of flintlock musket, formerly in use.
FUGITIVENESS: The quality or condition of being fugitive; evanescence;volatility; fugacity; instability.
FELLOWLIKE: Like a companion; companionable; on equal terms; sympathetic.[Obs.] Udall.
FURTIVE: Stolen; obtained or characterized by stealth; sly; secret;stealthy; as, a furtive look. Prior.A hasty and furtive ceremony. Hallam.
FLOTANT: Represented as flying or streaming in the air; as, a bannerflotant.
FORETHOUGHT: Thought of, or planned, beforehand; aforethought; prepense;hence, deliberate. "Forethought malice." Bacon.
FALCER: One of the mandibles of a spider.
FUNERATION: The act of burying with funeral rites. [Obs.] Knatchbull.
FERRICYANATE: A salt of ferricyanic acid; a ferricyanide.
FABIAN: Of, pertaining to, or in the manner of, the Roman general,Quintus Fabius Maximus Verrucosus; cautious; dilatory; avoiding adecisive contest. Fabian policy, a policy like that of FabiusMaximus, who, by carefully avoiding decisive contests, foiledHannibal, harassing his army by marches, countermarches, andambuscades; a policy of delays and cautions.
FLETCH: To feather, as an arrow. Bp. Warburton.[Congress] fletched their complaint, by adding: "America loved hisbrother." Bancroft.
FOREMAST: The mast nearest the bow. Foremast hand or man (Naut.), acommon sailor; also, a man stationed to attend to the gear of theforemast.
FOREHAND: Done beforehand; anticipative.And so extenuate the forehand sin. Shak.
FOLLICULAR: Affecting the follicles; as, follicular pharyngitis.
FOREFEND: To hinder; to fend off; to avert; to prevent the approach of;to forbid or prohibit. See Forfend.God forefend it should ever be recorded in our history. Landor.It would be a far better work . . . to forefend the cruelty. I.Taylor.
FLAMBE: Decorated by glaze splashed or irregularly spread upon thesurface, or apparently applied at the top and allowed to run down thesides; -- said of pieces of Chinese porcelain.
FANION: A small flag sometimes carried at the head of the baggage of abrigade. [Obs.]
FLAGELLIFORM: Shaped like a whiplash; long, slender, round, flexible, and(comming) tapering.
FIBRINOPLASTIN: An albuminous substance, existing in the blood, which incombination with fibrinogen forms fibrin; -- called alsoparaglobulin.
FESTOONY: Pertaining to, consisting of, or resembling, festoons. Sir J.Herschel.
FEMININE RHYME: See Female rhyme, under Female, a.
FIGARY: A frolic; a vagary; a whim. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
FORDABLE: Capable of being forded.-- Ford"a*ble*ness, n.
FEE: A right to the use of a superior's land, as a stipend forservices to be performed; also, the land so held; a fief.
FLEX: To bend; as, to flex the arm.
FASHIONER: One who fashions, forms, ar gives shape to anything. [R.]The fashioner had accomplished his task, and the dresses were broughthome. Sir W. Scott.
FONDUS: A style of printing calico, paper hangings, etc., in which thecolors are in bands and graduated into each other. Ure.
FLOWEN: imp. pl. of Fly, v. i. Chaucer.
FRIGHT: To alarm suddenly; to shock by causing sudden fear; to terrify;to scare.Nor exile or danger can fright a brave spirit. Dryden.
FLATLY: In a flat manner; evenly; horizontally; without spirit; dully;frigidly; peremptori;y; positively, plainly. "He flatly refused hisaid." Sir P. Sidney.He that does the works of religion slowly, flatly, and withoutappetite. Jer. Taylor.
FASCIOLE: A band of minute tubercles, bearing modified spines, on theshells of spatangoid sea urchins. See Spatangoidea.
FLUVIATILE: Belonging to rivers or streams; existing in or about rivers;produced by river action; fluvial; as, fluviatile starta, plants.Lyell.
FORESHORTENING: Representation in a foreshortened mode or way.
FARFETCH: To bring from far; to seek out studiously. [Obs.]To farfetch the name of Tartar from a Hebrew word. Fuller.
FREE-MARTIN: An imperfect female calf, twinborn with a male.
FELWORT: A European herb (Swertia perennis) of the Gentian family.
FLIBUSTIER: A buccaneer; an American pirate. See Flibuster. [Obs.]
FUN: Sport; merriment; frolicsome amusement. "Oddity, frolic, andfun." Goldsmith. To make fan of, to hold up to, or turn into,ridicule.
FIGGUM: A juggler's trick; conjuring. [Obs.]The devil is the author of wicked figgum. B. Jonson.
FAR-ABOUT: A going out of the way; a digression. [Obs.] Fuller.
FRUCTUARY: One who enjoys the profits, income, or increase of anything.Kings are not proprietors nor fructuaries. Prynne.
FOB: A little pocket for a watch. Fob chain, a short watch chainworn a watch carried in the fob.
FOCUS: A point in which the rays of light meet, after being reflectedor refrcted, and at which the image is formed; as, the focus of alens or mirror.
FORBRUISE: To bruise sorely or exceedingly. [Obs.]All forbrosed, both back and side. Chaucer.
FACTIONARY: Belonging to a faction; being a partisan; taking sides. [Obs.]Always factionary on the party of your general. Shak.
FLUKE: One of the lobes of a whale's tail, so called from theresemblance to the fluke of an anchor.
FERGUSONITE: A mineral of a brownish black color, essentially a tantalo-niobate of yttrium, erbium, and cerium; -- so called after RobertFerguson.
FORMULATE: To reduce to, or express in, a formula; to put in a clear anddefinite form of statement or expression. G. P. Marsh.
FLORICULTURAL: Pertaining to the cultivation of flowering plants.
FEOFF: , v. t. [imp. & p. p. Feoffed; p. pr. & vb. n.. Feoffing.]Etym: [OE. feffen, OF. feffer, fieffer, F. fieffer, fr. fief fief;cf. LL. feoffare, fefare. See Fief.] (Law)
FERETORY: A portable bier or shrine, variously adorned, used forcontaining relics of saints. Mollett.
FONDLE: To treat or handle with tenderness or in a loving manner; tocaress; as, a nurse fondles a child.
FLATTEN: To lower the pitch of; to cause to sound less sharp; to letfall from the pitch. To flatten a sail (Naut.), to set it more nearlyfore-and-aft of the vessel.-- Flattening oven, in glass making, a heated chamber in which splitglass cylinders are flattened for window glass.
FLANEUR: One who strolls about aimlessly; a lounger; a loafer.
FLASH BOILER: A variety of water-tube boiler, used chiefly in steamautomobiles, consisting of a nest of strong tubes with very littlewater space, kept nearly red hot so that the water as it tricklesdrop by drop into the tubes is immediately flashed into steam andsuperheated.
FORERIGHT: Ready; directly forward; going before. [Obs.] "A forerightwind." Chapman.
FISC: A public or state treasury. Burke.
FRISK: Lively; brisk; frolicsome; frisky. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
FABLIAU: One of the metrical tales of the Trouvères, or early poets ofthe north of France.
FIRST-CLASS: Of the best class; of the highest rank; in the first division;of the best quality; first-rate; as, a first-class telescope. First-class car or First-class railway carriage, any passenger car of thehighest regular class, and intended for passengers who pay thehighest regular rate; -- distinguished from a second-class car.
FATHER-LASHER: A European marine fish (Cottus bubalis), allied to the sculpin;-- called also lucky proach.
FAMILIARY: Of or pertaining to a family or household; domestic. [Obs.]Milton.
FORESHORTEN: To represent on a plane surface, as if extended in a directiontoward the spectator or nearly so; to shorten by drawing inperspective.
FARMERY: The buildings and yards necessary for the business of a farm; ahomestead. [Eng.]
FOOLIFY: To make a fool of; to befool. [R.] Holland.
FOREREACH: To advance or gain upon; -- said of a vessel that gains uponanother when sailing closehauled.
FLASHBOARD: A board placed temporarily upon a milldam, to raise the waterin the pond above its usual level; a flushboard. [U.S.]
FIRING PIN: In the breech mechanism of a firearm, the pin which strikes thehead of the cartridge and explodes it.
FRANC: A silver coin of France, and since 1795 the unit of the Frenchmonetary system. It has been adopted by Belgium and Swizerland. It isequivalent to about nineteen cents, or ten pence, and is divided into100 centimes.
FARFET: Farfetched. [Obs.]York with his farfet policy. Shak.
FOOTBOY: A page; an attendant in livery; a lackey. Shak.
FULGURATING: Resembling lightning; -- used to describe intense lancinatingpainsaccompanying locomotor ataxy.
FERMETURE: The mechanism for closing the breech of a breech-loadingfirearm, in artillery consisting principally of the breechblock,obturator, and carrier ring.
FORMULIZATION: The act or process of reducing to a formula; the state of beingformulized.
FRIPPER: One who deals in frippery or in old clothes. [Obs.] Bacon.
FEUD: A stipendiary estate in land, held of superior, by service; theright which a vassal or tenant had to the lands or other immovablething of his lord, to use the same and take the profists thereofhereditarily, rendering to his superior such duties and services asbelong to military tenure, etc., the property of the soil alwaysremaining in the lord or superior; a fief; a fee.
FULGURATION: The sudden brightening of a fused globule of gold or silver,when the last film of the oxide of lead or copper leaves its surface;-- also called blick.A phenomenon called, by the old chemists, fulguration. Ure.
FATIGATE: Wearied; tired; fatigued. [Obs.]Requickened what in flesh was fatigate. Shak.
FLORID: Flowery; ornamental; running in rapid melodic figures,divisions, or passages, as in variations; full of fioriture or littleornamentations.
FLUME: A stream; especially, a passage channel, or conduit for thewater that drives a mill wheel; or an artifical channel of water forhydraulic or placer mining; also, a chute for conveying logs orlumber down a declivity.
FANFARE: A flourish of trumpets, as in coming into the lists, etc.;also, a short and lively air performed on hunting horns during thechase.The fanfare announcing the arrival of the various Christian princes.Sir W. Scott.
FERMENTATION THEORY: The theory which likens the course of certain diseases (esp.infectious diseases) to the process of fermentation, and attributesthem to the organized ferments in the body. It does not differmaterially from the accepted germ theory (which see).
FOREL: A kind of parchment for book covers. See Forrill.
FURLONG: A measure of length; the eighth part of a mile; forty rods; twohundred and twenty yards.
FALSE: Not in tune. False arch (Arch.), a member having the appearanceof an arch, though not of arch construction.-- False attic, an architectural erection above the main cornice,concealing a roof, but not having windows or inclosing rooms.-- False bearing, any bearing which is not directly upon a verticalsupport; thus, the weight carried by a corbel has a false bearing.-- False cadence, an imperfect or interrupted cadence.-- False conception (Med.), an abnormal conception in which a mole,or misshapen fleshy mass, is produced instead of a properly organizedfetus.-- False croup (Med.), a spasmodic affection of the larynx attendedwith the symptoms of membranous croup, but unassociated with thedeposit of a fibrinous membrane.-- False door or window (Arch.), the representation of a door orwindow, inserted to complete a series of doors or windows or to givesymmetry.-- False fire, a combustible carried by vessels of war, chiefly forsignaling, but sometimes burned for the purpose of deceiving anenemy; also, a light on shore for decoying a vessel to destruction.-- False galena. See Blende.-- False imprisonment (Law), the arrest and imprisonment of a personwithout warrant or cause, or contrary to law; or the unlawfuldetaining of a person in custody.-- False keel (Naut.), the timber below the main keel, used to serveboth as a protection and to increase the shio's lateral resistance.-- False key, a picklock.-- False leg. (Zoöl.) See Proleg.-- False membrane (Med.), the fibrinous deposit formed in croup anddiphtheria, and resembling in appearance an animal membrane.-- False papers (Naut.), documents carried by a ship giving falserepresentations respecting her cargo, destination, ect., for thepurpose of deceiving.-- False passage (Surg.), an unnatural passage leading off from anatural canal, such as the urethra, and produced usually by theunskillful introduction of instruments.-- False personation (Law), the intentional false assumption of thename and personality of another.-- False pretenses (Law), false representations concerning past orpresent facts and events, for the purpose of defrauding another.-- False rail (Naut.), a thin piece of timber placed on top of thehead rail to strengthen it.-- False relation (Mus.), a progression in harmony, in which acertain note in a chord appears in the next chord prefixed by a flator sharp.-- False return (Law), an untrue return made to a process by theofficer to whom it was delivered for execution.-- False ribs (Anat.), the asternal rebs, of which there are fivepairs in man.-- False roof (Arch.), the space between the upper ceiling and theroof. Oxford Gloss.-- False token, a false mark or other symbol, used for fraudulentpurposes.-- False scorpion (Zoöl.), any arachnid of the genus Chelifer. SeeBook scorpion.-- False tack (Naut.), a coming up into the wind and filling awayagain on the same tack.-- False vampire (Zoöl.), the Vampyrus spectrum of South America,formerly erroneously supposed to have blood-sucking habits; -- calledalso vampire, and ghost vampire. The genuine blood-sucking batsbelong to the genera Desmodus and Diphylla. See Vampire.-- False window. (Arch.) See False door, above.-- False wing. (Zoöl.) See Alula, and Bastard wing, under Bastard.-- False works (Civil Engin.), construction works to facilitate theerection of the main work, as scaffolding, bridge centering, etc.
FROUFROU: A rustling, esp. the rustling of a woman's dress.
FELSITE: A finegrained rock, flintlike in fracture, consistingessentially of orthoclase feldspar with occasional grains of quartz.
FERULACEOUS: Pertaining to reeds and canes; having a stalk like a reed; as,ferulaceous plants.
FOGGER: One who fogs; a pettifogger. [Obs.]A beggarly fogger. Terence in English(1614)
FOOLSCAP: A writing paper made in sheets, ordinarily 16 x 13 inches, andfolded so as to make a page 13 x 8 inches. See Paper.
FOP-DOODLE: A stupid or insignaficant fellow; a fool; a simpleton. [R.]Hudibras.
FORLAY: To lie in wait for; to ambush.An ambushed thief forlays a traveler. Dryden.
FOREREAD: To tell beforehand; to signify by tokens; to predestine. [Obs.]Spenser.
FUGH: An exclamation of disgust; foh; faugh. Dryden.
FORSWAT: Spent with heat; covered with sweat. [Obs.] P. Sidney.
FAR-OFF: Remote; as, the far-off distance. Cf. Far-off, under Far, adv.
FLOCK: To gather in companies or crowds.Friends daily flock. Dryden.Flocking fowl (Zoöl.), the greater scaup duck.
FACTURE: An invoice or bill of parcels.
FORESPURRER: One who rides before; a harbinger. [Obs.] Shak.
FORCEMEAT: Meat chopped fine and highly seasoned, either served up alone,or used as a stuffing. [Written also forced meat.]
FIRMAMENTAL: Pertaining to the firmament; celestial; being of the upperregions. Dryden.
FELONRY: A body of felons; specifically, the convict population of apenal colony. Howitt.
FULIGINOSITY: The condition or quality of being fuliginous; sootiness; matterdeposited by smoke. [R.]
FODIENTIA: A group of African edentates including the aard-vark.
FORMIC: Pertaining to, or derived from, ants; as, formic acid; in anextended sense, pertaining to, or derived from, formic acid; as,formic ether. Amido formic acid, carbamic acid.-- Formic acid, a colorless, mobile liquid, HCO.OH, of a sharp, acidtaste, occurring naturally in ants, nettles, pine needles, etc., andproduced artifically in many ways, as by the oxidation of methylalcohol, by the reduction of carbonic acid or the destructivedistillation of oxalic acid. It is the first member of the fattyacids in the paraffin series, and is homologous with acetic acid.
FLUORESCENCE: That property which some transparent bodies have of producingat their surface, or within their substance, light different in colorfrom the mass of the material, as when green crystals of fluor sparafford blue reflections. It is due not to the difference in the colorof a distinct surface layer, but to the power which the substance hasof modifying the light incident upon it. The light emitted byfluorescent substances is in general of lower refrangibility than theincident light. Stockes.
FORPASS: To pass by or along; to pass over. [Obs.] Spenser.
FISSILE: Capable of being split, cleft, or divided in the direction ofthe grain, like wood, or along natural planes of cleavage, likecrystals.This crystal is a pellucid, fissile stone. Sir I. Newton.
FORMALISM: The practice or the doctrine of strict adherence to, ordependence on, external forms, esp. in matters of religion.Official formalism. Sir H. Rawlinson.
FOOTSTALL: The plinth or base of a pillar.
FESTI-VAL: A time of feasting or celebration; an anniversary day of joy,civil or religious.The morning trumpets festival proclaimed. Milton.
FISSIPALMATE: Semipalmate and loboped, as a grebe's foot. See Illust. underAves.
FORTHINK: To repent; to regret; to be sorry for; to cause regret. [Obs.]"Let it forthink you." Tyndale.That me forthinketh, quod this January. Chaucer.
FANCIED: Formed or conceived by the fancy; unreal; as, a fancied wrong.
FAUGH: An exclamation of contempt, disgust, or abhorrence.
FELICIFY: To make happy; to felicitate. [Obs.] Quarles.
FIMBRIATED: Having a very narrow border of another tincture; -- said esp.of an ordinary or subordinary.
FILCH: To steal or take privily (commonly, that which is of littlevalue); to pilfer.Fain would they filch that little food away. Dryden.But he that filches from me my good name, Robs me of that which notenriches him, And makes me poor indeed. Shak.
FEMALIZE: To make, or to describe as, female or feminine. Shaftesbury.
FACULAR: Of or pertaining to the faculæ. R. A. Proctor.
FLUORINE: A non-metallic, gaseous element, strongly acid or negative, orassociated with chlorine, bromine, and iodine, in the halogen groupof which it is the first member. It always occurs combined, is veryactive chemically, and possesses such an avidity for most elements,and silicon especially, that it can neither be prepared nor kept inglass vessels. If set free it immediately attacks the containingmaterial, so that it was not isolated until 1886. It is a pungent,corrosive, colorless gas. Symbol F. Atomic weight 19.
FIRMS: The principal rafters of a roof, especially a pair of rafterstaken together. [Obs.]
FLESHLINESS: The state of being fleshly; carnal passions and appetites.Spenser.
FITWEED: A plant (Eryngium foetidum) supposed to be a remedy for fits.
FIRECREST: A small European kinglet (Regulus ignicapillus), having abright red crest; -- called also fire-crested wren.
FIRTH: An arm of the sea; a frith.
FLOCCULUS: A small lobe in the under surface of the cerebellum, near themiddle peduncle; the subpeduncular lobe.
FUMINGLY: In a fuming manner; angrily. "They answer fumingly." Hooker.
FUNGIC: Pertaining to, or obtained from, mushrooms; as, fungic acid.
FLEMISH: Pertaining to Flanders, or the Flemings.-- n.
FEELER: One of the sense organs or certain animals (as insects), whichare used in testing objects by touch and in searching for food; anantenna; a palp.Insects . . . perpetually feeling and searching before them withtheir feelers or antennæ. Derham.
FAVELLA: A group of spores arranged without order and covered with athin gelatinous envelope, as in certain delicate red algæ.
FORMIDABLE: Exciting fear or apprehension; impressing dread; adapted toexcite fear and deter from approach, encounter, or undertaking;alarming.They seemed to fear the formodable sight. Dryden.I swell my preface into a volume, and make it formidable, when yousee so many pages behind. Drydn.
FREE: Certain or honorable; the opposite of base; as, free service;free socage. Burrill.
FISHINESS: The state or quality of being fishy or fishlike. Pennant.
FUMARINE: An alkaloid extracted from fumitory, as a white crystallinesubstance.
FULL-GROWN: Having reached the limits of growth; mature. "Full-grownwings." Lowell.
FELLY: , adv. In a fell or cruel manner; fiercely; barbarously;savagely. Spenser.
FOUNDER: One who founds, establishes, and erects; one who lays afoundation; an author; one from whom anything originates; one whoendows.
FRANK-MARRIAGE: A certain tenure in tail special; an estate of inheritancegiven to a man his wife (the wife being of the blood of the donor),and descendible to the heirs of their two bodies begotten. [Obs.]Blackstone.
FRENZIED: Affected with frenzy; frantic; maddened.-- Fren"zied-ly, adv.The people frenzied by centuries of oppression. Buckle.Up starting with a frenzied look. Sir W Scott.
FURFURAN: A colorless, oily substance, C4H4O, obtained by distillingcertain organic substances, as pine wood, salts of pyromucic acid,etc.; -- called also tetraphenol.
FIXEDLY: In a fixed, stable, or constant manner.
FACTOTUM: A person employed to do all kinds of work or business. B.Jonson.
FEITSUI: The Chinese name for a highly prized variety of pale greenjade. See Jade.
FUELER: One who, or that which, supplies fuel. [R.] [Written alsofueller.] Donne.
FLOORING: A platform; the bottom of a room; a floor; pavement. See Floor,n. Addison.
FULLNESS: The state of being full, or of abounding; abundance;completeness. [Written also fulness.]"In thy presence is fullness of joy." Ps. xvi. 11.
FLUVIALIST: One who exlpains geological phenomena by the action of streams.[R.]
FLUVIO-MARINE: Formed by the joint action of a river and the sea, as depositsat the mouths of rivers.
FYLLOT: A rebated cross, formerly used as a secret emblem, and a commonornament. It is also called gammadion, and swastika.
FOOL-HAPPY: Lucky, without judgment or contrivance. [Obs.] Spenser.
FINCHBACKED: Streaked or spotted on the back; -- said of cattle.
FETID: Having an offensive smell; stinking.Most putrefactions . . . smell either fetid or moldy. Bacon.
FLAGMAN: One who makes signals with a flag.
FNESE: To breathe heavily; to snort. [Obs.] Chaucer.
FAVOSITE: Like or pertaining to the genus Favosites.
FENERATE: To put money to usury; to lend on interest. [Obs.] Cockeram.
FRILLED: Furnished with a frill or frills. Frilled lizard (Zoöl.), alarge Australian lizard (Chlamydosaurus Kingii) about three feetlong, which has a large, erectile frill on each side of the neck.
FOREQUOTED: Cited before; quoted in a foregoing part of the treatise oressay.
FLUNLYISM: The quality or characteristics of a flunky; readiness to cringeto those who are superior in wealth or position; toadyism. Thackeray.
FLINTWARE: A superior kind of earthenware into whose composition flintenters largely. Knight.
FAIENCE: Glazed earthenware; esp., that which is decorated in color.
FAVONIAN: Pertaining to the west wind; soft; mild; gentle.
FIFTH: The interval of three tones and a semitone, embracing fivediatonic degrees of the scale; the dominant of any key.
FATTINESS: State or quality of being fatty.
FERULIC: Pertaining to, or derived from, asafetida (Ferula asafoetida);as, ferulic acid. [Written also ferulaic.]
FOOT: The terminal part of the leg of man or an animal; esp., thepart below the ankle or wrist; that part of an animal upon which itrests when standing, or moves. See Manus, and Pes.
FORBIDDING: Repelling approach; repulsive; raising abhorrence, aversion, ordislike; disagreeable; prohibiting or interdicting; as, a forbiddingaspect; a forbidding formality; a forbidding air.
FAULE: A fall or falling band. [Obs.]These laces, ribbons, and these faules. Herrick.
FIGWORT: A genus of herbaceous plants (Scrophularia), mostly found inthe north temperate zones. See Brownwort.
FORD: To pass or cross, as a river or other water, by wading; to wadethrough.His last section, which is no deep one, remains only to be forted.Milton.
FARMHOUSE: A dwelling house on a farm; a farmer's residence.
FURCULUM: The wishbone or merrythought of birds, formed by the unitedclavicles.
FELLOWFEEL: To share through sympathy; to participate in. [R.] D. Rodgers.
FENOWED: Corrupted; decayed; moldy. See Vinnewed. [Obs.] Dr. Favour.
FALX: A curved fold or process of the dura mater or the peritoneum;esp., one of the partitionlike folds of the dura mater which extendinto the great fissures of the brain.
FISCAL: Pertaining to the public treasury or revenue.The fiscal arreangements of government. A. Hamilton.
FRACID: Rotten from being too ripe; overripe. [Obs.] Blount.
FASHIONED: Having a certain style or fashion; as old-fashioned; new-fashioned.
FLATLONG: ; 115), adv. With the flat side downward; not edgewise. Shak.
FOREHEARTH: The forward extension of the hearth of a blast furnace underthe tymp.
FAHLBAND: A stratum in crystalline rock, containing metallic sulphides.Raymond.
FLUIDAL: Pertaining to a fluid, or to its flowing motion. Fluidalstructure (Geol.), the structure characteristic of certain volcanicrocks in which the arrangement of the minute crystals shows the linesof flow of thew molten material before solidification; -- also calledfluxion structure.
FERULE: A flat piece of wood, used for striking, children, esp. on thehand, in punishment.
FIRM: The name, title, or style, under which a company transactsbusiness; a partnership of two or more persons; a commercial house;as, the firm of Hope & Co.
FASTISH: Rather fast; also, somewhat dissipated. [Colloq.] Thackeray.
FLASK: The wooden or iron frame which holds the sand, etc., formingthe mold used in a foundry; it consists of two or more parts; viz.,the cope or top; sometimes, the cheeks, or middle part; and the drag,or bottom part. When there are one or more cheeks, the flask iscalled a three part flask, four part flask, etc. Erlenmeyer flask, athin glass flask, flat-bottomed and cone-shaped to allow of safelyshaking its contents laterally without danger of spilling; -- socalled from Erlenmeyer, a German chemist who invented it.-- Florence flask. Etym: [From Florence in Italy.] (a) Same asBetty, n., 3. (b) A glass flask, round or pear-shaped, with round orflat bottom, and usually very thin to allow of heating solutions.-- Pocket flask, a kind of pocket dram bottle, often covered withmetal or leather to protect it from breaking.
FANEGA: A dry measure in Spain and Spanish America, varying from 1 DeColange.
FEUTER: To set close; to fix in rest, as a spear. Spenser.
FORESHOW: To show or exhibit beforehand; to give foreknowledge of; toprognosticate; to foretell.Your looks foreshow You have a gentle heart. Shak.Next, like Aurora, Spenser rose, Whose purple blush the dayforeshows. Denham.
FARCTATE: Stuffed; filled solid; as, a farctate leaf, stem, or pericarp;-- opposed to tubular or hollow. [Obs.]
FORNICATOR: An unmarried person, male or female, who has criminalintercourse with the other sex; one guilty of fornication.
FILTRATE: To filter; to defecate; as liquid, by straining or percolation.Arbuthnot.
FAULD: The arch over the dam of a blast furnace; the tymp arch.
FIFTHLY: In the fifth place; as the fifth in order.
FLUIDRACHM: See Fluid dram, under Fluid. Pharm. of the U. S.
FURZY: bounding in, or overgrown with, furze; characterized by furze.Gay.
FETIS: Neat; pretty; well made; graceful. [Obs.]Full fetis was her cloak, as I was ware. Chaucer.
FANLIKE: Resembling a fan; -- specifically (Bot.), folded up like a fan,as certain leaves; plicate.
FLEECER: One who fleeces or strips unjustly, especially by trickery orfraund. Prynne.
FREE-HEARTED: Open; frank; unreserved; liberal; generous; as, free-heartedmirth.-- Free"-heart`ed*ly, adv.-- Free"-heart`ed*ness, n.
FUMATORIUM: An air-tight compartment in which vapor may be generated todestroy germs or insects; esp., the apparatus used to destroy SanJosé scale on nursery stock, with hydrocyanic acid vapor.
FOISTER: One who foists something surreptitiously; a falsitier. Mir. forMag.
FORBIDDEN: Prohibited; interdicted.I kniw no spells, use no forbidden arts. Milton.Forbidden fruit. (a) Any coveted unlawful pleasure, -- so called withreference to the forbidden fruit of the Garden of Eden. (b) (Bot.) Asmall variety of shaddock (Citrus decumana). The name is given indifferent places to several varieties of Citrus fruits.
FRESCADE: A cool walk; shady place. [R.] Maunder.
FIDICINAL: Of or pertaining to a stringed instrument.
FELSITIC: relating to, composed of, or containing, felsite.
FELLOWSHIP: (Eccl.) To acknowledge as of good standing, or in communionaccording to standards of faith and practice; to admit to Christianfellowship.
FERE: A mate or companion; -- often used of a wife. [Obs.] [Writtenalso fear and feere.] Chaucer.And Cambel took Cambrina to his fere. Spenser.In fere, together; in company. [Obs.] Chaucer.
FUCUSOL: An oily liquid, resembling, and possibly identical with,furfurol, and obtained from fucus, and other seaweeds.
FLABILE: Liable to be blown about. Bailey.
FUGLEMAN: A soldier especially expert and well drilled, who takes hisplace in front of a military company, as a guide for the others intheir exercises; a file leader. He originally stood in front of theright wing. [Written also flugelman.]
FUSCOUS: Brown or grayish black; darkish.Sad and fuscous colors, as black or brown, or deep purple and thelike. Burke.
FRIST: To sell upon credit, as goods. [R.] Crabb.
FARTHINGALE: A hoop skirt or hoop petticoat, or other light, elasticmaterial, used to extend the petticoat.We'll revel it as bravely as the best, . . . With ruffs and cuffs,and farthingales and things. Shak.
FAGOTTO: The bassoon; -- so called from being divided into parts forease of carriage, making, as it were, a small fagot.
FORE: Journey; way; method of proceeding. [Obs.] "Follow him and hisfore." Chaucer.
FLENSE: To strip the blubber or skin from, as from a whale, seal, etc.the flensed carcass of a fur seal. U. S. Census (1880).
FILLY: A female foal or colt; a young mare. Cf. Colt, Foal.Neighing in likeness of a filly foal. Shak.
FORERUNNER: A piece of rag terminating the log line.
FANCILESS: Having no fancy; without ideas or imagination. [R.]A pert or bluff important wight, Whose brain is fanciless, whoseblood is white. Armstrong.
FLUCTUATION: The motion or undulation of a fluid collected in a natural orartifical cavity, which is felt when it is subjected to pressure orpercussion. Dunglison.
FASTENER: One who, or that which, makes fast or firm.
FIGPECKER: The European garden warbler (Sylvia, or Currica, hortensis); --called also beccafico and greater pettychaps.
FOIST: A light and fast-sailing ship. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
FANTOM: See Phantom. Fantom corn, phantom corn. Grose.
FILANDER: A species of kangaroo (Macropus Brunii), inhabiting New Guinea.
FAIRYLAND: The imaginary land or abode of fairies.
FLORENTINE: Belonging or relating to Florence, in Italy. Florentine mosaic,a mosaic of hard or semiprecious stones, often so chosen and arrangedthat their natural colors represent leaves, flowers, and the like,inlaid in a background, usually of black or white marble.
FUTURITIAL: Relating to what is to come; pertaining to futurity; future.[R.]
FIELDING: The act of playing as a fielder.
FOREBODING: Presage of coming ill; expectation of misfortune.
FORMERLY: In time past, either in time immediately preceding or at anyindefinite distance; of old; heretofore.
FORTY: Four times ten; thirtynine and one more.
FEATHER: A longitudinal strip projecting as a fin from an object, tostrengthen it, or to enter a channel in another object and therebyprevent displacement sidwise but permit motion lengthwise; a spline.
FATHERSHIP: The state of being a father; fatherhood; paternity.
FIGURIST: One who uses or interprets figurative expressions. Waterland.
FICTION: An assumption of a possible thing as a fact, irrespective ofthe question of its truth. Wharton.
FENG-HWANG: A pheasantlike bird of rich plumage and graceful form andmovement, fabled to appear in the land on the accession of a sage tothe throne, or when right principles are about to prevail. It isoften represented on porcelains and other works of art.
FERACITY: The state of being feracious or fruitful. [Obs.] Beattie.
FURNISHER: One who supplies or fits out.
FLABELLUM: A fan; especially, the fan carried before the pope on stateoccasions, made in ostrich and peacock feathers. Shipley.
FLOAT: A contrivance for affording a copious stream of water to theheated surface of an object of large bulk, as an anvil or die.Knight.
FUGATO: in the gugue style, but not strictly like a fugue.-- n.
FAN-NERVED: Having the nerves or veins arranged in a radiating manner; --said of certain leaves, and of the winfs of some insects.
FORBEARING: Disposed or accustomed to forbear; patient; long-suffering.-- For*bear"ing*ly, adv.
FILACER: A former officer in the English Court of Common Pleas; -- socalled because he filed the writs on which he made out process.[Obs.] Burrill.
FLOORHEADS: The upper extermities of the floor of a vessel.
FOWL: To catch or kill wild fowl, for game or food, as by shooting,or by decoys, nets, etc.Such persons as may lawfully hunt, fish, or fowl. Blackstone.Fowling piece, a light gun with smooth bore, adapted for the use ofsmall shot in killing birds or small quadrupeds.
FRAGMENTARY: Composed of the fragments of other rocks.
FORTISSIMO: Very loud; with the utmost strength or loudness.
FLUTY: Soft and clear in tone, like a flute.
FAITH: By my faith; in truth; verily.
FRACTED: Having a part displaced, as if broken; -- said of an ordinary.Macaulay.
FLOOR: That part of the bottom of a vessel on each side of the keelsonwhich is most nearly horizontal.
FRUGIFEROUS: Producing fruit; fruitful; fructiferous. Dr. H. More.
FLABBERGAST: To astonish; to strike with wonder, esp. by extraordinarystatements. [Jocular] Beaconsfield.
FRETWORK: Work adorned with frets; ornamental openwork or work in relief,esp. when elaborate and minute in its parts. Heuce, any minute playof light andshade, dark and light, or the like.Banqueting on the turf in the fretwork of shade and sunshine.Macaulay.
FELLOW-COMMONER: A student at Cambridge University, England, who commons, ordines, at the Fellow's table.
FOSTER: To be nourished or trained up together. [Obs.] Spenser.
FLOCCULATION: The process by which small particles of fine soils andsediments aggregate into larger lumps.
FORKINESS: The quality or state or dividing in a forklike manner.
FILOPLUME: A hairlike feather; a father with a slender scape and without aweb in most or all of its length.
FALLOW: Left untilled or unsowed after plowing; uncultivated; as,fallow ground. Fallow chat, Fallow finch (Zoöl.), a small Europeanbird, the wheatear (Saxicola ænanthe). See Wheatear.
FORFICATE: Deeply forked, as the tail of certain birds.
FORAGE: To wander or rove in search of food; to collect food, esp.forage, for horses and cattle by feeding on or stripping the country;to ravage; to feed on spoil.His most mighty father on a hill Stood smiling to behold his lion'swhelp Forage in blood of French nobility. Shak.Foraging ant (Zoöl.), one of several species of ants of the genusEciton, very abundant in tropical America, remarkable for marching invast armies in search of food.-- Foraging cap, a forage cap.-- Foraging party, a party sent out after forage.
FERRUGO: A disease of plants caused by fungi, commonly called the rust,from its resemblance to iron rust in color.
FEOFFMENT: One who enfeoffs or grants a fee.
FORENENST: Over against; opposite to. [Now dialectic]The land forenenst the Greekish shore. Fairfax.
FITTER: A little piece; a flitter; a flinder. [Obs.]Where's the Frenchman Alas, he's all fitters. Beau. & Fl.
FREEDMAN: A man who has been a slave, and has been set free.
FEUDIST: A writer on feuds; a person versed in feudal law. Spelman.
FATHERLESSNESS: The state of being without a father.
FICTIVE: Feigned; counterfeit. "The fount of fictive tears." Tennyson.
FUSCINE: A dark-colored substance obtained from empyreumatic animal oil.[R.]
FIGHTWITE: A mulct or fine imposed on a person for making a fight orquarrel to the disturbance of the peace.
FLOWER STATE: Florida; -- a nickname, alluding to sense of L. floridus,from florida flowery. See Florid.
FIBROMA: A tumor consisting mainly of fibrous tissue, or of samemodification of such tissue.
FRIZETTE: A curl of hair or silk; a pad of frizzed hair or silk worn bywomen under the hair to stuff it out.
FOREHOOK: A piece of timber placed across the stem, to unite the bows andstrengthen the fore part of the ship; a breast hook.
FIDALGO: The lowest title of nobility in Portugal, corresponding to thatof Hidalgo in Spain.
FOUR-IN-HAND: Consisting of four horses controlled by one person; as, a four-in-hand team; drawn by four horses driven by one person; as, a four-in-hand coach.-- n.
FURILIC: Pertaining to, or derived from, furile; as, furilic acid.
FRUTICOSE: Pertaining to a shrub or shrubs; branching like a shrub;shrubby; shrublike; as, a fruticose stem. Gray.
FLUEWORK: A general name for organ stops in which the sound is caused bywind passing through a flue or fissure and striking an edge above; --in distinction from reedwork.
FRAGMENT: A part broken off; a small, detached portion; an imperfectpart; as, a fragment of an ancient writing.Gather up the fragments that remain. John vi. 12.
FEATHER-EDGE: The thin, new growth around the edge of a shell, of an oyster.
FIBRIL: A small fiber; the branch of a fiber; a very slender thread; afibrilla. Cheyne.
FERIA: A week day, esp. a day which is neither a festival nor a fast.Shipley.
FESCUE: A grass of the genus Festuca. Fescue grass (Bot.), a genus ofgrasses (Festuca) containing several species of importance inagriculture. Festuca ovina is sheep's fescue; F. elatior is meadowfescue.
FIJIAN: Of or pertaining to the Fiji islands or their inhabitants.-- n.
FAR: A young pig, or a litter of pigs.
FLASH: To cover with a thin layer, as objects of glass with glass of adifferent color. See Flashing, n., 3 (b).
FUZZLE: To make drunk; to intoxicate; to fuddle. [Obs.] Burton.
FINESTILL: To distill, as spirit from molasses or some saccharinepreparation.
FINITE: Having a limit; limited in quantity, degree, or capacity;bounded; -- opposed to infinite; as, finite number; finite existence;a finite being; a finite mind; finite duration.
FOLKLAND: Land held in villenage, being distributed among the folk, orpeople, at the pleasure of the lord of the manor, and resumed at hisdiscretion. Not being held by any assurance in writing, it wasopposed to bookland or charter land, which was held by deed. Mozley &W.
FLAGON: A vessel with a narrow mouth, used for holding and conveyingliquors. It is generally larger than a bottle, and of leather orstoneware rather than of glass.A trencher of mutton chops, and a flagon of ale. Macaulay.
FOWLERITE: A variety of rhodonite, from Franklin Furnace, New Jersey,containing some zinc.
FIRSTBORN: First brought forth; first in the order of nativity; eldest;hence, most excellent; most distinguished or exalted.
FLISK: To frisk; to skip; to caper. [Obs. Scot.] "The flisking flies."Gosson.
FASCIATION: The act or manner of binding up; bandage; also, the conditionof being fasciated.
FONT: A complete assortment of printing type of one size, including adue proportion of all the letters in the alphabet, large and small,points, accents, and whatever else is necessary for printing withthat variety of types; a fount.
FARMING: Pertaining to agriculture; devoted to, adapted to, or engagedin, farming; as, farming tools; farming land; a farming community.
FLEAWORT: An herb used in medicine (Plantago Psyllium), named from theshape of its seeds. Loudon.
FECULENT: Foul with extraneous or impure substances; abounding withsediment or excrementitious matter; muddy; thick; turbid.Both his hands most filthy feculent. Spenser.
FOILER: One who foils or frustrates. Johnson.
FASCINE: A cylindrical bundle of small sticks of wood, bound together,used in raising batteries, filling ditches, strengthening ramparts,and making parapets; also in revetments for river banks, and in matsfor dams, jetties, etc.
FISTULAR: Hollow and cylindrical, like a pipe or reed. Johnson.
FUNGUS: Any one of the Fungi, a large and very complex group ofthallophytes of low organization, -- the molds, mildews, rusts,smuts, mushrooms, toadstools, puff balls, and the allies of each.
FEAR: A variant of Fere, a mate, a companion. [Obs.] Spenser.
FOIN: The beech marten (Mustela foina). See Marten.
FLAUNT: To throw or spread out; to flutter; to move ostentatiously; as,a flaunting show.You flaunt about the streets in your new gilt chariot. Arbuthnot.One flaunts in rags, one flutters in brocade. Pope.
FRENZY: Any violent agitation of the mind approaching to distraction;violent and temporary derangement of the mental faculties; madness;rage.All else is towering frenzy and distraction. Addison.The poet's eye in a fine frenzy rolling. Shak.
FLAGGINESS: The condition of being flaggy; laxity; limberness. Johnson.
FOGYISM: The principles and conduct of a fogy. [Colloq.]
FINDING: The result of a judicial examination or inquiry, especiallyinto some matter of fact; a verdict; as, the finding of a jury.Burrill.After his friends finding and his rent. Chaucer.
FACING: The finishing of any face of a wall with material differentfrom that of which it is chiefly composed, or the coating or materialso used.
FRANCHISE: A particular privilege conferred by grant from a sovereign or agovernment, and vested in individuals; an imunity or exemption fromordinary jurisdiction; a constitutional or statutory right orprivilege, esp. the right to vote.Election by universal suffrage, as modified by the Constitution, isthe one crowning franchise of the American people. W. H. Seward.
FEUDARY: Held by, or pertaining to, feudal tenure.
FALSELY: In a false manner; erroneously; not truly; perfidiously ortreacherously. "O falsely, falsely murdered." Shak.Oppositions of science, falsely so called. 1 Tim. vi. 20.Will ye steal, murder . . . and swear falsely Jer. vii. 9.
FOTHER: To stop (a leak in a ship at sea) by drawing under its bottom athrummed sail, so that the pressure of the water may force it intothe crack. Totten.
FOOLHARDINESS: Courage without sense or judgment; foolish rashness;recklessness. Dryden.
FLOATING: Floating threads. See Floating threads, above.
FORELAND: A piece of ground between the wall of a place and the moat.Farrow.
FOREST: A large extent or precinct of country, generally waste andwoody, belonging to the sovereign, set apart for the keeping of gamefor his use, not inclosed, but distinguished by certain limits, andprotected by certain laws, courts, and officers of its own. Burrill.
FAKER: One who fakes something, as a thief, a peddler of petty things,a workman who dresses things up, etc. [Slang]
FIELDFARE: a small thrush (Turdus pilaris) which breeds in northern Europeand winters in Great Britain. The head, nape, and lower part of theback are ash-colored; the upper part of the back and wing coverts,chestnut; -- called also fellfare.
FLOUNDER: A flatfish of the family Pleuronectidæ, of many species.
FERRET-EYE: The spur-winged goose; -- so called from the red circle aroundthe eyes.
FINDFAULTING: Apt to censure or cavil; faultfinding; captious. [Obs.]Whitlock.
FILOPLUMACEOUS: Having the structure of a filoplume.
FREQUENTAGE: The practice or habit of frequenting. [R.] Southey.
FRUSTULE: The siliceous shell of a diatom. It is composed of two valves,one overlapping the other, like a pill box and its cover.
FORMED: Arranged, as stars in a constellation; as, formed stars. [R.]
FREE-MINDED: Not perplexed; having a mind free from care. Bacon.
FUCHSIA: A genus of flowering plants having elegant drooping flowers,with four sepals, four petals, eight stamens, and a single pistil.They are natives of Mexico and South America. Double-floweredvarieties are now common in cultivation.
FLEAK: A flake; a thread or twist. [Obs.]Little long fleaks or threads of hemp. Dr. H. More.
FILM: To cover with a thin skin or pellicle.It will but skin and film the ulcerous place. Shak.
FRESH-WATER: A lantern having a lamp surrounded by a hollow cylindricalFresnel lens.
FELON: A person who has committed a felony.
FARMER: One who farms; as:(a) One who hires and cultivates a farm; a cultivator of leasedground; a tenant. Smart.(b) One who is devoted to the tillage of the soil; one who cultivatesa farm; an agriculturist; a husbandman.(c) One who takes taxes, customs, excise, or other duties, tocollect, either paying a fixed annuual rent for the privilege; as, afarmer of the revenues.(d) (Mining) The lord of the field, or one who farms the lot and copeof the crown. Farmer-general Etym: [F. fermier-general], one to whomthe right of levying certain taxes, in a particular district, wasfarmed out, under the former French monarchy, for a given sum paiddown.-- Farmers' satin, a light material of cotton and worsted, used forcoat linings. McElrath.-- The king's farmer (O. Eng. Law), one to whom the collection of aroyal revenue was farmed out. Burrill.
FATLING: A calf, lamb, kid, or other young animal fattened forslaughter; a fat animal; -- said of such animals as are used forfood.He sacrificed oxen and fatlings. 2 Sam. vi. 13.
FLUKY: Formed like, or having, a fluke.
FIBRINATION: The state of acquiring or having an excess of fibrin.
FIREBOARD: A chimney board or screen to close a fireplace when not in use.
FRUITION: Use or possession of anything, especially such as isaccompanied with pleasure or satisfaction; pleasure derived frompossession or use. "Capacity of fruition." Rogers. "Godlikefruition." Milton.Where I may have fruition of her love. Shak.
FORELIE: To lie in front of. [Obs.]Which forelay Athwart her snowy breast. Spenser.
FRIATION: The act of breaking up or pulverizing.
FRUMENTATION: A largess of grain bestowed upon the people, to quiet them whenuneasy.
FULHAM: A false die. [Cant] [Written also fullam.] Shak.
FORECITED: Cited or quoted before or above. Arbuthnot.
FREE-LOVER: One who believes in or practices free-love.
FISSION: A method of asexual reproduction among the lowest (unicellular)organisms by means of a process of self-division, consisting ofgradual division or cleavage of the into two parts, each of whichthen becomes a separate and independent organisms; as when a cell inan animal or plant, or its germ, undergoes a spontaneous division,and the parts again subdivide. See Segmentation, and Cell division,under Division.
FORETASTE: A taste beforehand; enjoyment in advance; anticipation.
FUSTIGATION: A punishment by beating with a stick or club; cudgeling.This satire, composed of actual fustigation. Motley.
FINFOOT: A South American bird (heliornis fulica) allied to the grebes.The name is also applied to several related species of the genusPodica.
FANATICISM: Excessive enthusiasm, unreasoning zeal, or wild and extravagantnotions, on any subject, especially religion; religious frenzy.
FALLOPIAN: Pertaining to, or discovered by, Fallopius; as, the Fallopiantubes or oviducts, the ducts or canals which conduct the ova from theovaries to the uterus.
FRUSTUM: The part of a solid next the base, formed by cutting off the,top; or the part of any solid, as of a cone, pyramid, etc., betweentwo planes, which may be either parallel or inclined to each other.
FLYING BOAT: A compact form of hydro-aëroplane having one central body, orhull.
FECAL: relating to, or containing, dregs, feces, or ordeure; fæcal.
FUSIBLE: CapabIe of being melted or liquefied. Fusible metal, any alloyof different metals capable of being easily fused, especially analloy of five parts of bismuth, three of lead, and two of tin, whichmelts at a temperature below that of boiling water. Ure.-- Fusible plug (Steam Boiler), a piece of easily fusible alloy,placed in one of the sheets and intended to melt and blow off thesteam in case of low water.
FUNGIFORM: Shaped like a fungus or mushroom. Fungiform papillæ (Anat.),numerous small, rounded eminences on the upper surface of the tongue.
FLIP-FLAP: The repeated stroke of something long and loose. Johnson.
FEOFFEE: The person to whom a feoffment is made; the person enfeoffed.
FORESIGHTED: Sagacious; prudent; provident for the future. Bartram.
FRUITY: Having the odor, taste, or appearance of fruit; also, fruitful.Dickens.
FULL-BUTT: With direct and violentop position; with sudden collision.[Colloq.] L'Estrange.
FLUTEMOUTH: A fish of the genus Aulostoma, having a much elongated tubularsnout.
FAT-KIDNEYED: Gross; lubberly.Peace, ye fat-kidneyed rascal ! Shak.
FOREKNOW: To have previous knowledge of; to know beforehand.Who would the miseries of man foreknow Dryden.
FERTILIZATION: The act of fecundating or impregnating animal or vegetablegerms; esp., the process by which in flowers the pollen renders theovule fertile, or an analogous process in flowerless plants;fecundation; impregnation. Close fertilization (Bot.), thefertilization of pistils by pollen derived from the stamens of thesame blossom.-- Cross fertilization, fertilization by pollen from some otherblossom. See under Cross, a.
FLOORWALKER: One who walks about in a large retail store as an overseer anddirector. [U.S.]
FILMY: Composed of film or films.Whose filmy cord should bind the struggling fly. Dryden.
FORMELL: The female of a hawk or falcon.
FILTRATION: The act or process of filtering; the mechanical separation of aliquid from the undissolved particles floating in it.
FROG-EYED: Spotted with whitish specks due to a disease, or producedartificially by spraying; -- said of tobacco used for cigar wrappers.
FROTERER: One who frotes; one who rubs or chafes. [Obs.] Marston.
FACTITIOUS: Made by art, in distinction from what is produced by nature;artificial; sham; formed by, or adapted to, an artificial orconventional, in distinction from a natural, standard or rule; notnatural; as, factitious cinnabar or jewels; a factitious taste.-- Fac-ti"tious*ly, adv.-- Fac*ti"tious-ness, n.He acquires a factitious propensity, he forms an incorrigible habit,of desultory reading. De Quincey.
FLUCTUABILITY: The capacity or ability to fluctuate. [R.] H. Walpole.
FLEA-BEETLE: A small beetle of the family Halticidæ, of many species. Theyhave strong posterior legs and leap like fleas. The turnip flea-beetle (Phyllotreta vittata) and that of the grapevine (Graptoderachalybea) are common injurious species.
FRUITFUL: Full of fruit; producing fruit abundantly; bearing results;prolific; fertile; liberal; bountiful; as, a fruitful tree, orseason, or soil; a fruitful wife.-- Fruit"ful*ly, adv.-- Fruit"ful*ness, n.Be fruitful and multiply and replenish the earth. Gen. i. 28.[Nature] By disburdening grows More fruitful. Milton.The great fruitfulness of the poet's fancy. Addison.
FORMIDABLENESS: The quality of being formidable, or adapted to excite dread.Boyle.
FLITE: To scold; to quarrel. [Prov. Eng.] Grose.
FRANK-CHASE: The liberty or franchise of having a chase; free chase.Burrill.
FRORE: Frostily. [Obs.]The parching air Burns frore, and cold performs the effect of fire.Milton.
FAUSSE-BRAYE: A second raampart, exterior to, and parallel to, the mainrampart, and considerably below its level.
FALCONER: A person who breeds or trains hawks for taking birds or game;one who follows the sport of fowling with hawks. Johnson.
FRANTIC: Mad; raving; furious; violent; wild and disorderly; distracted.Die, frantic wretch, for this accursed deed! Shak.Torrents of frantic abuse. Macaulay.-- Fran"tic*al*ly, adv.-- Fran"tic*ly, adv. Shak.-- Fran"tic*ness, n. Johnson.
FLEE: To run away, as from danger or evil; to avoid in an alarmed orcowardly manner; to hasten off; -- usually with from. This issometimes omitted, making the verb transitive.[He] cowardly fled, not having struck one stroke. Shak.Flee fornication. 1 Cor. vi. 18.So fled his enemies my warlike father. Shak.
FLAMY: Flaming; blazing; flamelike; flame-colored; composed of flame.Pope.
FUNICULAR: Pertaining to a funiculus; made up of, or resembling, afuniculus, or funiculi; as, a funicular ligament. Funicular action(Mech.), the force or action exerted by a rope in drawing togetherthe supports to which its ends are Fastened, when acted upon byforces applied in a direction transverse to the rope, as in thearcher's bow.-- Funicular curve. Same as Catenary.-- Funicular machine (Mech.), an apparatus for illustrating certainprinciples in statics, consisting of a cord or chain attached at oneend to a fixed point, and having the other passed over a pulley andsustaining a weight, while one or more other weights are suspendedfrom the cord at points between the fixed support and the pulley.-- Funicular polygon (Mech.), the polygonal figure assumed by a cordfastened at its extremities, and sustaining weights at differentpoints.
FERRIS WHEEL: An amusement device consisting of a giant power-driven steelwheel, revolvable on its stationary axle, and carrying a number ofbalanced passenger cars around its rim; -- so called after G. W. G.Ferris, American engineer, who erected the first of its kind for theWorld's Columbian Exposition in Chicago in 1893.
FOLKMOTE: An assembly of the people; esp. (Sax. Law),
FIRST-HAND: Obtained directly from the first or original source; hence,without the intervention of an agent.One sphere there is . . . where the apprehension of him is first-handand direct; and that is the sphere of our own mind. J. Martineau.
FERTILITATE: To fertilize; to fecundate. Sir T. Browne.
FORCEPS: The caudal forceps-shaped appendage of earwigs and some otherinsects. See Earwig. Dressing forceps. See under Dressing.
FIELD: The whole surface of an escutcheon; also, so much of it isshown unconcealed by the different bearings upon it. See Illust. ofFess, where the field is represented as gules (red), while the fessis argent (silver).
FURY: A thief. [Obs.]Have an eye to your plate, for there be furies. J. Fleteher.
FOOZLE: To bungle; to manage awkwardly; to treat or play unskillfully;as, to foozle a stroke in golf.
FOLLICLE: A simple podlike pericarp which contains several seeds andopens along the inner or ventral suture, as in the peony, larkspurand milkweed.
FOUNDLING: A deserted or exposed infant; a child found without a parent orowner. Foundling hospital, a hospital for foundlings.
FLY-CATCHING: Having the habit of catching insects on the wing.
FOSSETTE: A small, deep-centered ulcer of the transparent cornea.
FLECKLESS: Without spot or blame. [R.]My consnience will not count me fleckless. Tennyson.
FOSTERAGE: The care of a foster child; the charge of nursing. Sir W.Raleigh.
FLAGITATE: To importune; to demand fiercely or with passion. [Archaic]Carcyle.
FORENOON: The early part of the day, from morning to meridian, or noon.
FLAT: Wanting relief; destitute of variety; without points ofprominence and striking interest.A large part of the work is, to me, very flat. Coleridge.
FLEXIBILITY: The state or quality of being flexible; flexibleness; pliancy;pliability; as, the flexibility of strips of hemlock, hickory,whalebone or metal, or of rays of light. Sir I. Newton.All the flexibility of a veteran courtier. Macaulay.
FEUILLANTS: A reformed branch of the Bernardines, founded in 1577 atFeuillans, near Toulouse, in France.
FIELDER: A ball payer who stands out in the field to catch or stopballs.
FAVORITISM: The disposition to favor and promote the interest of one personor family, or of one class of men, to the neglect of others havingequal claims; partiality.A spirit of favoritism to the Bank of the United States. A. Hamilton.
FORMALLY: In a formal manner; essentially; characteristically; expressly;regularly; ceremoniously; precisely.That which formally makes this [charity] a Christian grace, is thespring from which it flows. Smalridge.You and your followers do stand formally divided against theauthorized guides of the church and rest of the people. Hooker.
FARRAGINOUS: Formed of various materials; mixed; as, a farraginous mountain.[R.] Kirwan.AA farraginous concurrence of all conditions, tempers, sexes, andages. Sir T. Browne.
FOGE: The Cornish name for a forge used for smelting tin. Raymond
FLACHERIE: A bacterial disease of silkworms, supposed to be due to eatingcontaminated mulberry leaves.
FUNCTION: The appropriate action of any special organ or part of ananimal or vegetable organism; as, the function of the heart or thelimbs; the function of leaves, sap, roots, etc.; life is the sum ofthe functions of the various organs and parts of the body.
FARANDAMS: A fabrik made of silk and wool or hair. Simmonds.
FIDEJUSSOR: A surety; one bound for another, conjointly with him; aguarantor. Blackstone.
FLAVOR: To give flavor to; to add something (as salt or a spice) to, togive character or zest.
FANTASTIC: A person given to fantastic dress, manners, etc.; an eccentricperson; a fop. Milton.Our fantastics, who, having a fine watch, take all ocasions to drowit out to be seen. Fuller.
FOSSIL: Like or pertaining to fossils; contained in rocks. whetherpetrified or not; as, fossil plants, shells. Fossil copal, a resinoussubstance, first found in the blue clay at Highgate, near London, andapparently a vegetable resin, partly changed by remaining in theearth.-- Fossil cork, flax, paper, or wood, varieties of amianthus.-- Fossil farina, a soft carbonate of lime.-- Fossil ore, fossiliferous red hematite. Raymond.
FOOTMAN: A moth of the family Lithosidæ; -- so called from its livery-like colors.
FOREKNOWINGLY: With foreknowledge.He who . . . foreknowingly loses his life. Jer. Taylor.
FIPPLE: A stopper, as in a wind instrument of music. [Obs.] Bacon.
FIT: imp. & p. p. of Fight. [Obs. or Colloq.]
FACTIVE: Making; having power to make. [Obs.] "You are . . . factive,not destructive." Bacon.
FLOURISHINGLY: , adv. In a flourishing manner; ostentatiously.
FOOTFIGHT: A conflict by persons on foot; -- distinguished from a fight onhorseback. Sir P. Sidney.
FLAMBOYER: A name given in the East and West Indies to certain trees withbrilliant blossoms, probably species of Cæsalpinia.
FREQUENTATION: The act or habit of frequenting or visiting often; resort.Chesterfield.
FREMITUS: Palpable vibration or thrill; as, the rhonchial fremitus.
FLOUNCE: To throw the limbs and body one way and the other; to spring,turn, or twist with sudden effort or violence; to struggle, as ahorse in mire; to flounder; to throw one's self with a jerk or spasm,often as in displeasure.To flutter and flounce will do nothing but batter and bruise us.Barrow.With his broad fins and forky tail he laves The rising sirge, andflounces in the waves. Addison.
FERRYBOAT: A vessel for conveying passengers, merchandise, etc., acrossstreams and other narrow waters.
FURRING: Double planking of a ship's side.
FADEDLY: In a faded manner.A dull room fadedly furnished. Dickens.
FINESPUN: Spun so as to be fine; drawn to a fine thread; attenuated;hence, unsubstantial; visionary; as, finespun theories.
FLAGELLANT: One of a fanatical sect which flourished in Europe in the 13thand 14th centuries, and maintained that flagellation was of equalvirtue with baptism and the sacrament; -- called also disciplinant.
FORFEITABLE: Liable to be forfeited; subject to forfeiture.For the future, uses shall be subject to the statutes of mortmain,and forfeitable, like the lands themselves. Blackstone.
FORISFAMILIATE: Literally, to put out of a family; hence, to portion off, so asto exclude further claim of inheritance; to emancipate (as a with hisown consent) from paternal authority. Blackstone.
FERRUMINATION: The soldering ir uniting of me [R.] Coleridge.
FULLAGE: The money or price paid for fulling or cleansing cloth.Johnson.
FIVELING: A compound or twin crystal consisting of five individuals.
FOREVOUCHED: Formerly vouched or avowed; affirmed in advance. [R.] Shak.
FOOTFALL: A setting down of the foot; a footstep; the sound of afootstep. Shak.Seraphim, whose footfalls tinkled on the tufted floor. Poe
FILOSELLE: A kind of silk thread less glossy than floss, and spun fromcoarser material. It is much used in embroidery instead of floss.
FRICTIONAL: Relating to friction; moved by friction; produced by friction;as, frictional electricity. Frictional gearing, wheels which transmitmotion by surface friction instead of teeth. The faces are sometimesmade more or less V-shaped to increase or decrease friction, asrequired.
FICE: A small dog; -- written also fise, fyce, fiste, etc. [SouthernU.S.]
FLANGE: To make a flange on; to furnish with a flange.
FURFURINE: A white, crystalline base, obtained indirectly from furfurol.
FARADIC: Of or pertaining to Michael Faraday, the distinguishedelectrician; -- applied especially to induced currents ofelectricity, as produced by certain forms of inductive apparatus, onaccount of Faraday's investigations of their laws.
FAULT-FINDING: The act of finding fault or blaming; -- used derogatively. AlsoAdj.
FLUFFY: Pertaining to, or resembling, fluff or nap; soft and downy."The carpets were fluffy." Thackeray.The present Barnacle . . . had a youthful aspect, and the fluffiestlittle whisker, perhaps, that ever was seen. Dickens.-- Fluff"i*ness, n.
FALCIDIAN: Of or pertaining to Publius Falcidius, a Roman tribune.Falcidian law (Civil Law), a law by which a testator was obliged toleave at least a fourth of his estate to the heir. Burrill.
FRANK-LAW: The liberty of being sworn in courts, as a juror or witness;one of the ancient privileges of a freeman; free and common law; --an obsolete expression signifying substantially the same as theAmerican expression civil rights. Abbot.
FITFUL: Full of fits; irregularly variable; impulsive and unstable.After life's fitful fever, he sleeps well. Shak.-- Fit"ful*ly, adv.-- Fit"ful*ness, n.The victorius trumpet peal Dies fitfully away. Macaulay.
FIRE BEETLE: A very brilliantly luminous beetle (Pyrophorus noctilucus), oneof the elaters, found in Central and South America; -- called alsocucujo. The name is also applied to other species. See Firefly.
FLORIDEAE: A subclass of algæ including all the red or purplish seaweeds;the Rhodospermeæ of many authors; -- so called from the rosy orflorid color of most of the species.
FIBRINOPLASTIC: Like fibrinoplastin; capable of forming fibrin when brought incontact with fibrinogen.
FREAKISH: Apt to change the mind suddenly; whimsical; capricious.It may be a question whether the wife or the woman was the morefreakish of the two. L'Estrange.Freakish when well, and fretful when she's sick. Pope.-- Freak"ish*ly, adv.-- Freak"ish*ness, n.
FAGGING: Laborious drudgery; esp., the acting as a drudge for another atan English school.
FLEAMY: Bloody; clotted. [Obs. or Prov.]Foamy bubbling of a fleamy brain. Marston.
FREEBOOTERY: The act, practice, or gains of a freebooter; freebooting.Booth.
FURUNCULAR: Of or pertaining to a furuncle; marked by the presence offuruncles.
FRAPPE: Iced; frozen; artificially cooled; as, wine frappé. -- n.
FLATBILL: Any bird of the genus Flatyrynchus. They belong to the familyof flycatchers.
FURL: To draw up or gather into close compass; to wrap or roll, as asail, close to the yard, stay, or mast, or, as a flag, close to oraround its staff, securing it there by a gasket or line. Totten.
FLUSTER: To make hot and rosy, as with drinking; to heat; hence, tothrow into agitation and confusion; to confuse; to muddle.His habit or flustering himself daily with claret. Macaulay.
